Market data and certain economic and industry data, forecasts used, and statements regarding our position in the industry made, in this Offering Memorandum are based upon market research, government and other publicly available information, reports prepared by third-party industry consultants and independent industry publications. In particular, we have used data extracted from the following sources (the “Industry Reports”): - Frost & Sullivan Global Heat Exchanger Growth Opportunities (May 2023) (the “Frost & Sullivan

We are a leading global provider of heat exchanger solutions with more than 100 years of experience in design, manufacturing, installation and service (source: Frost & Sullivan Report). We have built our strategic pillars on (i) High Tech applications and solutions, in particular for Data Centers with liquid and free cooling, (ii) Green Tech applications and solutions in various vertical markets, such as Power & Energy, HVAC, Hydrogen, Liquified Natural Gas, Carbon Capture Storage, (iii) Conventional applications, such as in the Refrigeration, Food & Beverage, Chemicals and Oil & Gas vertical markets, as well as (iv) Service applications across all our vertical markets and product groups. Our diversified presence across regions and transformative industries are supported by long-term underlying megatrends, such as digitalization, energy transition and environmental concerns in general. Based on the breath of our product portfolio, extensive global footprint, and diverse end-markets, as well as our technology leadership position and R&D capabilities, we believe we are well-positioned to benefit from the long-term growth trends in our vertical markets. Since 2021, under our new management, we have been implementing a comprehensive strategic program known as “High Five”. The High Five program is designed to build a long-term sustainable business and comprises the following five strategic pillars: (i) Grow High Tech, (ii) Grow Green Tech, (iii) More Service, (iv) Grow APAC & Americas and (v) More Digitalization, with greater emphasis on reducing complexity through digitalization. At the same time, we divested unprofitable businesses, such as the Enexio in recent years. Since the beginning of 2021 and despite several external shocks, such as the Russia-Ukraine war and the spike in energy prices and inflation caused thereby, our Order Intake, Revenue and Normalized EBITDA have increased from €1,099.3 million, €931.7 million and €78.8 million, respectively, for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €1,697.9 million, €1,347.9 million and €146.9 million, respectively, for the year ended December 31, 2023. Historically, our business operations have been primarily divided into four product groups: Kelvion Thermal Solutions (“KTS”), Refrigeration Technologies (“RT”), Plate Heat Exchangers (“PHE”) and Machine Cooling Systems (“MCS”). We also consider our key vertical markets and geographic regions in the management of our business. - _KTS provides air fin coolers and cooling towers for installations with large cooling requirements as well as air dryers used to remove humidity from air streams. KTS focuses on providing customized solutions and primarily serves Data Centers, Power & Energy, Oil & Gas and Chemicals vertical markets. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, KTS accounted for 44.6% of our revenue. - _RT supplies standard and customized heat exchangers for cooling and removing heat in different applications using air and liquid cooling methods. The primary vertical markets are HVAC, refrigeration applications and Data Centers. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, RT accounted for 20.5% of our revenue. - _PHE offers a range of gasketed, brazed and welded plate heat exchangers for a variety of applications and vertical markets, including HVAC, Food & Beverage, Chemicals, Power & Energy and Heavy & Light Equipment. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, PHE accounted for 17.9% of our revenue. - _MCS supplies heat exchangers for power generation, power transmission, large engine applications (marine and off-highway) and Green Tech applications such as biomass, green hydrogen, or renewable energies. The primary vertical markets are Transportation, Heavy & Light Equipment, Power & Energy and Oil & Gas. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, MCS accounted for 14.3% of our revenue. Since the beginning of 2024, the RT, MCS and PHE have been managed on a regional basis in the following geographic regions – Americas, APAC and EMEA. In addition, all our product groups’ activities are complemented by a comprehensive after-sales support and services offering, reflecting our ability to support our customers with full-service packages thereby reducing their operating costs. We provide services both for our own products as well as for third-party products, managed on a centralized and global basis across our product groups. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our service business generated revenues of €251 million and for the year ended December 31, 2023 revenues of €259 million, an increase of 21% compared to the year ended December 31, 2022. 1 ----- We have a large and diverse customer base, including many blue-chip customers, and have built long-standing customer partnerships. Our customer base comprises more than 19,000 active customers (i.e., customers that have placed an order with us in the last 24 months) and repeat orders over multiple years from more than 12,000 customers. Our customer base is also diversified across vertical markets and geographies. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our Order Intake by strategic pillar can be broken down as follows: circa 39% in High Tech, circa 36% in Conventional applications, circa 17% in services and circa 7% in Green Tech. During the same period, the Order Intake by geography comprised circa 45% in EMEA, circa 42% in Americas and circa 13% in APAC. Headquartered in Herne, Germany, we operate in 24 countries around the world, with 22 production facilities, 33 service centers and 19 engineering centers as of March 31, 2024. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, we generated total revenue of €1,401 million and Normalized EBITDA of €157.2 million.

Subsubsection Title: Global market leader for mission-critical solutions to transformative industries, including Data Centers, Power & Energy, HVAC, Carbon Capture Storage and Hydrogen
Subsubsection Text: We are a leading global provider of heat exchanger solutions (source: Frost & Sullivan Report) serving a diverse range of transformative industries (such as Data Centers, Power & Energy, HVAC, Carbon Capture Storage, and Hydrogen), and vertical markets with a broad and differentiated product portfolio. We are also among the top three global providers (based on our Order Intake in the addressable market, as of 2022) and the only company that can provide the full spectrum of solutions across all vertical markets globally. Our leading market position is supported by our comprehensive geographical footprint with operations in 24 countries (comprising 22 production facilities, 33 service centers and 19 engineering centers as of March 31, 2024) as well as our diverse product offering across a broad range of heat exchanger products, which differentiates us from our competitors. Our solutions and products are often mission-critical to our clients’ operations because they are necessary to ensure the efficiency and safety of our clients’ operations while they only represent a relatively small portion of the overall cost. Transformative Industries support the exponential growth of digital data by providing the infrastructure for data storage, processing, and management of digital data. Innovations in cooling and energy efficiency are transforming this sector. Power & Energy includes renewable sources, smart grids and energy storage solutions. Advances in these areas are crucial for reducing carbon emissions and transitioning to a more sustainable energy framework. Innovations in HVAC systems are enhancing energy efficiency, comfort in residential, commercial and industrial buildings. Smart HVAC technologies and sustainable practices are at the forefront of this transformation. The Carbon Capture Storage industry focuses on technologies to capture and store carbon dioxide emissions from industrial processes and power generation, helping to mitigate climate change. Lastly, the Hydrogen industry is developing technologies for producing, storing, and utilizing hydrogen as a clean energy source. Hydrogen has the potential to play a significant role in decarbonizing transportation, industry and power generation. As part of our High Five program, we focus on vertical markets within the strategic pillars High Tech and Green Tech. These strategic pillars present a significant market opportunity to us which is forecast to grow significantly until 2027. We estimate that the total addressable market for heat exchangers in the vertical markets comprising our High Tech and Green Tech pillars amounted to €2.4 billion and €1.1 billion in 2022, respectively (source: Frost & Sullivan Report, MarketsandMarkets Report, Third Party Report and internal company assessments). These vertical markets are also forecast to have the most attractive growth rates, expanding at a CAGR of 8% and 20%, respectively, between 2022 and 2027. During the same period, we reduced our exposure to Oil & Gas, Chemicals and Power & Energy from 37% of our Order Intake for the year ended December 31, 2021 to 29% in the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. Our decentralized model of local production, near our customers, helps us maintain our leading positions in our core geographic regions. Our ability to provide a one-stop shop product approach combined with our service offering is increasingly valued by customers. Compared to smaller, regionally focused peers, we believe we have a better understanding of technical, health, safety and environmental regulation standards globally and locally. Combined with our scale and logistical strength to carry out large projects which are generally command improved margins. We believe that this differentiated product and service offering has been instrumental for recent contract wins from key customers. For example, we were awarded an order from a leading US-based bitcoin mining platform for adiabatic hybrid coolers. We developed a customized solution focusing on water and energy consumption. As a result, our cooling solution required 70% less water and 25% less energy than existing models, which also aligns well with our own long-term sustainability goals. Another example is an order from a US-based hyperscaler in the Data Center vertical market. Through measures, such as joint technology workshops with the customer, material optimization and a design-to-cost approach, we believe we were able to reduce the material requirements for our heat exchanger solutions by approximately 10% compared to existing models. Our global scale also underpins the strength of our brand, which places us well to continue to strengthen our positions in these fast growing and transformative end-markets segments and vertical markets. 2 -----

Subsubsection Title: Well-positioned to benefit from long-term sustainable secular megatrends, such as increasing environmental awareness and the changes triggered by energy transition, along with the growth of digitalization
Subsubsection Text: We believe we are strategically well-positioned to benefit from underlying megatrends across our strategic pillars and vertical markets. The key pillars and vertical markets we serve are characterized by underlying growth supported by long-term sustainable trends. For example, the High Tech market, which accounted for 39% of our Order Intake for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, is projected to increase at a CAGR of 8% from 2022 to 2027 due to strong and growing demand for data centers. The Green Tech market, which accounted for 7% of our Order Intake for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, is expected to grow at a CAGR of 20% between 2022 to 2027 based on an increasing focus on energy efficiency and environmental awareness, which, in turn, is driving regulatory changes aimed at climate protection and heat recovery for residential and commercial buildings as well as for industrial applications (source: Frost & Sullivan Report, MarketsandMarkets Report, Third Party Report and internal company assessments). Similar global trends and the (re)-industrialization in Conventional markets underpin the growth outlook across a range of industries, with the services business also being transformed by a shift to, and higher demand for, high-proximity and intelligent services. Note: Based on nominal rates. Primary market for Green Tech is Heat Pumps (HVAC), but definition of Green Tech includes other vertical markets such as LNG, Green Hydrogen, Carbon Capture and Bio-ethanol. OI = Order Intake (1) Electric power generation and distribution (2) Including Marine & Shipbuilding, Mining, Water and Wastewater (3) Difference in the sum due to “other industries” segment, accounting for circa €30m of revenue and circa €34m of Order Intake 2023 Source: Frost & Sullivan Report

Subsubsection Title: Difficult to replicate business model, underpinned by differentiated engineering solutions, service capabilities and customer responsiveness
Subsubsection Text: We believe our differentiated technical offerings and service capabilities are difficult to replicate and, consequently, create high barriers to entry and prevent new competitors from easily entering our markets. Our application engineering expertise and production know-how are based on decades of experience and supported by our network of 19 engineering centers and more than 450 engineers worldwide. Our innovation portfolio includes hybrid coolers for High Tech, our advanced diffusion bonded heat exchanger “K°Bond” used in oil rigs, LNG, regasification facilities and CO2 stations, natural refrigerants, high pressure laser (HPL) for Green Tech and hydrogen leakage testing for Services. In particular, our advanced manufacturing technologies, including 3D design and simulation, help to improve product performance and reduce failure rates. In addition, computational fluid design and simulation is validated by our inhouse labs and supports the development of our thermal design know-how and proprietary software, which enables us to design solutions according to customer requirements. Our differentiated technical solutions are complemented by our strong Service offering and proximity to our customers, including the ability to provide local service to global customers based on our presence in 24 countries and the ability to service other third-party brands. This is backed by performance agreements, aimed at maximizing customers’ return on investment and predictive maintenance to reduce operational downtime. We have a full-service portfolio spanning start-up (safe delivery, installation and early start post installation support), inspection and maintenance (period checks), repairs and overhauls, testing and monitoring (understanding condition of equipment), spare parts (designed to match the original parts), upgrades and replacements (for outdated components) and consulting and training (leading to competency 3 ----- of client personnel). We believe the breadth of our portfolio of Services offers customers seamless operation across the globe. The responsiveness to our customers, and our close working relationship build trust in our solutions and delivery. This builds long-term partnerships and trust fostering reliability as evidenced by the high proportion of our 19,000 active customers (i.e., customers that have placed an order with us in the last 24 months) that have placed repeat orders over multiple years. We are of the opinion that these long-term partnerships are another factor that makes our business model difficult to replicate.

Subsubsection Title: Highly diversified revenue stream across geographies and vertical markets ensuring stable growth and operational flexibility
Subsubsection Text: The combination of our global footprint, comprehensive product portfolio and range of vertical markets we serve provides us with a well-diversified income stream. We serve approximately ten vertical markets and have operations in 24 countries. This allows us to realize growth opportunities from higher demand in individual sectors or regions, for example in the Data Center vertical market where revenue contribution increased by 88% in the year ended December 31, 2023 (compared to the year ended December 31, 2022). We also believe this helps us better withstand adverse changes and developments in a particular market or sector. The charts below show our revenue, by vertical market and by geography, for the year ended December 31, 2023. (1) Based on customer country

Subsubsection Title: High revenue visibility from strong Order Intake and Order Backlog development
Subsubsection Text: Our Order Intake and Order Backlog provide us with high revenue visibility, and we believe the strong development in our Order Intake and Order Backlog will support our future performance and continued growth. From 2021 to 2023, Order Intake increased at a CAGR of approximately 24%, from €1,099 million in the year ended December 31, 2021, to €1,698 million in the year ended December 31, 2023 and Order Backlog increased from €615 million as of December 31, 2021 to €1,103 million as of December 31, 2023. Over the same period, our revenue increased from €931.7 million in the year ended December 31, 2021, to €1,347.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, resulting in a consistent ratio of Order Intake to revenue of more than 1.0x (“book-to-bill ratio”) across the periods. Moreover, for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our book-to-bill-ratio amounted to 1.1x. Revenue visibility is further enhanced by the fact that, historically, a majority of our Order Intake in any given year was converted into revenue in the same fiscal year or the next succeeding year. The portion of our Order Intake in the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023 that was or is planned to be converted into revenue in the same year or the next succeeding year represented 51% and 54% of our revenue for the years ended December 31, 2022, and 2023 as well as 62% of our budgeted revenue for the year ending December 31, 2024. We believe that our high revenue visibility also helps drive our profitability as it allows for improved management of customer order fulfilment, efficient operations planning and hence limits impacts under absorption. Our diversified presence across geographic regions and vertical markets enables us to benefit from increasing demand in specific regions and vertical markets without being overly dependent on any single region or vertical market. Order Intake for the year ended December 31, 2023, included €860 million in KTS, €388 million in RT, €258 million in PHE and €210 million in MCS, driven to a significant extent by strong growth in KTS. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, Order Intake was led by High Tech, followed by Conventional and with Green Tech and Service broadly equal. Americas and EMEA dominated the regions and APAC has been steadily growing. 4 ----- The increase in Order Intake has been driven primarily by high demand for data center applications (particularly in the United States due to hyperscalers) and HVAC applications (driven by catch-up in China). The growth has also been attributable to large projects, including a carbon capture project in North America (approximately U.S. $118 million in contract value) and an Oil & Gas project in Brazil (approximately U.S. $62 million in contract value).

Subsubsection Title: Consistent and sustained progress in implementation of operational excellence plan will further enhance profitability development
Subsubsection Text: We have a strong track record of successfully implementing operational excellence measures across our businesses to enhance profitability. These include initiatives to drive revenue growth, such as pricing adjustments and production capacity realignments to increase and optimize production capacity to grow with our customers. To strengthen our position, we are also refocusing our innovation pipeline to consistently introduce new products on a global scale. They also include measures focused on our cost position, such as numerous supply chain initiatives across our supply chain on a global scale (with 74 identified measures completed within 2024), production capacity utilization measures (including production re-organization) and evaluating product mix to identify and focus on most profitable products and customer demand. In addition, beginning in 2022, we initiated a range of actions and measures to systematically improve our cash position by focusing on working capital. These included, among others, regular forecasting and active monitoring of cash management and cash conversion cycles, enhancements of enterprise resource planning systems to better track inventory levels and reduce slow-moving materials as well as actively managing receivables through initiating standard customer debt collection policies. As a result, we reduced trade working capital w/o retention from 12.1% of revenue for the year ended December 31, 2021 to 1.1% of revenue for the year ended December 31, 2023. Over the same period, we managed to increase our Free Cash Flow Conversion rate from 57.8% for the year ended December 31, 2021 to 61.5% for the year ended December 31, 2023. Over the last three years, we have set several measures to improve our operational efficiency (e.g. quality cost improvements from inward quality review and improvements in internal processes) and commercial efficiency. Our commercial efficiency focuses on the core areas (i) target selling (e.g. focus on vertical markets), (ii) process simplification (e.g. sales order review) and (iii) digitalization. The chart below illustrates the impact of the above mentioned measures on our Normalized EBITDA between the year ended December 31, 2021 and the twelve months ended March 31, 2024: nEBITDA = Normalized EBITDA (1) D&A is part of gross profit; it has been added back to calculate nEBITDA. 5 -----

Subsubsection Title: Proven leadership team with track record of transformation, growth, and value creation
Subsubsection Text: We benefit from an experienced management team led by Andy Blandford, our Chief Executive Officer, and Mark Bevan, our Chief Financial Officer, each of whom joined the Group in 2022 and have more than 30 years of experience in various management and executive management positions at leading global companies. Our leadership team includes Harald Gössl, EVP Technology, and Steffen Thierfelder, EVP Sales & Services, each of whom also has more than 20 years of experience. They are supported by leadership team with extensive industry experience and operational know-how, including regional managers responsible for developing their respective markets. We believe that the collective industry experience and operational know-how of our leadership team, combined with their extensive management experience, provide us with a competitive advantage and are instrumental for the implementation of our strategy and achievement of our long-term objective of delivering sustainable growth.
We believe we benefit from the following competitive strengths:

Subsubsection Title: Focus on growth in High Tech and Green Tech markets
Subsubsection Text: We aim to utilize our strong technological capabilities and innovative solutions to capture the growing demand from customers in the High Tech and Green Tech markets, such as, Data Centers, HVAC, Carbon Capture Storage, Renewable Energy and LNG. These vertical markets are characterized by high growth potential, complex requirements, and stringent quality standards, which create attractive opportunities for us as a reliable and flexible partner. We plan to expand our presence in these vertical markets by developing new solutions and applications, enhancing our customer relationships, and pursuing selective acquisitions that complement our portfolio and geographic footprint.

Subsubsection Title: Continue to grow our Service business
Subsubsection Text: We intend to leverage our large installed product and customer base to continue to grow our Service business. For example, we are focused on improving the organizational setup of our Service business across our product groups by establishing dedicated service responsibilities and pooling service skills across product groups in certain regions and increasing transparency. In KTS, we are considering strategic cooperations with specialist service providers to drive our service business coverage and support our strategic objectives to benefit from robust growth in our strategic pillars and vertical markets. This way we can utilize our product and engineering knowledge with a technical service partner who has a strong market foothold that we can leverage.

Subsubsection Title: Increase market share in the Americas and APAC region
Subsubsection Text: We intend to continue to focus on the growth of our global platform and improve our market share in the Americas and APAC regions through investment in production capacity and local dedicated sales teams. For example, we aim to leverage our scale to further penetrate existing markets and strengthen our positions in China, India and the United States, by capitalizing on strong and growing demand in our Data Center business in the Americas as well as in our HVAC and Carbon Capture Storage solutions in Green Tech market applications. In RT and MCS, we intend to increase production capacity and optimize production locations in the United States as well as build up a dedicated sales team for the Transportation market. In the APAC region, we plan to continue to focus on product localization in the region and investing in our sales and distribution networks.

Subsubsection Title: Continue to reduce complexity and focus on digitalization to drive operational excellence
Subsubsection Text: We continue to pursue our strategy of operational excellence by reducing complexity and enhancing digitalization across our functional and business areas. This means focusing on activities like “80/20” where we seek to improve the profitability of our product range, optimizing SAP in key locations, reducing process complexity through digital tools such as Tagetik (our financial consolidation tool) and SAP (our core ERP). We also continue to deploy tools such as Power BI to help us, for example, manage inventory reduction and improve our supply chain management globally. In addition, we are exploring the use of Artificial Intelligence to support our sales and engineering processes, along with implementing SAP CPQ and LO-VC. We continue to focus on the optimization of our operational footprint, especially in EMEA region, and ensure we are manufacturing the right products in the right place for cost optimization and customer requirements. 6 -----

We started our journey to create consistency in performance, profitability and a platform for growth in 2021 with the High Five strategic program. This set out five focus areas to concentrate on to build a better business. These five areas comprise: (1) Grow High Tech, (2) Grow Green Tech, (3) More Service, (4) Grow APAC & Americas and (5) More Digitalization.

Based on preliminary management accounts, we estimate that revenue for the months April and May 2024 amounted to approximately €258.8 million (compared to approximately €217.6 million for April and May 2023) and EBITDA for the months April and May 2024 amounted to approximately €32.1 million (compared to approximately €21.9 million for April and May 2023). The increase in revenue was primarily driven by a strong development in the EMEA, offsetting slightly lower revenue in the Americas and APAC. EBITDA increased at a higher rate than revenue driven by favorable changes in product mix. The result of April and May 2024 includes expenses of €4.1 million for restructuring in Germany (PHE). _The preliminary financial data of the Group as of and for the months of April and May 2024 presented above has been prepared by, and is the responsibility of, management. Our independent auditors have not audited, reviewed, compiled, examined or performed any procedures with respect to the unaudited preliminary financial data shown above, nor have they expressed any opinion or any other form of assurance on such data and assume no responsibility for, and disclaim any association with, the unaudited preliminary financial data. Such information has been derived from management accounts, is preliminary and is subject to our financial closing procedures. While we believe such preliminary financial data to be reasonable, our actual results could vary from and differences could be material. As such, you should not place undue reliance on this information, and this information may not be indicative of our performance in the remainder of the year or any future period. See “Forward-Looking Statements,” “Risk Factors” and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” in this Offering Memorandum for additional information and descriptions of various factors that could affect our future performance._

In April 2024, we decided to reduce production capacity at two of our German production facilities in PHE. The capacity reduction reflects lower demand for heat pumps in Europe and, in particular, in Germany following a recent decrease in energy prices as well as regulatory uncertainty. We expect that the capacity reduction will impact approximately 150 employees and have booked a provision in a mid-single digit million amount to cover expected costs and expenses.

_The following discussion has been prepared by, and is the responsibility of, the management of the Issuer and is solely based on a large number of estimates and projections, including, among others, with respect to economic conditions, realizable sales prices and market growth projections, all of which are inherently uncertain, and operating data used by management. There can be no assurance that these estimates will be realized or that actual results will not be higher or lower than estimated. The following discussion is further based on a number of assumptions, including, among others, no significant deterioration of economic and political conditions in the markets in which the Group operates, no significant disruptions in the supply chain relevant to the business of the Group, no material price increases of raw materials, no unexpected changes in governmental regulations worldwide, no significant slippage in customer purchase order placement, no significant further softening in European heat pump market, continued growth in our Americas and APAC regions and consistency of foreign exchange rates._ Based on our budget for 2024, we estimate an increase in order intake to approximately €1,750 million and an increase in revenue to approximately €1,600 million. We estimate Normalized EBITDA for 2024 to significantly exceed the prior year. Our budgeted revenue increase is broad-based, with all segments contributing, and is based on the high order backlog, and expected order intake. We anticipate strongest revenue growth in KTS, followed by RT, both driven by strong Data Centre grow, and we estimate moderate growth in MCS and PHE.

The Issuer estimates that the gross proceeds from the Offering will be €425.0 million. The Issuer intends to use the gross proceeds from the Offering (i) to redeem the Existing Notes in full, (ii) for general corporate purposes, including expenses expected to be incurred in connection with a production footprint alignment program in the EMEA region as well as certain capital expenditures and (iii) to pay costs, fees and expenses related to the Transactions (as defined below). In addition, Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l. will repay all amounts outstanding under and subsequently cancel the Existing L/G Facility Agreement and the Existing RCF Facility Agreement and enter into the Super Senior Facilities Agreement on or about the Issue Date. The Offering, the use of proceeds therefrom, the repayment of all amounts outstanding under and subsequent cancellation of the Existing L/G Facility Agreement and the Existing RCF Facility Agreement and the entry into the Super Senior Facilities Agreement are collectively referred to herein as the “Transactions.” 7 ----- The following table which illustrates the estimated sources and uses of funds of gross proceeds from the Offering by the Issuer. The actual amounts set forth in the table and in the accompanying footnotes are subject to adjustment and may differ from our estimate of costs, fees and expenses. See also “Use of Proceeds.”

Notes offered hereby[(1)] ............ 425.0 Repayment of the Existing Notes[(2)] 371.8 General corporate purposes, including EMEA footprint alignment and capital expenditures[(3)] ................................. 36.7 Costs, fees and expenses[(4)] .............. 16.5

(1) Reflects the expected gross proceeds from the issuance of the Notes offered hereby, assuming an issuance at par. (2) Includes capitalized interest of €15.6 million under the Existing Notes, which will be repaid in full with the proceeds from the Offering. Does not include accrued and unpaid interest thereon until the redemption date. (3) The Issuer will use a portion of the gross proceeds for general corporate purposes, including to fund expected costs (including redundancy payments and closure costs) in connection with a planned production footprint alignment program in the EMEA region that is expected to be implemented in 2024 and 2025 as well as certain capital expenditures (such as equipment for the automation of processes and investments into a new enterprise resource planning software). While no definitive decision has been taken as of the date of this Offering Memorandum, we currently estimate that the closure costs (including costs relating to the termination of leases and relocation costs) as well as redundancy costs will amount to approximately €25 million to €30 million and the total costs will amount to approximately €52 million. Any remaining balance which is not covered by the proceeds from the Offering will be funded from cash on hand. See also “Risk Factors—Risks Related to our Business and Industry—We may be unable to _successfully implement ongoing and future improvement programs and may incur additional costs in connection with such programs.”_ (4) Represents estimated fees and expenses associated with the Transactions, which includes estimated underwriting fees, commitment fees, commissions, legal and other professional fees and other transaction costs and expenses related to the Transactions. These fees and expenses have been estimated as of the date of this Offering Memorandum and actual amounts may differ.

Founded in 1997 and owned by its partners, Triton is a leading European mid-market sector-specialist investor. Triton focuses on investing in businesses that provide mission critical goods and services in its three core sectors of Business Services, Industrial Tech, and Healthcare. Triton has over 200 investment professionals across eleven offices and invests through three complementary “All Weather” strategies: Mid-Market Private Equity, Smaller Mid-Cap Private Equity, and Opportunistic Credit. 8 -----

Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l. and Kelvion Holding GmbH will be the initial borrowers under the Super Senior Facilities Agreement. The Super Senior Facilities will be guaranteed on a senior basis by the same Guarantors and will be secured on a first-priority basis over the same Collateral securing the Notes and certain hedging obligations and cash management obligations, if any. (collectively, the “Post-Issue Date **Guarantors” and, together with the Initial Guarantors, the “Guarantors”). The Guarantors will also guarantee the obligations under the Super Senior Facilities Agreement on a pari passu basis. See “Description of the Notes— _Guarantees.” As of and for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, the external revenue, aggregated EBITDA and aggregated total assets, each_ calculated on an unconsolidated basis and excluding intra-group profits of the Issuer and the Guarantors together represented 73.2%, 95.5% and 66.8% of the external revenue, aggregated EBITDA and total assets, respectively, of the Group. The Guarantees will be subject to certain significant contractual and legal limitations or subject to certain defenses under applicable law. See “Certain Insolvency Law Considerations and Limitations _on the Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and Security Interests” and “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes, the Guarantees and the Collateral—Corporate benefit, financial assistance laws, capital maintenance requirements and other limitations on the Guarantees and the_ Collateral may adversely affect the validity and enforceability of the Guarantees and the Collateral.”_ The Guarantees may also be released without consent of the holders of the Notes under certain circumstances. In 2022, KTS was carved-out to a separate subgroup of legal entities to facilitate a potential sale of this segment. In connection with the legal separation of KTS, a new management incentive program was implemented through TESCO Management SCA. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, TESCO Management SCA holds 10% of the share capital in TES LuxCO S.à r.l. and certain members of senior management of KTS, in turn, hold approximately 78% of the shares in TESCO Management SCA, with the remaining approximately 22% being held by Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l. See “Management—Management Incentive Plans.” (7) Kelvion Mashimpeks LLC is incorporated as a limited liability company under the laws of the Russian Federation. Following the outbreak of the Russia-Ukraine Conflict, Kelvion Mashimpeks LLC was ringfenced and a disposal process is currently being pursued. Kelvion Mashimpeks LLC and its subsidiaries will therefore be designated “Unrestricted Subsidiaries” under the Indenture. In addition, Enexio Poland Sp. z o.o. as well as its subsidiaries will also be designated as “Unrestricted Subsidiaries” under the Indenture and, consequently, these Unrestricted subsidiaries will not be subject to the restrictive covenants in the Indenture. As of and for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, the aggregated revenue, aggregated EBITDA and aggregated total assets, each calculated on an unconsolidated basis and excluding intra-group profits, of Kelvion Mashimpeks LLC and its subsidiaries together represented 1.1%, 1.6% and 1.2% of our consolidated revenue, EBITDA and total assets, respectively. While no separate financial information for Enexio Poland Sp. z o.o. is available for the year ended December 31, 2023, we believe that the company is non-operating and does not have any significant revenue. 10 -----

Subsubsection Text: _The following diagram depicts, in simplified form, our corporate and financing structure adjusted to give effect to the Transactions as set forth under “Summary—The Transactions” and “Use of Proceeds.” The diagram does not include all Group entities or their respective indebtedness. Subsection Title: Ranking of the Notes .................... The Notes will:
Subsubsection Text: - be general senior obligations of the Issuer; - rank senior in right of payment to any existing and future indebtedness of the Issuer that is subordinated in right of payment to the Notes; - be secured as set forth under “—Collateral” on a first-ranking basis along with the obligations under the Super Senior Facilities Agreement; however, holders of the Notes will receive proceeds from the enforcement of the Collateral and certain distressed disposals only after any obligations secured on a super senior basis, including obligations under the Super Senior Facilities and certain hedging obligations and cash management obligations, have been repaid in full; - be pari passu with all existing and future obligations of the Issuer that are not subordinated in right of payment to the Notes, including obligations under the Super Senior Facilities Agreement; - be effectively senior to any existing and future indebtedness of the Issuer that is unsecured or secured by liens junior to the liens securing the Notes, to the extent of the value of such Collateral; - be effectively subordinated to any existing and future secured indebtedness of the Issuer that is secured by property or assets that do not secure the Notes, to the extent of the value of such property and assets securing such indebtedness; and - be structurally subordinated to any existing and future indebtedness of subsidiaries of the Issuer that are not Guarantors. 11 -----

Subsection Title: Use of Proceeds ............................. The gross proceeds from the Offering will be used (i) to redeem the Existing Notes
Subsubsection Text: in full, (ii) for general corporate purposes, including certain capital expenditures as well as expenses expected to be incurred in connection with a production footprint alignment program in the EMEA region and (iii) to pay costs, fees and expenses related to the Transactions as set forth in “Use of Proceeds.” Optional Redemption ...................** The Issuer may redeem all or part of the Notes at any time on or after   , 2025 at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any. At any time prior to   , 2025, the Issuer may redeem on any one or more occasions all or part of the Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any, plus the Applicable Premium, as described under “Description of _the Notes—Optional Redemption.”_ See “Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption.”

Any payments made by or on behalf of the Issuer or any Guarantor under or with respect to the Notes or the Guarantees will be made without withholding or deduction for or on account of any taxes in any relevant taxing jurisdiction unless required by law. Subject to certain exceptions and limitations, if the Issuer or the applicable Guarantor or paying agent is required by law to withhold or deduct such taxes with respect to a payment on any Note or Guarantee, the Issuer or the applicable Guarantor will pay the Additional Amounts necessary so that the net amount received after such withholding or deduction is not less than the amount that would have been received in the absence of the withholding or deduction. See “Description of the Notes—Withholding Taxes.” If certain changes in the law of any relevant taxing jurisdiction become effective after the issuance of the Notes that would impose withholding taxes on the payments on the Notes and would require the Issuer or any Guarantor to pay Additional Amounts (as described in “Description of the Notes—Withholding _Taxes”), the Issuer may redeem the Notes in whole, but not in part, at any time, at_ a redemption price of 100% of the principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, and Additional Amounts, if any, to the date of redemption. See “Description of the Notes—Redemption for Taxation Reasons.”

Subsection Title: Tender Offers................................ In connection with certain tender offers for the Notes, if holders of not less than
Subsubsection Text: 90% in aggregate principal amount of the applicable outstanding Notes validly tender and do not withdraw such Notes in such tender offer and the Issuer, or any third party making such a tender offer in lieu of the Issuer, purchases, all of the Notes validly tendered and not withdrawn by such holders, the Issuer or such third party will have the right to redeem the Notes that remain outstanding in whole, but not in part, following such purchase at a price equal to the price offered to each other holder of Notes. See “Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption.”

Subsection Title: Change of Control ........................ If the Issuer experiences a Change of Control, the holders of the Notes will have
Subsubsection Text: the right to require the Issuer to offer to repurchase the Notes at a purchase price equal to 101% of their principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any, to the date of repurchase. See “Description of the _Notes—Change of Control.”_ 14 ----- Original Issue Discount ................** The Notes may be issued with original issue discount (“OID”) for US federal income tax purposes. In such event, holders subject to US federal income tax will generally be required to include such OID in gross income (as ordinary income) as it accrues (on a constant yield to maturity basis) for US federal income tax purposes in advance of the receipt of cash payments to which such OID is attributable and regardless of the holder’s regular method of accounting for US federal income tax purposes. See “Taxation—Certain US Federal Income Tax Considerations— _Original Issue Discount.”_

Subsection Title: Certain Covenants ........................ The Indenture will limit, among other things, the ability of the Issuer and its
Subsubsection Text: restricted subsidiaries to: - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness or issue certain preferred stock; - pay dividends, redeem capital stock and make other distributions; - make certain other restricted payments or restricted investments; - prepay or redeem subordinated debt or equity; - create or permit to exist certain liens; - impose restrictions on the ability of the restricted subsidiaries to pay dividends; - transfer or sell certain assets; - merge or consolidate with other entities; - engage in certain transactions with affiliates; and - impair the security interests for the benefit of the holders of the Notes. Certain of the covenants will be suspended if and for as long as we achieve investment grade ratings. See “Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants— _Suspension of Covenants on Achievement of Investment Grade Status.” Each of the_ covenants in the Indenture will be subject to significant exceptions and qualifications. See “Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants.”

Subsection Title: Transfer Restrictions ................... The Notes and the Guarantees have not been, and will not be, registered under
Subsubsection Text: US federal or state or any foreign securities laws and are subject to restrictions on transferability and resale. See “Transfer Restrictions.” The Issuer is under no obligation to, nor does it intend to, register the Notes or the Guarantees in the United States.

Subsection Title: Absence of a Public Market for the Notes ....................................
Subsubsection Text: The Notes will be new securities for which there is no established trading market. Although the Initial Purchasers have advised the Issuer that they intend to make a market in the Notes, they are not obligated to do so and they may discontinue market-making at any time without notice. Accordingly, the Issuer cannot assure you as to the development or liquidity of any market for the Notes. Furthermore, the Notes will not have registration rights under the US Securities Act.

Subsubsection Text: the information in this Offering Memorandum and, in particular, you should evaluate the specific risk factors set forth in the “Risk Factors” section before making a decision whether to invest in the Notes.

- Audited. (a) Related to the closure of production facilities in Wingles, France, in December 2023. The adjustment mainly includes expenses of €8.4 million for severance, €1.5 million in consulting and legal costs in 2023. In December 2022, we recorded an inventory allowance of €3.1 million. (b) In the first quarter of 2022, KTS was carved out to a separate subgroup of legal entities in connection with a potential sale of KTS’ business. The adjustment relates to corresponding consulting, legal and stamp-duty costs (€5.4 million in 2021 and €3.2 million in 2022). As part of this strategic realignment, inventories and certain assets were impaired (€0.2 million in each of 2021 and 2022) and the decision was made to close the production for MCS and KTS in Pune, India, which led to severance costs. The adjustment also includes €0.2 million of personnel expenses in 2022 related to the transition period from the former CEO and current CEO. (c) Relates to severance payments for redundancies in our sales team in connection with key customer prioritization initiatives and the digitalization of order processing. (d) Relate to various measures and initiatives agreed in connection with the Group’s refinancing in 2019, including reorganization and downsizing of KTS in Spain, the exit of MCS production in India and capacity adjustments for KTS in France. (e) Relate to initiatives in MCS, RT and PHE in the United States, including changes to the product portfolio in MCS, a shift in product focus to dry coolers for data center and HVAC applications in RT as well as the relocation of PHE business operations to Knoxville, Tennessee. In 2022, the adjustment mainly relates to inventory write-offs (€7.4 million). (f) Relates primarily to the sale of the Dry Cooling Systems (DCS) business. DCS Heller was sold in December 2020, followed by the sale of the cooling tower service business in October 2021 and the sale of certain assets of the air-cooled condenser business (DCS-ACC) in March 2022. The remaining DCS-ACC business was wound down. In 2021, the adjustment relates to other operating income from the reversal of provisions related to the winding down of the DCS-ACC business (€17.7 million). In 2022, the adjustment includes €0.4 million for severance payments and €0.2 million for consulting costs related to the winding down of the DCS-ACC business. In January 2022, we divested the ENEXIO Water Business, and the associated consulting expenses and impairment of assets held for sale due to the lower than anticipated selling price (€1.6 million) were normalized in 2021. In 2022, the adjustment also includes a warranty provision of €1.4 million for a potential claim in Germany. (g) The adjustment comprises severance payments, impairment of inventories, consulting expenses and provision releases in relation to initiatives across various product groups and sales entities. (h) Relates to the litigation proceedings with former bondholders of the Galapagos group. Legal costs amounted to €11.5 million in 2023, of which €3.6 million had already accrued prior to 2021. Two settlement payments, in each case in the amount of €2.5 million, were made in December 2023 and in March 2024. (i) Relates to legal and notary fees of €2.0 million in connection with the Group’s refinancing in 2019, with the adjustment made in 2021 as well as consulting expenses related to the extension of the revolving credit facility and associated consulting services in November 2023 and January 2024. (j) Relates the sale of the building and land in France, which resulted in a gain of €1.5 million in 2021 and €4.8 million in 2023 (with a purchase price of €8.0 million). The purchase receivable was factored and a corresponding liability was recognized. In 2021, the adjustment includes the effect from the sale of non-current assets in Sarstedt, Germany (€0.1 million). (k) Relates to a GEA legacy project from 2008. ENEXIO contracted a construction of a dry cooling solution for a power station in Lephalale, South Africa. As part of the purchase price allocation, we recognized a provision of €49.3 million for the estimated risks associated with the project as well as a corresponding receivable from a reimbursement right (70% of the respective provision, €35.5 million). Following the decision of a final court in 2021, the remaining provision of €18.3 million was released. 20 ----- (l) Relates to consulting expenses, impairment of current assets and one-off costs to mitigate the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, ramp-up costs with respect to the outsourcing of coating services and training as well as out of period income/expenses. (m) Mainly relates to impairment charges related to the closure of production facilities in Wingles, France, in December 2023. (4) Free Cash Flow is calculated as Normalized EBITDA less Capital Expenditures.

(5) Free Cash Flow Conversion is calculated as Free Cash Flow divided by Normalized EBITDA. (6) Capital expenditures is shown as payments to acquire property, plant and equipment and intangible assets in our consolidated statement of cash flows. (7) Trade working capital w/o retention is calculated as inventories plus trade receivables and contract assets less accounts payables and advanced payments & contract liabilities. The internal “trade working capital” includes also factoring and customer retention as these derive from operational business even if retentions are part of financial receivables in accordance with IFRS. Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We are exposed to risks associated with changes in global economic conditions and economic developments in the countries in which we operate
Subsubsection Text: As a global manufacturer of heat exchangers and other cooling & heating products, we are exposed to risks associated with fluctuations in the global economy. A slowdown in the global economy and elevated levels of private and public debt in various countries may cause demand to decline in our key markets. The situation may be exacerbated by protectionist tendencies, persistently elevated levels of inflation, uncertainties regarding future monetary policy, armed conflicts that remain unresolved and related migration trends, as well as the spread of infectious diseases. Some recent developments which have significantly impacted global macroeconomic conditions include the ongoing military conflicts in the Ukraine (the “Russia-Ukraine Conflict”), the conflict in Gaza and attacks by Houthi rebels on merchant shipping vessels in the southern Red Sea region as well as the COVID-19 pandemic. See also “—The COVID-19 pandemic had an _adverse effect on our revenue and profitability, cash flow and liquidity, growth plans and prospects, and any future pandemic or other public health incidents could also have similar effects” and “—The Russia-Ukraine Conflict and the sanctions imposed by numerous countries and multinational entities in response, as well as countermeasures by Russia, have had, and may continue to have, adverse impacts on the global economy, the global capital markets, supply chains, energy prices and supplies, any of which could negatively impact our operations.”_ The Russia-Ukraine Conflict and the sanctions and export control measures instituted by the European Union (the “EU”), the United Kingdom, the United States, Canada and Japan, among others, contributed to increased inflationary pressures (including increased prices for oil and natural gas), gas supply shortages, supply chain disruptions, market volatility and economic uncertainty, particularly in Europe. The inflationary environment and related intensified general price increases (in particular due to rising energy costs), combined with an increase in interest rates, resulted in a slowdown of customer demand and thus would have had an impact on our growth. While we may increase product prices in order to mitigate the impact of inflation and increases in energy costs, competitive pressures may constrain our ability to do so and we may remain subject to market risks with respect to inflationary pressures. Furthermore, increasing inflation has put upward pressure on the cost of raw materials (see “—Increases in raw material prices, energy costs and prices for input _materials and intermediate products may result in higher manufacturing or purchasing costs and lower margins, and we may not be able to pass such increased costs on to our customers fully or at all”) and other operating costs, and our ability_ to raise prices to counteract increased raw materials prices and other operating costs (such as labor costs) may be limited, which may reduce our operating profit to the extent where we are not able to pass on related price increases to our customers. In addition, our initiatives, in particular the enforcement of price adjustment clauses in our customer contracts, to mitigate headwinds from inflation in our raw materials and other operating costs may not be sufficient to offset these risks. As part of the capital goods industry, we are also exposed to fluctuations in the overall investment climate. Among other things, fluctuations in growth rates or forecasts of gross domestic product, interest rate environments and alterations in government investment subsidies, can result in significant changes in demand for capital goods in the markets in which we operate, potential cancellations of orders already booked or the reorganization of longer-term business relationships. Therefore, our revenue and results of operations are influenced, and will continue to be influenced, by macroeconomic trends and the general state and performance of the global economy. Moreover, uncertainty in connection with trade tensions between the United States and China and further changes to the trade policy of the United States may have a material adverse effect on the overall economies of EU countries and other markets in which we operate, including APAC and MEA. The uncertain political development in the United States and potential restrictions and limitations impacting international trade may have a negative impact on the export economy in general, and on our results of operations in particular. If individual countries take increasingly protectionist measures to improve their competitiveness in the global 23 ----- market and other countries introduce countermeasures, this may result in market access barriers, such as higher import duties or more complicated certification processes in order to reduce imports. Any of the aforementioned factors could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations and ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: The COVID-19 pandemic had an adverse effect on our revenue and profitability, cash flow and liquidity, growth plans and prospects, and any future pandemic or other public health incidents could also have similar effects.
Subsubsection Text: The COVID-19 pandemic created significant macroeconomic uncertainty, volatility and disruption and had serious adverse economic consequences, including declining economic growth, numerous business insolvencies and significantly increased unemployment. As a result of the COVID-19 pandemic and measures imposed to contain the outbreak of the disease, particularly in Europe and the United States, our business operations experienced delays and disruptions, including, but not limited to, supply chain interruptions and delays in delivery of products or projects to some of our customers. Potential impacts of any further outbreaks of disease or other public health threats in the future include but are not limited to: (i) staffing shortages if portions of our workforce are unable to work effectively due to illness, quarantines, government actions, facility closures, or other restrictions; (ii) short- or long-term disruptions in our supply chain and our ability to deliver products to our customers; (iii) deterioration in the markets that we or our customers operate in, which may result in lower sales or a lack in the ability of our customers to pay us; and (iv) significant volatility or negative pressure in the financial markets, which could adversely affect our access to capital and/or financing. Any adverse effect on our ability to access capital and/or secure financing could also have the effect of heightening many of the other risks described in this “Risk Factors” section and have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations and ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: The Russia-Ukraine Conflict and the sanctions imposed by numerous countries and multinational entities in response, as well as countermeasures by Russia, have had, and may continue to have, adverse impacts on the global economy, the global capital markets, supply chains, energy prices and supplies, any of which could negatively impact our operations.
Subsubsection Text: The Russia-Ukraine Conflict prompted the EU and numerous countries to impose sanctions on a range of Russian and Belarusian state and corporate entities and individuals, including extensive trade embargoes, travel bans, asset freezes and the exclusion of certain Russian and Belarusian banks from the global financial system, among other measures. In response, Russia has sanctioned persons and entities within so-called “non-friendly” countries and terminated gas supply contracts with several countries and entities in Europe. The unpredictable nature of the conflict means that further sanctions, against Russia and Belarus (or Russian and Belarusian entities) and further retaliatory actions by Russia and Belarus against the imposing countries, including the possible expropriation of assets owned by nationals of, or companies based in, such sanctioning countries, including us, may be forthcoming. While we have a subsidiary in Russia, sales in the region were ceased in January 2023 and the Russian subsidiary’s operations were ringfenced for disposal in May 2023. A disposal process is currently being pursued. However, there can be no assurance if and at which terms such disposal may be completed. Under Russian law, among other things, any disposal is required to be made at a discount compared to a valuation prepared by an approved valuer and subject to government approval. For the time being, the Russian entity operates under its own brand name and has established its own supply chain. In addition, in October 2022, we ceased all trading with Belarus. In the year ended December 31, 2023, Kelvion Mashimpeks LLC (our Russian subsidiary) accounted for 1.1% (€16.0 million) of our total revenue. However, our business, financial condition and results of operations have been and could continue to be materially adversely affected by the Russia-Ukraine Conflict in a number of ways. The Russia-Ukraine Conflict and the related sanctions have created significant global economic uncertainty and have threatened to exacerbate pre-existing global economic challenges such as those arising from the COVID-19 pandemic and its consequences, increasing inflation (including energy prices) and slowing economic growth. The conflict and the related sanctions have also caused and may continue to cause volatility in oil and natural gas prices and could potentially lead to shortages or further energy price increases of these resources. These developments have caused and may continue to cause significant increases in energy prices which, in turn, impact our input costs. In addition, the conflict has provoked a significant return home of Ukraine labour employed in different European countries, creating labour availability tension in some industries, notably manufacturing and transportation. If any of the foregoing risks were to materialize, our business, financial condition, results of operations and ability to fulfil our obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees could be materially and adversely affected. Such risks may also have the effect of heightening other risks, such as those relating to inflation, capital markets volatility and our ability to access additional capital, any of which could materially and adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations. We, our suppliers or our customers may be unable to obtain or maintain sufficient financing, including working capital financing, and credit insurance. 24 ----- Our working capital requirements can vary, depending in part on the level, variability and timing of our customers’ production, and the payment terms with its customers and suppliers. Our liquidity could also be adversely impacted if our suppliers were to suspend normal trade credit terms and require payment in advance or on delivery. If our available cash flows from operating activities are not sufficient to fund our ongoing cash needs, we would be required to look to our cash balances and availability for borrowings to satisfy those needs, as well as potential additional sources of capital, which may not be available on satisfactory terms, in sufficient amount or at all. There can be no assurance that we, our suppliers or our customers will continue to have such ability. This may increase the risk that we cannot produce our products or will have to pay higher prices for our inputs. These higher prices may not be recovered in our selling prices.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Certain industries and end-markets we serve are cyclical and our results may be adversely impacted by such cycles and negative developments.
Subsubsection Text: We serve a variety of end-markets, including, Data Centers, HVAC, Power & Energy, Oil & Gas, and Heavy & Light Industry. Demand for our products and services is dependent on the levels of investment in these end-markets and industries, which, in turn, is affected by a number of macroeconomic factors, such as economic growth and GDP, levels of capital investments, inflation and interest rates as well as the availability of credit and financing. These industries and end-markets are also characterized by different trends and market drivers. A negative development in any of our primary end-markets, particularly in Data Centers, could have a negative impact on our business, financial position and results of operations. Any of the aforementioned factors could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations and ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Changes in government spending and legislative actions and initiatives relating to renewable energy and electric power may adversely affect demand for our products and services.
Subsubsection Text: Demand for our products and services may be negatively impacted by changes in government spending and renewable energy policies and initiatives. Many countries in which we operate have, or are considering, mandates that require specified percentages of power to be generated from renewable sources. In addition, some countries are considering limits on both the development of new nuclear power plants and on the continued operation of existing nuclear power plants following environmental incidents. Subsidies of renewable energy sources could result in reduced investment in conventional power plants, which tend to be more heat exchanger-intensive than many of the renewable energy technologies currently deployed. Furthermore, the continuing political discussion relating to the future energy mix (among other jurisdictions, in Germany) could lead to delayed investment decisions or to reduced investments by our customers, in particular in the oil and gas and energy sectors, which could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations. For example, in the year ended December 31, 2023, 11.6% of our revenue resulted from sales to customers in the Power & Energy and, therefore, policy changes in connection with transitions to renewable energy sources could have an adverse impact on our revenue and results of operations. In addition, demand for products in PHE is affected by demand for heat pumps and has been negatively impacted by regulatory uncertainty in relation to the phase out of conventional heating systems since the end of 2023. Any further changes in government spending and renewable energy policies and initiatives could have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees if they result in reduced demand for our products and services in traditional coal, nuclear and gas-fired power plants.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We may be unable to successfully implement ongoing and future improvement programs and may incur additional costs in connection with such programs.
Subsubsection Text: We have in the past implemented, and intend to continue to implement, improvement programs aimed at aligning our production capacities with the demand in the relevant end-markets by closing certain manufacturing sites and transferring the manufacturing to other sites. For example, we stopped production at our site in Wingles, France, which had been loss-making for a number of years, in 2023, as the market of heat pumps, which experienced a boom as a result of the energy crisis at the beginning of 2022, has experienced decline. In connection with the closure of the production in Wingles, France, we agreed a redundancy plan and incurred other closure costs in an aggregate amount of €14.0 million in the years ended December 31, 2022 and December 31, 2023. We are also evaluating certain other footprint alignment programs in the EMEA region, e.g. in Western Europe, which could result in the closure of additional sites and redundancy plans. In particular, we are in the final stage of assessing a footprint reduction for one site in Western Europe and expect to conclude this assessment in the near future. While no definitive decision has been taken as of the date of this Offering Memorandum, we currently estimate that the closure costs (including costs relating to the termination of leases and relocation costs) as well as redundancy costs will amount to approximately €25 million to €30 million and the total costs will amount to approximately €52 million, which will be – directly or indirectly – funded from the proceeds of the offering of the Notes. See “Use of Proceeds.” However, our actual costs may be significantly higher due to a number of factors, some of which are beyond our control. In addition, there can be no assurance that we will be able to implement the planned restructuring measures on time, for example due to the need to find an agreement with employee representatives or landlords. 25 ----- In addition, even if we are able to implement our footprint alignment program as planned, there can be no assurance that such measures result in the efficiency gains or cost savings currently anticipated by us. We may, for example, experience delays in ramping up production at our new sites or such sites may not be as efficient as anticipated due to factors such as availability and skills of the local workforce and the need to use new suppliers. Furthermore, a reduction of our labor force at the affected sites could adversely affect our business, e.g., through strikes, lawsuits, business interruptions or reputational damage. The materialization of any of the risks described above could have a material and adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations, which could in turn adversely affect our ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We face country risks in the regions in which we operate, including in emerging markets.
Subsubsection Text: We are active in numerous countries worldwide. We have a global production footprint, with production sites in more than 20 countries around the world, including Germany, the United States, the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, France, Spain, Poland, the Czech Republic, Qatar, South Africa, India and China, as well as service and engineering hubs in additional jurisdictions. Our operations in any of the countries in which we operate, and particularly in emerging markets, are subject to the following risks: - changes in the rate of economic growth; - unsettled political or economic conditions; - expropriation or other governmental actions; - war and social unrest; - terrorist attacks or other armed conflicts; - bribery and corruption; - national and regional labor strikes; - confiscatory taxation or other adverse tax policies, - deprivation of contract rights; - trade regulations affecting production, pricing and marketing of products; - reduced protection of intellectual property rights; - restrictions on the repatriation of income or capital; - exchange controls; - inflation; - currency fluctuations and devaluation; - the effect of global environmental, health and safety issues on economic conditions; - market opportunities and operating restrictions; and - changes in financial policy and availability of credit. Moreover, financial and political turmoil in an emerging market may adversely affect the economic conditions of other emerging markets or countries in the region, as investors may move their money to more stable, developed markets. The uncertainty over whether governments will implement changes in policies or regulations affecting these or other factors in the future may contribute to economic uncertainty in such markets. Furthermore, the performance of emerging market economies has historically been affected by the political climate in these countries. Political crises have had a negative impact on the confidence of investors and the public in general, and they have adversely affected the economic development of these countries. 26 ----- In addition, we may conduct business with customers or service or agency partners in countries that are subject to export control regulations, trade embargoes, economic sanctions or other forms of trade restrictions imposed by the United States, the European Union or other countries or multilateral organizations. It is possible that any expansion into or within sanctioned countries could adversely impact our ability to gain or retain investors, customers or suppliers or result in reputational harm or other adverse consequences. Further, should legal developments require us to modify or terminate our activities in such countries, we may be exposed to customer complaints or contractual remedies or other adverse consequences. Any of the aforementioned factors could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations and ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We generate a significant amount of Order Intake and revenue from a limited number of large customers.
Subsubsection Text: Although our customer base is large, we depend on certain large customers for a significant proportion of our revenue and Order Intake. For example, in the year ended December 31, 2023, our ten largest customers generated approximately 46% of our Order Intake (year ended December 31, 2022: approximately 32%), with the largest customer generating approximately 25% of Order Intake in the year ended December 31, 2023 (year ended December 31, 2022: approximately 20%). Furthermore, our largest customer generated approximately 18% of our revenue in the year ended December 31, 2023. The loss of all or a substantial portion of our business with any of our largest customers, and in particular our largest customer, could have a material adverse impact on our business, financial condition and results of operations. We may make fewer business with these customers for a number of reasons, including but not limited to: - reduced demand for our customers’ products or services, including, in particular, as a result of cyclical downturns that disproportionately affect our customers’ industries; - failure to deliver products or solutions that meet our customers’ specifications and our contractual obligations; - technological changes; - reduced or delayed customer requirements; or - bankruptcy or insolvency of a customer. Any significant change in the revenue or Order Intake we generate from our largest customers could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial position, results of operations and ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We may not be able to realize revenues represented by our Order Intake and Order Backlog.
Subsubsection Text: We present Order Intake and Order Backlog as operational key performance indicators in this Offering Memorandum. Order Intake refers to binding customer contracts and purchase orders concluded and received in the respective reporting period at the respective price, while Order Backlog refers to the binding customer contracts and purchase orders concluded and the portion of the associated transaction price for which the amount of sales has not yet been recognized in accordance with IFRS. See “Summary Financial and Other Information—Order Intake and Order _Backlog”. There can be no assurance that these contractual terms will remain unchanged, or that the order intake or order_ backlog will result in an actual recognition of revenue within the period initially anticipated, if at all. We may experience variances in the realization of estimated Order Intake and Order Backlog because of delays or cancellations, scope adjustments, external market factors and economic factors beyond our control. In addition, many of our contracts grant the customer the right to change, delay or cancel purchase orders at any time after they have been placed against the payment of proven damages suffered by us as a result of such change, delay or cancellation or, in certain cases, against payment of fixed contractual penalties. If the estimated Order Intake or Order Backlog fails to materialize as anticipated, this could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and ability to fulfill our obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees. Our Order Intake and Order Backlog does not provide a precise indication of the time period over which we are contractually entitled to receive such revenue and there is no assurance that such revenues will be actually received within the anticipated timeframes or at all. Our Order Intake and Order Backlog are computed based on facts known and assumptions deemed appropriate at the computation date. Our definition of Order Intake and Order Backlog may not necessarily be the same as that used by other companies engaged in activities similar to us. As a result, the amount of Order Intake and Order Backlog reported by us may not be comparable to similar metrics reported by such other companies. 27 -----

Subsection Title: Risks Related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We are exposed to intense competition and our competitive position may deteriorate.
Subsubsection Text: The market for heat exchangers in which we operate is highly competitive. We compete with both large international market participants and numerous smaller regional and local suppliers that vary depending on the region.
