Subsubsection Title: Three Months Ended March 31, 2024 Compared to Three Months Ended March 31, 2023
Subsubsection Text: _Revenue_ Revenue increased by €52,740 thousand, or 17.6%, from €299,600 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €352,340 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2024. The increase was primarily attributable to an increase in orders for Data Center solutions and machine cooling systems products. Revenue in RT decreased by €8,499 thousand, or 9.6%, from €88,105 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €79,606 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2024, driven mainly by higher revenues from Data Center solutions. Revenue in MCS decreased by €11,037 thousand, or 16.8%, from €65,604 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €54,567 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2024, driven mainly by higher service revenue and exhaust gas recirculation (EGR). Revenue in KTS increased by €32,746 thousand, or 25.7%, from €127,590 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €160,336 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2024. The increase was mainly driven by KTS’ growth in the Data Center vertical market as well as a large project in the oil & gas sector in Brazil. Revenue in PHE decreased by €20,445 thousand, or 25.1%, from €81,310 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €60,865 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2024. PHE’s revenue decline was driven by 70 ----- regulatory changes impacting the heat pump market, leading to a softening in order intake for brazed plate heat exchangers (HX65). _Cost of sales_ Cost of sales increased by €38,240 thousand, or 15.9%, from €240,449 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €278,689 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2024. The increase was primarily attributable to the overall growth of the business and increase in revenue. _Selling expenses_ Selling expenses increased by €1,210 thousand, or 6.2%, from €19,457 thousand in the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €20,667 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2024. The increase was primarily attributable to payroll inflation and headcount shifts. _Research and Development expenses_ Research and development expenses increased by €852 thousand, or 19.8%, from €4,302 thousand in the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €5,154 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2024. The increase was primarily attributable to payroll inflation and headcount shifts. As a percentage of revenue, research and development expenses increased slightly to 1.5%, compared to 1.4% in the three months ended March 31, 2023. _General and administrative expenses_ General and administrative expenses increased by €883 thousand, or 4.4%, from €19,873 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €20,756 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2024. The increase was primarily attributable to payroll inflation. _Other income_ Other income increased by €7,302 thousand from €5,130 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €12,432 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2024. The increase was primarily attributable to exchange rate gains, which increased by €7,357 thousand. _Other expenses_ Other expenses increased by €6,763 thousand, or 99.6%, from €6,792 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €13,555 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2024. The increase was primarily attributable to increased exchange rate losses of €7,135 thousand. _Other financial expenses_ Other financial expenses increased by €3 thousand, from €0 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €3 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2024. The increase was attributable to losses from disposal of loans and receivables. _Interest income_ Interest income increased by €827 thousand, or 207.8%, from €398 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €1,225 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2024. The increase was primarily attributable to positive cash management in relation to balances held. _Interest expenses_ Interest expenses decreased by €3,266 thousand, or 20.8%, from €15,683 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €12,417 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2024. The decrease was primarily attributable to the Existing RCF Facility Agreement being undrawn and lower interest expenses under the Existing L&G Facility Agreement due to a significant reduction in the guarantee lines compared to the period in the prior year. _Income taxes_ Income taxes increased by €2,210 thousand, from €1,455 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2023 to €3,665 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2024. The increase was primarily attributable to the increased expected tax rate in 2024 and the positive business performance. 71 ----- _Profit or loss for the period_ Profit or loss for the period increased by €13,951 thousand, or 487.6%, from a loss of €2,861 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2023 to a profit of €11,090 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2024. The increase was the result of the factors described above.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Year Ended December 31, 2023 Compared to Year Ended December 31, 2022
Subsubsection Text: _Revenue_ Revenue increased by €270,689 thousand, or 25.1%, from €1,077,238 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2022 to €1,347,927 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2023. The increase was primarily attributable to the Data Center business in KTS and RT. In addition, MCS also showed strong growth. Revenue in RT increased by €20,834 thousand, or 7.6%, from €274,540 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2022 to €295,374 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2023, driven mainly by expansion in the business of cooling solutions (HX351 sales more than doubling) for operator of Data Centers. Revenue in MCS increased by €31,622 thousand, or 17.6%, from €179,291 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2022 to €210,913 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2023, driven mainly by the two big vertical markets of MCS, Transportation and Heavy and Light Industry, as well as the Oil & Gas, Chemicals and Power & Energy vertical markets. However, the increase in revenue was also due to higher sales in almost all product groups showing a strong development. Revenue in KTS increased by €178,363 thousand, or 43.1%, from €413,507 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2022 to €591,870 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2023. The increase was mainly driven by KTS’ growth in the Data Center vertical market and our service business benefitting from the installed base revenue growth also improved due to carbon capture solutions for Green Tech customers. Revenue in PHE increased by €27,441 thousand, or 11.3%, from €243,405 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2022 to €270,846 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2023. PHE’s revenue growth was driven by the increasing volume of brazed plate heat exchangers for the booming heat pump industry in the first half of 2023 and gasketed plate heat exchangers along with continued service revenue. _Cost of sales_ Cost of sales increased by €198,782 thousand, or 22.3%, from €892,166 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2022 to €1,090,948 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2023. The increase was primarily attributable to the increase in product volumes. _Selling expenses_ Selling expenses increased by €1,797 thousand, or 2.4%, from €76,007 thousand in the year ended December 31, 2022 to €77,804 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2023. The increase was primarily attributable to inflation. As a percentage of our revenue, selling expenses decreased from 7.1% in 2022 to 5.8% in 2023. The volume increase was drive by large customer data centre orders and OEMs where sales support was optimized. _Research and Development expenses_ Research and Development expenses increased by €2,547 thousand, or 18.2%, from €13,963 thousand in the year ended December 31, 2022 to €16,510 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2023. The increase was primarily attributable to inflation, additional external expenses and an average seven additional R&D engineers. As a percentage of our revenue, Research and Development expenses remained stable at 1.2% in 2023 (2022: 1.3%). _General and Administrative expenses_ General and Administrative expenses increased by €9,280 thousand, or 10.7%, from €86,366 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2022 to €95,646 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2023. The increase is mainly caused by legal consulting expenses of €8.0 million relating to historic litigation cases and covenant reset fees. Excluding the €8.0 million, general and administrative expenses as a percentage of our revenue decreased to 6.5% in 2023 from 8.0% in 2022. _Other income_ Other income decreased by €9,508 thousand, or 33.3%, from €28,571 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2022 to €19,063 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2023. The decrease was primarily attributable to lower 72 ----- exchange rate gains and miscellaneous other income, which was only partially offset by higher income from the disposal of non-current assets. _Other expenses_ Other expenses decreased by €9,766 thousand, or 32.7%, from €29,831 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2022 to €20,065 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2023. The decrease was primarily attributable to lower foreign currency exchange losses, which decreased by €7,719 thousand. _Interest income_ Interest income increased by €1,752 thousand from €396 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2022 to €2,148 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2023. The increase was driven by interest income from third parties earned from demand deposit accounts in the amount of €1,540 thousand compared to €146 thousand in the prior year. _Interest expenses_ Interest expenses increased by €2,812 thousand, or 5.0%, from €56,072 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2022 to €58,884 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2023. Interest expenses mainly consisted of interest expenses (including the release of capitalized financing cost) relating to the Existing Notes amounting to €32,404 thousand (2022: €33,183 thousand), interest on the TPECs of €11,351 thousand (2022: €11,351 thousand), interest expenses on liabilities to banks amounting to €4,320 thousand (2022: €5,837 thousand), mainly resulting from guarantee commissions of €3,568 thousand (2022: €5,052 thousand), and interest on the Existing L/G Facility Agreement amounting to €2,976 thousand (2022: €2,254 thousand). _Income taxes_ Income taxes changed by €20,957 thousand from tax income of €12,567 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2022 to a tax expense of €8,390 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2023. Despite positive earnings before tax (EBT) amounting to €8,682 thousand, our incurred current tax expenses of €26,087 thousand and a net deferred tax income of €17,697 thousand (2022: €23,586 thousand of deferred tax income). Current taxes mainly related to the positive EBT in several of our entities that could not be offset with losses in other jurisdictions. _Profit or loss for the period_ Profit or loss for the period increased by €37,992 thousand from a loss of €37,700 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2022 to a profit of €292 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2023. The increase was the result of the factors described above, including the extraordinary expenses mainly for restructuring and similar expenses.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Year Ended December 31, 2022 Compared to Year Ended December 31, 2021
Subsubsection Text: _Revenue_ Revenue increased by €145,496 thousand, or 15.6%, from €931,742 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €1,077,238 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2022. The increase was primarily attributable to positive growth in the HVAC & Refrigeration end-markets (Data Center business as the main driver) in our two largest regions Western Europe and North America. Revenue in RT increased by €32,082 thousand, or 13.2%, from €242,458 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €274,540 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2022. The increase was primarily driven by considerable volume growth and price increases, offset, in part by an initially weaker start of the year in the Americas and ongoing supply chain challenges. Revenue in MCS increased by €36,426 thousand, or 25.5%, from €142,865 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €179,291 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2022. The increase was primarily due to performance in the power, marine and other industries, which collectively accounted for nearly all of the product group’s revenue and the strength of the product group in Western Europe, Asia Pacific and North America. Revenue in KTS increased by €119,061 thousand, or 40.4%, from €294,446 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €413,507 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2022. The increase was mainly due to improving order intake throughout the second half of 2021 and 2022, mainly driven by KTS’ expanding Data Center business as well as improvement in the Oil & Gas end-markets. In 2021, revenue in KTS included non-recurring revenue of €38.7 million from an arbitration award related to a legacy power project in South Africa. 73 ----- Revenue in PHE increased by €34,861 thousand, or 16.7%, from €208,544 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €243,405 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2022, driven mainly by an increase in volumes of brazed plate heat exchangers for the booming heat pump industry as well as the expanding service business. _Cost of sales_ Cost of sales increased by €143,078 thousand, or 19.1%, from €749,088 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €892,166 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2022, which was in line with the development of sales revenue. _Selling expenses_ Selling expenses decreased by €2,691 thousand, or 3.4%, from €78,698 thousand in the year ended December 31, 2021 to €76,007 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2022. The decrease was primarily attributable to a reduction in the number of sales employees. _Research and development expenses_ Research and development expenses increased by €1,850 thousand, or 15.3%, from €12,113 thousand in the year ended December 31, 2021 to €13,963 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2022. The increase was primarily attributable to an increase in personnel expenses due to a combination of payroll inflation and to an average of 6 additional R&D engineers. _General and administrative expenses_ General and administrative expenses increased by €6,205 thousand, or 7.7%, from €80,161 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €86,366 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2022. The increase was mainly due to the increase in our revenue in 2022 and costs related to the carveout of KTS. _Other income_ Other income decreased by €16,941 thousand, or 37.2%, from €45,512 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €28,571 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2022. The decrease was primarily attributable to the reassessment of provisions relating to the winding down of the ACC business of ENEXIO recognized in 2021. _Other expenses_ Other expenses increased by €3,774 thousand, or 14.5%, from €26,057 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €29,831 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2022. The increase mainly resulted from exchange rate losses of €15,133 thousand (2021: €7,204 thousand) which decreased broadly in line with gains from exchange rate differences. _Interest income_ Interest income decreased by €6,261 thousand from €6,657 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €396 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2022. The decrease was mainly driven by the result of arbitration award of the Medupi project in 2022. _Interest expenses_ Interest expenses decreased by €2,312 thousand, or 4.0%, from €58,384 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €56,072 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2022. Interest expenses amounted to €56,072 thousand in 2022 (2021: €58,384 thousand), mainly consisting of interest expenses (including the release of capitalized financing cost) relating to the Existing Notes amounting to €33,183 thousand (2021: €33,565 thousand), interest on TPECs of €11,351 thousand (2021: €11,351 thousand), interest expenses on liabilities to banks of €5,837 thousand (2021: €6,956 thousand) mainly resulting from guarantee commissions of €5,052 thousand (2021: €6,085 thousand), and interest expenses on the Existing L/G Facility Agreement amounting to €2,254 thousand (2021: €32 thousand). _Income taxes_ Income taxes changed by €31,396 thousand from a tax expense of €18,829 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2021 to tax income of €12,567 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2022. Despite negative earnings before tax (“EBT”), our incurred current tax expenses of €11,019 thousand and a net deferred tax income of €23,586 thousand (2021: total income taxes of €18,829 thousand, thereof current tax expenses €12,561 thousand and net deferred tax expenses of €6,268 thousand). Current taxes mainly relate to the positive EBT in several legal entities that cannot be offset with losses in other jurisdictions. 74 ----- _Profit or loss for the period_ Profit or loss for the period improved by €2,865 thousand, or 7.1%, from a loss of €40,565 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2021 to a loss of €37,700 thousand for the year ended December 31, 2022. The change was the result of the factors described above and despite the challenging market environment in 2022 and excluding the extraordinary expenses mainly related to restructuring and similar expenses.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Overview
Subsubsection Text: Our principal sources of funds have been cash generated from our operating activities. Our principal uses of cash are funding the daily business, working capital and capital expenditures. We expect to meet our requirements for the next twelve months primarily from cash flows from operating activities. In addition, we utilize factoring agreements to support our liquidity needs and manage our working capital. As of March 31, 2024, €27.3 million were utilized under our existing factoring agreements and €85 million were available for utilization. See “Description of Certain Financing _Arrangements—Factoring Arrangements.”_ From time to time, we also enter into bilateral facilities with local lenders to fund working capital and capital expenditure requirements. As of March 31, 2024, we had bilateral facilities in Brazil and, to a minor extent, in France and our liabilities under these bank loans amounted to €5.1 million. Although we believe that our expected cash flows from operating activities will be adequate to meet our anticipated liquidity needs, there can be no assurance that our business will generate sufficient cash flows from operating activities to meet these needs or that future debt financing will be available to us in an amount sufficient to enable us to fund our liquidity needs. See “Risk Factors.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: - Comprises unrestricted and restricted cash and cash equivalents. Restricted cash consists of cash and cash equivalents in the Group’s legal entities in Russia. See Note 4.8 of the 2023 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements.Cash flows from operating activities. Cash flows from operating activities decreased by €23,745 thousand, or 50.7%, from an inflow of €46,844 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2023 to an inflow of €23,099 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2024. The decrease was primarily attributable to lower pre-payments received from customers in the three months ended March 31, 2024 compared to the period in the prior year. Cash flows from operating activities increased by €49,804 thousand from €29,796 thousand in the year ended December 31, 2021 to €79,600 thousand in the year ended December 31, 2022. The increase was primarily attributable to a change in provisions of €51,158 thousand, mainly driven by the settlement of a legacy project for the construction of a dry cooling solution for a power station in South Africa and the release of a provision made in 2021, which more than offset the decrease of €22,873 thousand of EBIT to €7,118 thousand in the year ended December 31, 2022 from €29,991 thousand in the prior year. The increase was attributable to an increase in cash inflow of €3,977 thousand from trade working capital as well as €2,901 thousand lower tax payments. Cash flows from operating activities increased by €138,187 thousand from €79,600 thousand in the year ended December 31, 2022 to €217,787 thousand in the year ended December 31, 2023. The increase was primarily attributable to higher EBIT of €65,418 thousand compared to €7,118 thousand in the prior year as well as an improvement in trade working capital. 75 ----- _Cash flows from investing activities_ Cash flows from investing activities decreased by €2,081 thousand, or 19.9%, from an outflow of €10,465 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2023 to an outflow of €8,384 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2024. The decrease was primarily attributable to phasing of projects spend at comparative times. Cash flows from investing activities increased by €4,859 thousand, or 17.0%, from an outflow of €28,623 thousand in the year ended December 31, 2021 to an outflow of €33,482 thousand in the year ended December 31, 2022. The increase was primarily attributable to the sustained high level of investment activity in 2022. Cash outflows in 2022 related to the acquisition of property, plant and equipment as well as to intangible assets of €34,769 thousand. The proceeds from the disposal of non-current assets and assets held for sale amounted to €1,287 thousand and related to the replacement of non-material equipment. Cash flows from investing activities increased by €12,672 thousand, or 37.8%, from an outflow of €33,482 thousand in the year ended December 31, 2022 to an outflow of €46,154 thousand in the year ended December 31, 2023. Cash outflows in 2023 related to the acquisition of property, plant and equipment as well as to intangible assets of €56,605 thousand. The proceeds from the disposal of non-current assets and assets held for sale amounted to €10,451 thousand, which related primarily to the sale of land and buildings in France which was recorded as an asset held for sale. _Cash flows from financing activities_ Cash flows from financing activities decreased by €2,822 thousand, or 28.1%, from an outflow of €10,044 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2023 to an outflow of €7,222 thousand for the three months ended March 31, 2024. The decrease was primarily attributable to lower utilisation under the Existing RCF Agreement and reduced utilisations under the Existing L/G Facility Agreement. Cash flows from financing activities decreased by €15,858 thousand from an outflow of €22,237 thousand in the year ended December 31, 2021 to an outflow of €6,379 thousand in the year ended December 31, 2022. Cash outflows from financing activities in 2022 primarily consisted of interest payments (€41,734 thousand, 2021: €18,098 thousand), payments from finance lease (€12,706 thousand, 2021: €20,016 thousand), as well as proceeds from the revolving credit facility (€50,000 thousand, 2021: €15,000 thousand). The higher interest payments in 2022 related mainly to the deferral of the payment of interest on the Existing Notes in December 2021 (€14.2 million) and lower interest on the Existing L/G Facility Agreement. Cash flows from financing activities increased by €108,269 thousand from an outflow of €6,379 thousand in the year ended December 31, 2022 to an outflow of €114,648 thousand in the year ended December 31, 2023. Cash outflows from financing activities in 2023 primarily consisted of repayment under the revolving credit facility of €65,000 thousand, and interest payments of €40,522 thousand.

Subsubsection Text: Unaudited 76 ----- _December 31, 2023 compared to December 31, 2022_ As of December 31, 2023, our trade working capital w/o retention amounted to €15.2 million, a decrease of €69.0 million compared to €84.2 million as of December 31, 2022. Trade working capital w/o retention at year end 2023 primarily related to the component business driven PHE (€44.8 million) and MCS (€9.7 million). The decrease was primarily attributable to a reduction in RT mainly due to an increase of advance payments on projects received and a reduction in PHE mainly due to a decrease in trade receivables and in inventories. The increase in inventories was primarily due to the increase (€6.7 million) in KTS. The increase was offset, in part, the other product groups, including PHE, RT and MSC. The lower level of trade working capital w/o retention as of December 31, 2023 was driven by RT and KTS, where high advance payments were collected on major projects and which is reflected in the increase in advanced payments & contract liabilities of €234.7 million at year end 2023 (increase of €89.7 million compared to year end 2022). The increase was primarily driven by the higher activity at the end of 2023 compared to the end of 2022. For the year ending December 31, 2024, we expect trade working capital w/o retention to increase due to growth and expected stage of completion of larger projects. _December 31, 2022 compared to December 31, 2021_ As of December 31, 2022, our trade working capital w/o retention amounted to €84.2 million, a decrease of €28.2 million compared to €112.4 million as of December 31, 2021. Trade working capital w/o retention at year end 2022 primarily related to the component business driven PHE (€74.0 million), RT (€19.5 million) and MCS (€17.8 million), whereas the trade working capital w/o retention of the project business-oriented KTS had negative trade working capital w/o retention (€15.3 million). The decrease was primarily attributable to a reduction in KTS due to high advance payments on projects received and an increase in trade receivables. The increase in inventories (€11.0 million) was primarily attributable to an increase in KTS and was offset, in part, by a decrease in PHE. The decrease in trade working capital w/o retention as of December 31, 2022 was driven by KTS, where high advance payments were collected on major projects mainly in the US, which is also reflected in the higher advance payments of €145.0 million at year end 2022 (increase of €59.3 million compared to the prior year). This increase, together with the higher overall level of accounts payables (increase of €14.1 million), which was mainly driven by the described higher activity at the end of 2022 compared to 2021.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk
Subsubsection Title: Currency Risk
Subsubsection Text: We have significant assets and liabilities outside the Eurozone, particularly in China, USA, South Africa, Brazil, India, Poland, Czech Republic and Great Britain. These assets and liabilities are denominated in local currency. When the net asset values are converted into Euro, the currency fluctuations result in period to period changes in those net asset values. Our equity position reflects these changes in net asset values. We also have transactional currency exposures which arise mostly from sales or purchases in currencies other than the functional currency. In order to mitigate the impact of currency exchange rate fluctuations for the operating business, all companies are required to economically hedge foreign currency items, as they arise in order to fix prices on the basis of hedging rates. Currency risks are economically hedged for recognized assets and liabilities, unrecognized firm commitments, and highly probable forecasted transactions, when denominated in another currency than the functional currency of the company. The hedging periods are determined by the maturity of the economical hedged items and are usually up to twelve months, but may also exceed that period significantly in exceptional cases. Hedge accounting in the sense of IFRS 9 is not applied. All economic hedging transactions – to the extent legally permissible – are handled by our group treasury department. Our companies report their exposures to group treasury, which enters on behalf of the respective companies into corresponding derivative transactions with banks. The economical hedging transactions are closely monitored by group treasury. For additional information, see Note 5.10 of the 2023 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk
Subsubsection Title: Credit Risk
Subsubsection Text: Credit risk refers to the risk that counterparties may default on their contractual obligations resulting in a financial loss to us. In general, we have adopted a policy of only dealing with creditworthy counterparties and obtaining sufficient collateral in the form of advanced payments where appropriate, as a means of mitigating the risk of financial loss from defaults. We monitor the exposure and the credit ratings of our existing and potential counterparties continuously. Companies active in the component business use credit limits to assess their counterparty default risk, whereas a maximum risk limit is defined for each party. In most cases, this limit is derived from recognized credit rating agencies and credit default swaps if available. Appropriate action is taken if the individual limit is exceeded. Companies active in the project business ascertain the financial standing of potential customers on a case-by-case basis using all available financial information. Before a project order is accepted, the assessment is additionally reviewed under internal risk procedures. In the case of export transactions, confirmed and unconfirmed letters of credit are used alongside sureties, guarantees, and cover notes, including from export credit agencies. 79 ----- Trade receivables consist of a large number of customers, spread across different industries and regions. Hence, there is no concentration of risk. Valuation allowances take account of specific credit risks. Derivative financial instruments are concluded only with financial institutions with high credit-ratings assigned by international credit-rating agencies so as to reduce the credit risk involved. We do not have any critical credit risk exposure to any single counterparty or any group of counterparties having similar characteristics. The credit risk on cash and cash equivalents is limited because the counterparties are banks with high credit-ratings assigned by international credit-rating agencies and also typically are our lenders. Therefore, the credit quality of financial assets which are neither past due nor impaired is assessed to be good. The maximum exposure to credit risk of financial assets is the carrying amount. For additional information, see Note 5.10 of the 2023 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk
Subsubsection Title: Liquidity Risk
Subsubsection Text: We are exposed to liquidity risk which may mean that it may be unable to meet payment obligations because it has insufficient cash funds at its disposal. To manage our short, medium and long-term funding and liquidity requirements the management has established an appropriate liquidity risk control framework consisting _inter alia of a multi-year financial plan and a rolling month-by-month cash forecast. We manage the liquidity risk by maintaining adequate reserves, banking facilities, and reserve borrowing facilities as well as by monitoring forecasted cash flows at regular intervals. The cash flow from operating activities is the most important source of liquidity. In order to optimize borrowing and the use of our cash funds, cash pools in various countries are established. The cash pools automatically balance the accounts of the participating companies every day by crediting or debiting a target account. This prevents separate cash investments and borrowings by these companies to a large extent. For additional information on credit lines and guarantees, see Note 8.2 of the 2023 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: In the ordinary course of business, we are exposed to a variety of markets risks, including currency risks, credit risk and liquidity risk. We monitor and manage these risks as part of our overall risk management. The following section briefly describes the significant market risks to which we are exposed. This description does not address other risks to which we are exposed in the ordinary course of business, such as operational risks. See “Risk Factors.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Impairments of property, plant and equipment, and intangible assets
Subsubsection Text: The determination of impairments of property, plant and equipment, and intangible assets involves the use of estimates that include, but are not limited to, the cause, timing, and amount of the impairment. Impairment is based on a large number of factors, such as changes in current competitive conditions, expectations of growth in the heat exchanger industry, increased cost of capital, changes in the future availability of financing, technological obsolescence, discontinuance of services, current replacement costs, prices paid in comparable transactions, and other changes in circumstances, which indicate that an impairment exists. The identification of impairment indicators, as well as the estimation of future cash flows and the determination of fair values for assets (or groups of assets) require management to make significant judgements concerning the identification and validation of impairment indicators, expected cash flows, applicable discount rates, useful lives, and residual values. The carrying amounts of intangible assets, items of property, plant and equipment, and groups of cash-generating units with goodwill are reviewed if they are likely to have been impaired by events or changes in circumstances. In addition, indefinite-lived intangible assets and cash-generating units with goodwill are tested for impairment at least once a year. The impairment test compares the asset’s carrying amount against its recoverable amount (“impairment test”). The recoverable amount is defined as the higher of internal value in use and fair value less costs of disposal (net realizable value). An estimate of fair value less costs to sell is only required if the value in use is less than the carrying amount. If the carrying amount exceeds the recoverable amount, an impairment loss in the amount of the difference is recognized. In this case, the impairment loss is first deducted from the goodwill of the cash-generating unit with goodwill. Any amount exceeding goodwill is allocated proportionately to the carrying amounts of non-current non-financial assets. Fair value less costs of disposal is generally the benchmark for measuring the impairment of product groups classified as “held for sale”. The valuations of other intangible assets, which were performed as part of the impairment test, 80 ----- are based on management assumptions. Previously recognized impairment losses are reversed if the reasons for the impairment no longer apply, except in the case of goodwill. Impairment losses are reversed up to a maximum of the amortized historical cost.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Leases
Subsubsection Text: We use estimates and judgements that affect the determination of the lease term – e.g., determining the enforceable period and whether a lessee is reasonably certain either to exercise a renewal option or not to exercise a termination option. We determine the lease term at the commencement date. As a lessee, we are required to reassess the lease term on the occurrence of a significant event or change in circumstances that is within its control and directly affects whether it is reasonably certain to exercise (or not to exercise) an option included in the original contract. Both lessees and lessors revise the lease term if there is a change in the non-cancellable period. This requires ongoing monitoring and increases financial statement volatility. Lease payments are discontinued at the rate implicit in the lease if that rate can readily be determined. Otherwise, discounting is at the incremental borrowing rate. The incremental borrowing rate, which is mainly applied, is based on the risk adjusted interest rates and determined for the respective lease terms and currencies.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Impairment
Subsubsection Text: We recognize loss allowances for expected credit losses (“ECLs”) on financial assets measured at amortized cost, debt investments measured at FVOCI and contract assets. We measure loss allowances at an amount equal to lifetime ECLs, except for the following, which are measured at 12-month (a) ECLs debt securities that are determined to have low credit risk at the reporting date; (b) and other debt securities and bank balances for which credit risk (i.e., the risk of default occurring over the expected life of the financial instrument) has not increased significantly since initial recognition. Loss allowances for trade receivables (including lease receivables) and contract assets are always measured at an amount equal to lifetime ECLs. When determining whether the credit risk of a financial asset has increased significantly since initial recognition and when estimating ECLs, we consider reasonable and supportable information that is relevant and available without undue cost or effort. This includes both quantitative and qualitative information and analysis, based on our historical experience and informed credit assessment, that includes forward-looking information. We assume that the credit risk on a financial asset has increased significantly if it is more than 30 days past due. At each reporting date, we assess whether financial assets carried at amortized cost and debt securities at FVOCI are credit-impaired. A financial asset is ‘credit-impaired’ when one or more events that have a detrimental impact on the estimated future cash flows of the financial asset have occurred. Evidence that a financial asset is credit-impaired includes the following observable data: (a) significant financial difficulty of the debtor or it is probable that the debtor will enter bankruptcy or other financial reorganization. Loss allowances for financial assets measured at amortized cost are deducted from the gross carrying amount of the assets. For debt securities at FVOCI, the loss allowance is charged to profit or loss and is recognized in OCI. The gross carrying amount of a financial asset is written off when we have no reasonable expectations of recovering a financial asset in its entirety or a portion thereof.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Recognition and measurement of deferred tax assets and income tax uncertainties
Subsubsection Text: We operate in a large number of countries and is therefore subject to different tax jurisdictions. Calculating tax liabilities requires management to make various estimates. Management believes that it has made a reasonable estimate of tax uncertainties. However, no assurance can be given that the actual outcome of these uncertainties will correspond to the estimates made. Any deviations may have an impact on the level of tax liabilities or deferred taxes in the year of the decision. When assessing the recoverability of deferred tax assets, management judges the extent to which realization of the deferred tax assets is sufficiently likely. The question of whether the deferred tax assets can actually be realized depends on whether sufficient future taxable income can be generated against which the temporary differences or tax loss carryforwards can be offset. Management therefore analyses the times at which the deferred tax liabilities reverse, and expected future taxable income. Management forecasts whether deferred tax assets can be realized on the basis of expected future taxable income. Deferred tax assets decline if the estimate of planned taxable income decreases, tax benefits available as a result of tax strategies are reduced, or the amount or timing of future tax benefits is restricted by changes in law. For additional information, see Note 6.7 of the 2023 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Recognition and calculation of construction contracts
Subsubsection Text: Identification and definition of performance obligation, as well as timing of revenue recognition are based on management’s estimates. Further, the recognition of construction contracts using the percentage of completion method is based on management’s estimates of the cost to complete the contracts. Changes in estimates or differences between the estimated cost and the actual cost to complete have a direct effect on recognized earnings from construction contracts. The operating units continuously review the estimates and adjust them if required. 81 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Obligations under pension plans
Subsubsection Text: The present value of pension obligations depends on actuarial assumptions. These assumptions comprise discount rates, expected wage and salary increases, as well as the pension growth rate and mortality rates. These assumptions can differ significantly from actual future outcomes as a result of changes in market and economic conditions, and can therefore have a material effect on the level of the obligation and the related expenses. The discount rate of the net carrying amount is calculated at the end of each year. This is the rate used to calculate the present value of future cash outflows expected to be required to settle the obligation. In order to calculate the discount rate, we use the interest rate on high-quality corporate bonds denominated in the same currency in which the benefits are paid and whose terms to maturity correspond to those of the pension obligations. For additional information, see Note 5.4.1 of the 2023 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Litigation
Subsubsection Text: In some cases, our companies are parties to litigation. The outcome of this litigation could have a material effect on our net assets, financial position, and results of operations. Management regularly analyses current information on these legal disputes and recognizes provisions for probable obligations including legal costs. Both internal counsels and external lawyers make this assessment. When deciding on the need to recognize provisions, management takes into account the probability of an unfavorable outcome and its ability to estimate the amount of the obligation with sufficient reliability.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Determination of fair value of financial instruments
Subsubsection Text: The level of management judgement, required in establishing the fair value of financial instruments for which there is a quoted price in an active market, is usually minimal. Similarly, there is little subjectivity or judgement required for instruments valued using valuation models which are standard across the industry and where all input parameters are quoted in active markets (e.g., for foreign exchange rate derivatives). The level of subjectivity and degree of management judgement required is more significant for those instruments valued using models and techniques where some or all of the parameter inputs are less or not observable. Management judgement is required in the selection and application of appropriate parameters, assumptions and modelling techniques. This applies especially in establishing the fair value of the embedded derivatives. 82 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The Consolidated Financial Statements have been prepared in accordance with IFRS. The preparation of financial statements in conformity with IFRS requires the use of estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities, the disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of sales revenues and expenses during the relevant period. Although such estimates and assumptions are based on management’s best knowledge of current events and circumstances, the actual results ultimately may differ from those estimates and assumptions. The section below presents accounting policies which require management to make judgments and certain assumptions as the underlying facts are of uncertain nature. As a result, any changes in these facts or assumptions may affect the results presented in the Consolidated Financial Statements.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: INDUSTRY Introduction to the Heat Exchanger Industry: Heat Exchanger Types
Subsubsection Text: A heat exchanger is a device used for heat transfer from one medium to another, without mixing the two media. Heat exchangers are used across a broad range of applications, including data centers, heating, ventilation, air conditioning (“HVAC”), power & energy, oil & gas, food & beverages, chemicals, transportation and heavy & light industry and other vertical markets. An important commercial feature of heat exchangers is that they typically represent only a small portion of the machinery and equipment cost but have a high-value impact as they are important in maintaining optimal temperatures for industrial processes. For example, heat exchangers prevent machines from overheating, which could result in significant and costly downtime in production processes. Heat exchangers are also vital for maintaining the reliability, efficiency, and longevity of data center operations. They ensure that servers remain cool and perform optimally. Heat exchangers typically use either a liquid medium, where water or another liquid is used to cool or heat the fluid flowing through, or air media, where air is used as the cooling or heating medium. Examples of liquid cooled heat exchangers include shell and tube heat exchangers and plate heat exchangers, while examples of air-cooled heat exchangers include air fin coolers, radiators, and condensers. Heat exchangers frequently need to operate in difficult environments, including a broad range of temperatures (from -200 °C to +900 °C) and pressures (from -1 bar to +800 bar), as well as needing to be resistant to corrosion, fouling and scaling. Because of this range of requirements, heat exchangers are technologically advanced products that require sophisticated engineering capabilities. The key parameters which differentiate heat exchangers are temperature and flow of heat, which are in turn determined by the material characteristics such as thermal conductivity, density, specific heat, fluid viscosity, fluid velocity and surface emissivity, as well as gas characteristics. From a technology perspective, there are four basic types of heat exchangers/heat removal devices: shell and tube heat exchangers, plate heat exchangers, air-cooled heat exchangers and cooling towers. _Shell and tube heat exchangers consist of a pressure vessel known as a “shell,” with a bundle of tubes inside of_ it. One fluid runs through the tubes, while another flows over the tubes within the shell, to transfer heat between the two fluids. Shell and tube heat exchangers are widely used because of the high flexibility in allowing for a broad range of pressures and temperatures. The key applications for shell and tube heat exchangers include power generation, food and beverage, waste heat recovery, desalination, pharmaceuticals, oil and gas, petrochemical, and marine applications. _Plate heat exchangers consist of a frame that holds together several metal plates that are either sealed by gaskets_ or brazed or welded together. Hot and cold fluids enter the heat exchanger via separate ports, and flow in the alternate channels that are formed by a pair of plates. The key advantage offered by plate heat exchangers is that the fluids are spread out over the plates and therefore exposed to a larger surface area, which facilitates the transfer of heat. Plate heat exchangers have a wide range of applications, including Data Centers, HVAC, food and beverages, Pharmaceutical and Biotech, Dairy Industry, Chemical processing, Renewable Energy systems, industrial processes, refrigeration, oil and gas applications and district heating and cooling. In an air-cooled heat exchanger, a pressure vessel is used that cools a circulating fluid within a finned tube by forcing ambient air over the exterior of the tubes. Air-cooled heat exchangers are favored in some applications because they eliminate the need for a continuous water supply, reduce environmental impact, and provide reliable cooling in a wide range of operating conditions. They are useful in remote locations or arid regions where water resources are limited. Key applications broadly include Data Centers, Power generation, Petrochemical and Chemical Processing, Renewable Energy, HVAC, refrigeration (for food and beverages), power, oil and gas, and Marine applications. _Cooling towers are heat removal devices used to transfer unnecessary heat from process media to the atmosphere,_ using either the principle of evaporative cooling (wet cooling towers) or a closed-circuit cooling tower where there is no direct contact between the process media and cooling air (dry cooling towers). Their ability to dissipate large amounts of heat makes them a critical component in many cooling applications. Cooling towers are used for Data Centers, Renewable Energy systems, power applications and, to some extent, other process applications such as chemicals and petrochemical processing, oil and gas and district cooling systems. The choice for a particular type of heat exchanger depends on the type of application and the characteristics of the site (e.g., dry cooling is particularly relevant in arid areas, where water is scarce) and has a direct impact on the operational cost of the application. While shell and tube exchangers currently represent the largest product segment in the global market for heat exchangers and are popular owing to their flexibility and application in a wide range of environments characterized by different pressures and temperatures, the segment for plate heat exchangers is presently growing rapidly, in part because of energy efficiency concerns. 83 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Development of the Global Heat Exchanger Market
Subsubsection Text: The Frost & Sullivan Report on Global Heat Exchanger Growth Opportunities published in May 2023 estimates that the size of the global heat exchanger market in 2022 was U.S.$14.3 billion and is expected to grow at compounded annual growth rate (“CAGR”) of 6.4% CAGR globally between 2022 and 2027. The following chart shows the development of heat exchanger demand (in U.S.$) until 2027: _Source: Frost & Sullivan Report_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Demand for heat exchangers supported by mega trends
Subsubsection Text: _Strong demand for data centers_ A data center comprises extremely sensitive electronic components that require a consistent temperature, humidity, airflow, and cleanliness to prevent equipment failure. The strong growth in data centers is driven by several key factors such as: (1) the emergence and popularity of artificial intelligence (AI) based applications, (2) increased demand of cloud storage, (3) remote working and distant learning, (4) rise of data intensive technologies like machine learning (ML), internet of things (IoT) and (5) increasing digitalization of businesses and processes. This has led to a need for advanced processors that have high heat dissipation and require more power which in turn has resulted in a shift away from the traditional data center architecture to the adoption of advanced, more efficient cooling solutions such as adiabatic cooling, immersion cooling, economizer, or free cooling. Technology company’s increased investment in data centers is driving the construction and development of hyperscale data centers globally. While, at the same time, global data protection regimes are driving the development of local data center clusters, leading to regional data center demands. _Heat recovery for new living quarters_ Heat exchangers play a crucial role in HVAC systems by transferring heat between two or more fluids, typically air and a refrigerant, without mixing them. In the developed economies such as Europe and USA, strong regulatory initiatives requiring clean energy equipment to replace fossil fuel boilers in new buildings are driving demand for HVAC / heat pumps. In emerging economies, growing population, raising levels of disposable income, and increasing living standards coupled with global surface temperature rises in tandem with greenhouse gas concentrations are giving rise to increasing demand to preserve an ambient environment in a building, leading to growing demand for HVAC systems. _Increasing environmental awareness_ With the growing push for energy transition, several new industries are emerging out of the traditional industrial applications such as renewable energy, hydrogen economy, fuel cells, carbon capture utilization and storage (“CCUS”), among others. The global energy transition market is expected to grow driven by increasing regulatory standards, environmental awareness, and continuous investments to shift the energy mix to more sustainable options. Heat exchangers 84 ----- play a crucial role in power plants across the value chain in maintaining optimum operating conditions from generation to storage to distribution. By 2030, cumulative investments in energy are expected to reach U.S.$44 trillion, of which, 80% i.e., U.S.$35 trillion will be towards transition technologies prioritizing efficiency, electrification, grid expansion and flexibility (source: IRENA March 2023). _Industrialization worldwide_ In the post-pandemic world, industrial development is increasingly shaped by digitalization and automation of industrial production, a shift of global economic towards Asia and efforts to make industrial production more sustainable. Energy-efficient equipment in energy-intensive vertical markets such as chemical and pharmaceutical manufacturers, food and beverages processing plants, the oil and gas industry and the marine industry are key drivers for demand for heat exchangers. New, energy-saving applications for heat exchangers, such as waste heat recovery systems, have become increasingly important. The requirement by end-customers for products that reduce costs and limit environmental emissions necessitates technological improvements. _Shift towards intelligent service_ The shift towards intelligent services for heat exchanger applications refers to the integration of advanced technologies and digital solutions to enhance the monitoring, maintenance and overall performance of heat exchangers. This includes remote monitoring and diagnostics, predictive maintenance, condition-based monitoring, remote control and optimization, digital twin technology, integration with enterprise systems. The aim is to leverage digitalization and automation technologies to enhance operational efficiency, reliability, and sustainability while reducing the lifecycle costs and enhancing customer value. As the demand for efficiency increases in a more environmentally aware world, these intelligent services become more important.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The global heat exchanger market is primarily driven by the following trends and features:

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Asia Pacific
Subsubsection Text: The Frost & Sullivan Report estimates that the Asia Pacific global heat exchanger market size was U.S.$4.7 billion in 2022, making it the largest regional market globally, and is expected to grow at CAGR of 7.7% between 2022 and 2027. This compares to a 2020 market size for Asia Pacific of U.S.$4.2 billion, implying a CAGR of 5.9% between 2020 and 2022. According to the Frost & Sullivan Report, chemicals are the largest vertical market segment by far in Asia Pacific followed by power generation. The growing demand for heat exchangers in Asia Pacific is due to rapid urbanization, construction activities, increasing capital expenditure by industrial companies, and strong consumer demand underpinned by population growth. Asia Pacific is expected to emerge as the top chemical producer globally and emerging economies such as China and India are expected to emerge as two of the top three countries in the power generation sector worldwide (source: Frost & Sullivan Report). Additionally, constant investments in a range of industry vertical markets, such as the chemical and power generation industries, are expected to boost demand for heat exchangers.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Europe
Subsubsection Text: The Frost & Sullivan Report estimates that the European global heat exchanger market size was U.S.$4.6 billion in 2022, making it the second largest regional market globally, and is expected to grow at CAGR of 6.5% between 2022 and 2027. This compares to a 2020 market size of U.S.$4.0 billion, implying a CAGR of approximately 6.9% between 2020 and 2022. Europe will remain a major heat exchanger market. Heat exchanger adoption is likely to increase due to stringent requirements being implemented by EU government to reduce emissions.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: North America
Subsubsection Text: The Frost & Sullivan Report estimates that the North American heat exchanger market size was U.S.$3.7 billion in 2022 and is expected to grow at a CAGR of 5.5% between 2022 and 2027, compared to a 2020 market size of U.S.$3.4 billion, implying a CAGR of 4.6% between 2020 and 2022. Power generation is the largest vertical market for heat exchangers in North America followed by chemicals, oil & gas, HVAC & refrigeration and data centers. Expanding refinery capacity and new chemical plant installations are expected to drive the North American heat exchanger market. North America’s continually increasing energy consumption supported by the power generation industry, which relies largely on 85 ----- heat exchangers, is expected to expand substantially. The installation of surface heat exchangers to update existing power plants and reduce carbon emissions is also expected to contribute to the growing demand for heat exchangers.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Latin America
Subsubsection Text: The Frost & Sullivan Report estimates that the Latin American heat exchanger market size was U.S.$0.4 billion in 2022 and expected to grow at a CAGR of 3.3% between 2022 and 2027 compared to a 2020 market size of U.S.$0.38 billion, implying a CAGR of 2.9% between 2020 and 2022. Primary applications for heat exchangers in Latin America are in-vehicle radiators, air conditioning systems, and sewage treatment facilities. An increasing number of heat exchangers being refurbished at conventional power stations, refineries, and chemical processing plants is expected to be a key factor driving growth in the Latin American market for heat exchangers. A growing population, raising levels of disposable income, and shifting living standards leading to increased demand for passenger vehicle and installation of HVAC systems in residential areas are also expected to have a positive impact on demand for heat exchangers in this market.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Middle East and Africa
Subsubsection Text: The Frost & Sullivan Report estimates that the Middle East and Africa heat exchanger market size was U.S.$1.0 billion in 2022 and is expected to grow at a CAGR of 4.5% between 2022 and 2027 compared to a 2020 market size of U.S.$0.9 billion, implying a CAGR of 4.3% between 2020 and 2022. Oil & Gas is the largest vertical market in Middle East and Africa for heat exchangers followed by chemicals, food & beverage, and power generation. Recent industry decline in Oil & Gas is expected to impact the growth of the market, however Middle East and Africa is also the largest market for commercial and residential centralized cooling systems, which is expected to drive heat exchanger market growth.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: In terms of geographical markets and as per definitions of the Frost & Sullivan Report, Asia Pacific is the largest regional market for heat exchangers, followed by Europe, and North America. While Europe and North America are characterized as a mature market, Asia Pacific has shown rapid growth in the past few years. The last years have witnessed a shift in demand from developed to emerging markets, and thus emerging countries and regions such as Asia Pacific, Latin America and the Middle East are expected to grow substantially on the back of growing population, rapid urbanization, increased industrialization and growing digitalization.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Heat Exchanger Demand in Key Strategic Pillars
Subsubsection Title: High Tech
Subsubsection Text: The High Tech sector is defined as comprising primarily of Data Centers (Hyperscalers, Colocation, Modular etc). As per the Frost & Sullivan Report, global Data Center heat exchange demand is expected to grow at a CAGR of 7.8% between 2022 and 2027. APAC is expected to witness the highest growth in the data center cooling market as data center installation ramps up and requires higher cooling due to the region’s hot climate. North America is the second-largest market followed by Europe. The types of heat exchangers used for data center are plate heat exchangers, liquid, or aircooled heat exchangers, adiabatic coolers, direct liquid / immersion cooler, economizer / free cooler. As processing power of the Data Centers increase and artificial intelligence / machine learning systems gain momentum, the cooling requirement of Data Centers are expected to increase. Along with air-cooled and chilled water solutions, data center operators are expected to increasingly deploy liquid cooling to increase efficiency of cooling solutions and reduce operational expenditure. North America is the leader in deploying advanced cooling solutions such as liquid coolers, adiabatic cooling, and economizer. Vertical market applications include, white space cooling, either air based (CRAC, CRAH) or liquid based (Direct to Chip, Immersion Cooling, Edge Cooling), heat rejection and recovery, utility cooling and backup generator cooling.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Heat Exchanger Demand in Key Strategic Pillars
Subsubsection Title: Green Tech
Subsubsection Text: The Green Tech sector is defined as comprising of HVAC, Carbon Capture Storage (CCS), Hydrogen economy and Liquified Natural Gas (LNG). This sector focuses on those application practices, processes and products aimed at minimizing environmental impact and promoting conservation of resources. It encompasses a wider range of technologies and solutions that strive to directly or indirectly address environmental challenges such as climate change, pollution, resource depletion and ecosystem degradation. _HVAC & Refrigeration_ The HVAC industry is growing, driven by rapid expansion in commercial and residential building development projects and purchases, worldwide. In developing economies, increasing urbanization and industrialization have created demand for more HVAC-equipped enterprises and residential complexes. Energy efficiency is now required for new HVAC installations. Governments globally have implemented legislation to encourage the use of HVAC systems that satisfy industry standards for energy efficiency. The global heat exchanger demand from HVAC and refrigeration applications is expected to grow at CAGR of 5.9% from 2022 to 2027 as per the Frost & Sullivan Report. 86 ----- _Carbon Capture Storage (CCS)_ CCS is an engineered system of technologies, refined over several decades, in the process of mitigating CO2 emissions from large point sources such as power plants, refineries and other industrial facilities, or the removal of existing CO2 from the atmosphere. Captive markets, where the producer of CO2 is also the consumer, such as in chemical production or natural gas processing for enhanced oil recovery, account for the majority of global carbon capture activity. The United States are the largest CCS market followed by Europe and APAC. Carbon capture is an increasing focus for all companies to leverage their competitive advantage in an emerging industry. Heat exchangers are essential in CCS processes for their role in energy efficiency, thermal processing, thereby reducing operational costs, and also forms a significant part of the investment in CCS projects. _Hydrogen economy_ Hydrogen economy is an umbrella term used to denote hydrogen’s role alongside low-carbon electricity to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases. It represents a significant growth market with diverse applications across various sectors such as heavy industry, long-haul transport, and long-term energy storage. This diversity of applications provides a wide range of opportunities. Currently, most hydrogen is produced from natural gas. Investment in technologies for producing green hydrogen (from renewable energy sources) and blue hydrogen (from natural gas with carbon capture and storage) could yield significant returns as these technologies mature and scale up. The growth of the hydrogen economy is driven by growing demand for cleaner fuel, coupled with increasing governmental regulations for desulphurization of petroleum products. Heat exchangers are an essential part of hydrogen generation as the technology / electrolysis process of generation of hydrogen is an exothermal process. Plate Heat Exchangers and Air Fin Coolers are typically used for this purpose. _Liquified Natural Gas (LNG)_ LNG is natural gas that has been cooled down to -162 °C to transform it into a liquid, making it easier and safer to transport. Natural gas primarily is methane and, when burned, releases water vapor and CO2. With emissions at 30-50% less than from other combustible sources, natural gas is regarded as the cleanest of the fossil fuels. LNG is considered as bridge fuel which can make energy transition easier. Fuel switching, primarily from fossil to LNG can reduce CO2 emissions and air pollutions. In the backdrop of recent geo-political situation and Europe’s quest to reduce dependency on Russian gas supply, LNG prices have risen sharply. Increased prices spurred a high level of new supply expected from 2024 to 2028. 193 million tons per annum nameplate capacity is expected to be added by 2028, which would represent 40% of the current capacity, implying 9% CAGR supply growth between 2024 and 2028. (source: IEEFA Report). Heat exchangers are used along the whole value chain of LNG starting from extraction, treatment, liquification, transportation, regasification and end use (power generation, gas boilers, hydrogen production).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Heat Exchanger Demand in Key Strategic Pillars
Subsubsection Title: Conventional Sectors
Subsubsection Text: Conventional sectors are defined as comprising of oil & gas, chemicals, power and energy, food & beverage, transportation, and heavy & light industry. _Chemicals_ As per the Frost & Sullivan Report, the chemical industry was the largest consumer of heat exchangers globally in 2022 contributing 25% of the heat exchanger demand and heat exchanger demand from this sector is expected to grow at a CAGR of 7.2% between 2022 and 2027. As more oil and gas businesses diversify into chemicals and petrochemicals to create new demand for oil and gas goods, the demand for heat exchangers is expected to continue to remain steady for this sector. China is the largest chemicals market accounting for approx. 60% of the APAC market, as per the Frost & Sullivan Report. Heat transfer is an energy-intensive phase in many chemical processes and not prioritizing efficiency might therefore result in inflated costs. The most popular kind of heat exchangers used in the chemical processing sector are Shell-and-Tube units because of their adaptability and capacity to handle fluids with various levels of particles. As a result, the chemical sector drives significant demand for Shell-and-Tube heat exchangers as it is capable of confining substances. _Power Generation_ As per the Frost & Sullivan Report, the power generation industry was the second largest end-market for heat exchangers globally in 2022, contributing 22% of the heat exchanger demand and heat exchanger demand from this sector is expected to grow at CAGR of 5.9% between 2022 and 2027. Population rises driving electricity generation contributing to growth of the heat exchanger market in the power generation industry. Europe is focused extensively on renewables, and North America and APAC are constructing additional thermal power plants to maintain a continuous increase in power generation capacity. The top three power generation countries are the United States, China, and India, with each spending extensively in thermal and dependable power. China and India are two of the fastest growing markets for heat exchangers 87 ----- for the power generation sector, with heavy investment in coal-fired and natural-gas-fired power plants to satisfy the predicted rise in energy demand. _Oil & Gas_ As per the Frost & Sullivan Report, the oil & gas industry was the third largest consumer of heat exchangers globally in 2022 contributing 16% of the heat exchanger demand and heat exchanger demand from this sector is expected to grow at a CAGR of 5.5% between 2022 and 2027. The upstream, midstream, and downstream segments of the oil and gas industry all have a need for heat exchangers. Oil refiners can help to optimize energy use and reduce emissions by combining efficient heat transfer technologies with process and application expertise. Up until it is burned, crude oil could be heated significantly by using welded-plate heat exchangers, which could result in significant operational expenditure reductions. Demand for heat exchangers in the oil and gas sector will rebound from the downturn during the forecast period because of increasing exploration and production activity globally. _Food & beverage_ As per the Frost & Sullivan Report, the food and beverage industry contributed to 8% demand for heat exchangers in 2022 and heat exchanger demand from this sector is expected to grow at a CAGR of 6.6% between 2022 and 2027. In the food and beverage sector, heat exchangers help reduce or eliminate microorganisms, which enhances product safety and shelf life. A heat exchanger may be used to warm or cool goods prior to procedures including filling, drying, and concentrating. For food processing techniques such as pasteurization and sterilization, heat exchangers are essential to maintain specific ambient temperature and humidity. The viscosity and particle size of the product determine the kind of heat exchanger used in this sector. The plate Heat Exchanger, used to move fluids swiftly, is the most used heat exchanger. Global food trends influence heat exchanger innovation in numerous ways. _Transportation, Heavy & Light Equipment_ This segment is not covered specifically in the Frost & Sullivan report as there is some crossover in other sectors in their analysis. However, we split out this market segment to focus on heat exchangers applied in different types of Transportation, Heavy and Light Equipment. Land transportation covers Rail, Road and Off-Road, as well as water transportation (e.g. Marine and Shipping). Heavy and Light Equipment heat exchangers are applied for example in heavy industry for production of large and heavy equipment, heavy machinery, coal, steel and other metals etc., and in light industry for production of light equipment, industrial cooling, paper, textile and other consumer goods. This segment is often characterized by direct end user relationships or OEM customers. The market dynamics are driven by growth in infrastructure projects, global manufacturing growth, energy efficiency requirements driven by global sustainability drive and general GDP growth Competition.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Heat Exchanger Demand in Key Strategic Pillars
Subsubsection Text: Heat exchangers are used in processes across a diverse range of industries. The major vertical markets for the global heat exchanger are the following: chemical (25%), power generation (22%), oil and gas (16%), HVAC and refrigeration (9%), data centers (8%), food and beverages (8%) and other industries (source: Frost & Sullivan Report). The major vertical markets for the Company follow a different split than that of the general market and can be categorized as mainly as High Tech, Green Tech, and Conventional sectors. The following is a description of the specific applications of our offering within each vertical market, as well as growth expectations and certain key drivers of each vertical market.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The competitive landscape in the heat exchanger industry is fragmented and varies significantly depending on the specific technology (shell and tube, plate, finned tube, cooling tower), business model (project, component), vertical market and geography. Depending on the region and the type of heat exchanger, we compete with both large international as well as with numerous smaller regional and local competitors. The service business is primarily local. According to the Frost & Sullivan Report, European manufacturers are the largest participants in the global market owing to large domestic markets and domestic strength, although a large number of small competitors compete in most regional markets. The Frost & Sullivan Report sees cost-effective manufacturers from the Asia Pacific region creating price pressures in the European market. Key competitive factors are customer proximity, engineering competence and cost competitiveness, and customer relationship. Rising raw material prices and a price sensitive customer base are resulting in thinner profit margins for manufacturers, mainly because the ability to transfer increased cost of production to customers remains limited. The Group’s global competitors are Alfa Laval, Lu-Ve, Güntner and Modine, S&T. Alfa Laval is our main competitor the in Plate Heat Exchanger market whereas, Lu-VE, an Italian manufacturer focusing on refrigeration technologies and is increasingly focusing on US and China. Danfoss is also a strong player in the market. In recent years, Lu-VE has also grown through acquisitions, for example the acquisition of Refion from Alfa Laval in 2022 to expand its portfolio mainly in the HVAC segment. 88 ----- Source: Internal estimates, Frost & Sullivan Report, MarketsandMarkets Report. (1) Services Total Addressable Market (TAM) is also included in High Tech, Green Tech, and Conventional TAMs. Services Order Intake is not accounted for in Global Market Shares HT/GT/C. (2) Green Tech applications are prevalent across nearly all vertical markets. The primary market is Heat Pumps (HVAC), but other relevant markets include LNG, Green Hydrogen, carbon capture and Bio-ethanol. The reported 20% CAGR is based on all the sub-applications within the various vertical markets, thus it differs from the HVAC CAGR. (3) Of relevant heat exchanger market value based on market reports and company estimates, calculated as Order Intake / TAM. (4) Refers to global heat exchanger market by revenue based on Frost & Sullivan Report, MarketsandMarkets Report, Third Party Report and internal estimates. 89 ----- The heat exchanger market is fragmented, and we are among the few global suppliers. The competitive landscape varies significantly depending on the specific technology (shell and tube, plate, finned tube, cooling tower), business model (project, component), end-market and geography. Depending on the region and the type of heat exchanger, we compete with both large international and smaller regional and local competitors. We believe that our services business primarily faces competition from local players and we currently do not expect increased competition from low cost countries. In RT, our primary competitors include LU-VE Group, Güntner and Modine. In MCS, our primary competitors are Modine and Vestas. 97 ----- In PHE, our primary competitors include Alfa Laval, Danfoss and SWEP.
