In KTS, our primary competitors include SPX, Evaptech, TAS and Verdon in the high tech market, Alfa Laval, SNT Energy and CHART in the green market and SNT Energy and CHART in the Oil & Gas market.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are a leading global provider of heat exchanger solutions with more than 100 years of experience in design, manufacturing, installation and service (source: Frost & Sullivan Report). We have built our strategic pillars on (i) High Tech applications and solutions, in particular for Data Centers with liquid and free cooling, (ii) Green Tech applications and solutions in various vertical markets, such as Power & Energy, HVAC, Hydrogen, Liquified Natural Gas, Carbon Capture Storage, (iii) Conventional applications, such as in the Refrigeration, Food & Beverage, Chemicals and Oil & Gas vertical markets, as well as (iv) Service applications across all our vertical markets and product groups. Our diversified presence across regions and transformative industries are supported by long-term underlying megatrends, such as digitalization, energy transition and environmental concerns in general. Based on the breath of our product portfolio, extensive global footprint, and diverse end-markets, as well as our technology leadership position and R&D capabilities, we believe we are well-positioned to benefit from the long-term growth trends in our vertical markets. Since 2021, under our new management, we have been implementing a comprehensive strategic program known as “High Five”. The High Five program is designed to build a long-term sustainable business and comprises the following five strategic pillars: (i) Grow High Tech, (ii) Grow Green Tech, (iii) More Service, (iv) Grow APAC & Americas and (v) More Digitalization, with greater emphasis on reducing complexity through digitalization. At the same time, we divested unprofitable businesses, such as the Enexio in recent years. Since the beginning of 2021 and despite several external shocks, such as the Russia-Ukraine war and the spike in energy prices and inflation caused thereby, our Order Intake, Revenue and Normalized EBITDA have increased from €1,099.3 million, €931.7 million and €78.8 million, respectively, for the year ended December 31, 2021 to €1,697.9 million, €1,347.9 million and €146.9 million, respectively, for the year ended December 31, 2023. Historically, our business operations have been primarily divided into four product groups: Kelvion Thermal Solutions (“KTS”), Refrigeration Technologies (“RT”), Plate Heat Exchangers (“PHE”) and Machine Cooling Systems (“MCS”). We also consider our key vertical markets and geographic regions in the management of our business. - _KTS provides air fin coolers and cooling towers for installations with large cooling requirements as well as air dryers used to remove humidity from air streams. KTS focuses on providing customized solutions and primarily serves Data Centers, Power & Energy, Oil & Gas and Chemicals vertical markets. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, KTS accounted for 44.6% of our revenue. - _RT supplies standard and customized heat exchangers for cooling and removing heat in different applications using air and liquid cooling methods. The primary vertical markets are HVAC, refrigeration applications and Data Centers. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, RT accounted for 20.5% of our revenue. - _PHE offers a range of gasketed, brazed and welded plate heat exchangers for a variety of applications and vertical markets, including HVAC, Food & Beverage, Chemicals, Power & Energy and Heavy & Light Equipment. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, PHE accounted for 17.9% of our revenue. - _MCS supplies heat exchangers for power generation, power transmission, large engine applications (marine and off-highway) and Green Tech applications such as biomass, green hydrogen, or renewable energies. The primary vertical markets are Transportation, Heavy & Light Equipment, Power & Energy and Oil & Gas. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, MCS accounted for 14.3% of our revenue. Since the beginning of 2024, the RT, MCS and PHE have been managed on a regional basis in the following geographic regions – Americas, APAC and EMEA. In addition, all our product groups’ activities are complemented by a comprehensive after-sales support and services offering, reflecting our ability to support our customers with full-service packages thereby reducing their operating costs. We provide services both for our own products as well as for third-party products, managed on a centralized and global basis across our product groups. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our service business generated revenues of €251 million and for the year ended December 31, 2023 revenues of €259 million, an increase of 21% compared to the year ended December 31, 2022. We have a large and diverse customer base, including many blue-chip customers, and have built long-standing customer partnerships. Our customer base comprises more than 19,000 active customers (i.e., customers that have placed an order with us in the last 24 months) and repeat orders over multiple years from more than 12,000 customers. Our customer base is also diversified across vertical markets and geographies. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our Order Intake by strategic pillar can be broken down as follows: circa 39% in High Tech, circa 36% in Conventional applications, circa 17% in services and circa 7% in Green Tech. During the same period, the Order Intake by geography comprised circa 45% in EMEA, circa 42% in Americas and circa 13% in APAC. 90 ----- Headquartered in Herne, Germany, we operate in 24 countries around the world, with 22 production facilities, 33 service centers and 19 engineering centers as of March 31, 2024. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, we generated total revenue of €1,401 million and Normalized EBITDA of €157.2 million.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Global market leader for mission-critical solutions to transformative industries, including Data Centers, Power & Energy, HVAC, Carbon Capture Storage and Hydrogen
Subsubsection Text: We are a leading global provider of heat exchanger solutions (source: Frost & Sullivan Report) serving a diverse range of transformative industries (such as Data Centers, Power & Energy, HVAC, Carbon Capture Storage, and Hydrogen), and vertical markets with a broad and differentiated product portfolio. We are also among the top three global providers (based on our Order Intake in the addressable market, as of 2022) and the only company that can provide the full spectrum of solutions across all vertical markets globally. Our leading market position is supported by our comprehensive geographical footprint with operations in 24 countries (comprising 22 production facilities, 33 service centers and 19 engineering centers as of March 31, 2024) as well as our diverse product offering across a broad range of heat exchanger products, which differentiates us from our competitors. Our solutions and products are often mission-critical to our clients’ operations because they are necessary to ensure the efficiency and safety of our clients’ operations while they only represent a relatively small portion of the overall cost. Transformative Industries support the exponential growth of digital data by providing the infrastructure for data storage, processing, and management of digital data. Innovations in cooling and energy efficiency are transforming this sector. Power & Energy includes renewable sources, smart grids and energy storage solutions. Advances in these areas are crucial for reducing carbon emissions and transitioning to a more sustainable energy framework. Innovations in HVAC systems are enhancing energy efficiency, comfort in residential, commercial and industrial buildings. Smart HVAC technologies and sustainable practices are at the forefront of this transformation. The Carbon Capture Storage industry focuses on technologies to capture and store carbon dioxide emissions from industrial processes and power generation, helping to mitigate climate change. Lastly, the Hydrogen industry is developing technologies for producing, storing, and utilizing hydrogen as a clean energy source. Hydrogen has the potential to play a significant role in decarbonizing transportation, industry and power generation. As part of our High Five program, we focus on vertical markets within the strategic pillars High Tech and Green Tech. These strategic pillars present a significant market opportunity to us which is forecast to grow significantly until 2027. We estimate that the total addressable market for heat exchangers in the vertical markets comprising our High Tech and Green Tech pillars amounted to €2.4 billion and €1.1 billion in 2022, respectively (source: Frost & Sullivan Report, MarketsandMarkets Report, Third Party Report and internal company assessments). These vertical markets are also forecast to have the most attractive growth rates, expanding at a CAGR of 8% and 20%, respectively, between 2022 and 2027. During the same period, we reduced our exposure to Oil & Gas, Chemicals and Power & Energy from 37% of our Order Intake for the year ended December 31, 2021 to 29% in the twelve months ended March 31, 2024. Our decentralized model of local production, near our customers, helps us maintain our leading positions in our core geographic regions. Our ability to provide a one-stop shop product approach combined with our service offering is increasingly valued by customers. Compared to smaller, regionally focused peers, we believe we have a better understanding of technical, health, safety and environmental regulation standards globally and locally. Combined with our scale and logistical strength to carry out large projects which are generally command improved margins. We believe that this differentiated product and service offering has been instrumental for recent contract wins from key customers. For example, we were awarded an order from a leading US-based bitcoin mining platform for adiabatic hybrid coolers. We developed a customized solution focusing on water and energy consumption. As a result, our cooling solution required 70% less water and 25% less energy than existing models, which also aligns well with our own long-term sustainability goals. Another example is an order from a US-based hyperscaler in the Data Center vertical market. Through measures, such as joint technology workshops with the customer, material optimization and a design-to-cost approach, we believe we were able to reduce the material requirements for our heat exchanger solutions by approximately 10% compared to existing models. Our global scale also underpins the strength of our brand, which places us well to continue to strengthen our positions in these fast growing and transformative end-markets segments and vertical markets.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Well-positioned to benefit from long-term sustainable secular megatrends, such as increasing environmental awareness and the changes triggered by energy transition, along with the growth of digitalization
Subsubsection Text: We believe we are strategically well-positioned to benefit from underlying megatrends across our strategic pillars and vertical markets. The key pillars and vertical markets we serve are characterized by underlying growth supported by long-term sustainable trends. 91 ----- For example, the High Tech market, which accounted for 39% of our Order Intake for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, is projected to increase at a CAGR of 8% from 2022 to 2027 due to strong and growing demand for data centers. The Green Tech market, which accounted for 7% of our Order Intake for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, is expected to grow at a CAGR of 20% between 2022 to 2027 based on an increasing focus on energy efficiency and environmental awareness, which, in turn, is driving regulatory changes aimed at climate protection and heat recovery for residential and commercial buildings as well as for industrial applications (source: Frost & Sullivan Report, MarketsandMarkets Report, Third Party Report and internal company assessments). Similar global trends and the (re)-industrialization in Conventional markets underpin the growth outlook across a range of industries, with the services business also being transformed by a shift to, and higher demand for, high-proximity and intelligent services. Note: Based on nominal rates. Primary market for Green Tech is Heat Pumps (HVAC), but definition of Green Tech includes other vertical markets such as LNG, Green Hydrogen, Carbon Capture and Bio-ethanol. OI = Order Intake (1) Electric power generation and distribution (2) Including Marine & Shipbuilding, Mining, Water and Wastewater (3) Difference in the sum due to “other industries” segment, accounting for circa €30m of revenue and circa €34m of Order Intake 2023 Source: Frost & Sullivan Report

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Difficult to replicate business model, underpinned by differentiated engineering solutions, service capabilities and customer responsiveness
Subsubsection Text: We believe our differentiated technical offerings and service capabilities are difficult to replicate and, consequently, create high barriers to entry and prevent new competitors from easily entering our markets. Our application engineering expertise and production know-how are based on decades of experience and supported by our network of 19 engineering centers and more than 450 engineers worldwide. Our innovation portfolio includes hybrid coolers for High Tech, our advanced diffusion bonded heat exchanger “K°Bond” used in oil rigs, LNG, regasification facilities and CO2 stations, natural refrigerants, high pressure laser welded cassette (HPL) for Green Tech and hydrogen leakage testing for Services. In particular, our advanced manufacturing technologies, including 3D design and simulation, help to improve product performance and reduce failure rates. In addition, computational fluid design and simulation is validated by our inhouse labs and supports the development of our thermal design know-how and proprietary software, which enables us to design solutions according to customer requirements. Our differentiated technical solutions are complemented by our strong Service offering and proximity to our customers, including the ability to provide local service to global customers based on our presence in 24 countries and the ability to service other third-party brands. This is backed by performance agreements, aimed at maximizing customers’ return on investment and predictive maintenance to reduce operational downtime. We have a full-service portfolio spanning start-up (safe delivery, installation and early start post installation support), inspection and maintenance (period checks), repairs and overhauls, testing and monitoring (understanding condition of equipment), spare parts (designed to match the original parts), upgrades and replacements (for outdated components) and consulting and training (leading to competency of client personnel). We believe the breadth of our portfolio of Services offers customers seamless operation across the globe. The responsiveness to our customers, and our close working relationship build trust in our solutions and delivery. This builds long-term partnerships and trust fostering reliability as evidenced by the high proportion of our 19,000 active customers (i.e., customers that have placed an order with us in the last 24 months) that have placed repeat orders over 92 ----- multiple years. We are of the opinion that these long-term partnerships are another factor that makes our business model difficult to replicate.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Highly diversified revenue stream across geographies and vertical markets ensuring stable growth and operational flexibility
Subsubsection Text: The combination of our global footprint, comprehensive product portfolio and range of vertical markets we serve provides us with a well-diversified income stream. We serve approximately ten vertical markets and have operations in 24 countries. This allows us to realize growth opportunities from higher demand in individual sectors or regions, for example in the Data Center vertical market where revenue contribution increased by 88% in the year ended December 31, 2023 (compared to the year ended December 31, 2022). We also believe this helps us better withstand adverse changes and developments in a particular market or sector. The charts below show our revenue, by vertical market and by geography, for the year ended December 31, 2023. (1) Based on customer country

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: High revenue visibility from strong Order Intake and Order Backlog development
Subsubsection Text: Our Order Intake and Order Backlog provide us with high revenue visibility, and we believe the strong development in our Order Intake and Order Backlog will support our future performance and continued growth. From 2021 to 2023, Order Intake increased at a CAGR of approximately 24%, from €1,099 million in the year ended December 31, 2021, to €1,698 million in the year ended December 31, 2023 and Order Backlog increased from €615 million as of December 31, 2021 to €1,103 million as of December 31, 2023. Over the same period, our revenue increased from €931.7 million in the year ended December 31, 2021, to €1,347.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2023, resulting in a consistent ratio of Order Intake to revenue of more than 1.0x (“book-to-bill ratio”) across the periods. Moreover, for the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, our book-to-bill-ratio amounted to 1.1x. Revenue visibility is further enhanced by the fact that, historically, a majority of our Order Intake in any given year was converted into revenue in the same fiscal year or the next succeeding year. The portion of our Order Intake in the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023 that was or is planned to be converted into revenue in the same year or the next succeeding year represented 51% and 54% of our revenue for the years ended December 31, 2022, and 2023 as well as 62% of our budgeted revenue for the year ending December 31, 2024. We believe that our high revenue visibility also helps drive our profitability as it allows for improved management of customer order fulfilment, efficient operations planning and hence limits impacts under absorption. Our diversified presence across geographic regions and vertical markets enables us to benefit from increasing demand in specific regions and vertical markets without being overly dependent on any single region or vertical market. Order Intake for the year ended December 31, 2023, included €860 million in KTS, €388 million in RT, €258 million in PHE and €210 million in MCS, driven to a significant extent by strong growth in KTS. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, Order Intake was led by High Tech, followed by Conventional and with Green Tech and Service broadly equal. Americas and EMEA dominated the regions and APAC has been steadily growing. 93 ----- The increase in Order Intake has been driven primarily by high demand for data center applications (particularly in the United States due to hyperscalers) and HVAC applications (driven by catch-up in China). The growth has also been attributable to large projects, including a carbon capture project in North America (approximately U.S. $118 million in contract value) and an Oil & Gas project in Brazil (approximately U.S.$ 62 million in contract value).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Consistent and sustained progress in implementation of operational excellence plan will further enhance profitability development
Subsubsection Text: We have a strong track record of successfully implementing operational excellence measures across our businesses to enhance profitability. These include initiatives to drive revenue growth, such as pricing adjustments and production capacity realignments to increase and optimize production capacity to grow with our customers. To strengthen our position, we are also refocusing our innovation pipeline to consistently introduce new products on a global scale. They also include measures focused on our cost position, such as numerous supply chain initiatives across our supply chain on a global scale (with 74 identified measures completed within 2024), production capacity utilization measures (including production re-organization) and evaluating product mix to identify and focus on most profitable products and customer demand. In addition, beginning in 2022, we initiated a range of actions and measures to systematically improve our cash position by focusing on working capital. These included, among others, regular forecasting and active monitoring of cash management and cash conversion cycles, enhancements of enterprise resource planning systems to better track inventory levels and reduce slow-moving materials as well as actively managing receivables through initiating standard customer debt collection policies. As a result, we reduced trade working capital w/o retention from 12.1% of revenue for the year ended December 31, 2021 to 1.1% of revenue for the year ended December 31, 2023. Over the same period, we managed to increase our Free Cash Flow Conversion rate from 57.8% for the year ended December 31, 2021 to 61.5% for the year ended December 31, 2023. Over the last three years, we have set several measures to improve our operational efficiency (e.g. quality cost improvements from inward quality review and improvements in internal processes) and commercial efficiency. Our commercial efficiency focuses on the core areas (i) target selling (e.g. focus on vertical markets), (ii) process simplification (e.g. sales order review) and (iii) digitalization. The chart below illustrates the impact of the above mentioned measures on our Normalized EBITDA between the year ended December 31, 2021 and the twelve months ended March 31, 2024: nEBITDA = Normalized EBITDA (1) D&A is part of gross profit; it has been added back to calculate nEBITDA. 94 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Proven leadership team with track record of transformation, growth, and value creation
Subsubsection Text: We benefit from an experienced management team led by Andy Blandford, our Chief Executive Officer, and Mark Bevan, our Chief Financial Officer, each of whom joined the Group in 2022 and have more than 30 years of experience in various management and executive management positions at leading global companies. Our leadership team includes Harald Gössl, EVP Technology, and Steffen Thierfelder, EVP Sales & Services, each of whom also has more than 20 years of experience. They are supported by leadership team with extensive industry experience and operational know-how, including regional managers responsible for developing their respective markets. We believe that the collective industry experience and operational know-how of our leadership team, combined with their extensive management experience, provide us with a competitive advantage and are instrumental for the implementation of our strategy and achievement of our long-term objective of delivering sustainable growth.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We believe we benefit from the following competitive strengths:

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Focus on growth in High Tech and Green Tech markets
Subsubsection Text: We aim to utilize our strong technological capabilities and innovative solutions to capture the growing demand from customers in the High Tech and Green Tech markets, such as, Data Centers, HVAC, Carbon Capture Storage, Renewable Energy and LNG. These vertical markets are characterized by high growth potential, complex requirements, and stringent quality standards, which create attractive opportunities for us as a reliable and flexible partner. We plan to expand our presence in these vertical markets by developing new solutions and applications, enhancing our customer relationships, and pursuing selective acquisitions that complement our portfolio and geographic footprint.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Continue to grow our Service business
Subsubsection Text: We intend to leverage our large installed product and customer base to continue to grow our Service business. For example, we are focused on improving the organizational setup of our Service business across our product groups by establishing dedicated service responsibilities and pooling service skills across product groups in certain regions and increasing transparency. In KTS, we are considering strategic cooperations with specialist service providers to drive our service business coverage and support our strategic objectives to benefit from robust growth in our strategic pillars and vertical markets. This way we can utilize our product and engineering knowledge with a technical service partner who has a strong market foothold that we can leverage.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Increase market share in the Americas and APAC region
Subsubsection Text: We intend to continue to focus on the growth of our global platform and improve our market share in the Americas and APAC regions through investment in production capacity and local dedicated sales teams. For example, we aim to leverage our scale to further penetrate existing markets and strengthen our positions in China, India and the United States, by capitalizing on strong and growing demand in our Data Center business in the Americas as well as in our HVAC and Carbon Capture Storage solutions in Green Tech market applications. In RT and MCS, we intend to increase production capacity and optimize production locations in the United States as well as build up a dedicated sales team for the Transportation market. In the APAC region, we plan to continue to focus on product localization in the region and investing in our sales and distribution networks.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Continue to reduce complexity and focus on digitalization to drive operational excellence
Subsubsection Text: We continue to pursue our strategy of operational excellence by reducing complexity and enhancing digitalization across our functional and business areas. This means focusing on activities like “80/20” where we seek to improve the profitability of our product range, optimizing SAP in key locations, reducing process complexity through digital tools such as Tagetik (our financial consolidation tool) and SAP (our core ERP). We also continue to deploy tools such as Power BI to help us, for example, manage inventory reduction and improve our supply chain management globally. In addition, we are exploring the use of Artificial Intelligence to support our sales and engineering processes, along with implementing SAP CPQ and LO-VC. We continue to focus on the optimization of our operational footprint, especially in EMEA region, and ensure we are manufacturing the right products in the right place for cost optimization and customer requirements. 95 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We started our journey to create consistency in performance, profitability and a platform for growth in 2021 with the High Five strategic program. This set out five focus areas to concentrate on to build a better business. These five areas comprise: (1) Grow High Tech, (2) Grow Green Tech, (3) More Service, (4) Grow APAC & Americas and (5) More Digitalization.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The origin of our heat exchangers business dates back to the foundation of the company Gesellschaft für Entstaubungs-Anlagen (“GEA”) by Otto Happel in 1920. Since then, we have manufactured and marketed our products in various markets, supplying customers, by means of our global sales, service and production network, in highly diverse sectors in more than 130 countries worldwide: energy; data center, chemical industries; marine applications; HVAC and refrigeration; environmental applications, as well as the food and beverage industries. In 1999, GEA was acquired by mg technologies AG (the successor of Metallgesellschaft AG) and was renamed GEA Group AG in 2005. In 2014, the GEA heat exchangers segment was acquired by Triton and formally split off from the GEA Group and, in 2015, rebranded under the name Kelvion. In 2019, the Issuer and Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l. (“Mangrove LuxCo IV”), a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Issuer, were incorporated and Mangrove LuxCo IV acquired Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l., Luxembourg, which held 100% of the shares in Kelvion Finance GmbH and all of its subsidiaries (together, the “Kelvion Group”) and in ENEXIO Management GmbH and all of its subsidiaries (together, the “ENEXIO Group”). The acquisition included a recapitalization of Galapagos Holdings S.A. and Galapagos S.A., which were the holding companies of the Kelvion Group and the ENEXIO Group at that time. Following the recapitalization, the ENEXIO business was wound down, with disposals of ENEXIO Hungary (2020), ENEXIO Service (2021), ENEXIO Water (2022) and the joint venture in India (2023). In the first quarter of 2022, the project business of the Group (Kelvion Thermal Solutions) was carved out to a separate subgroup of legal entities in connection with a potential sale. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, the sales process has been stopped. Management is now focusing on re-integration that may lead to certain advantages, e.g. via sharing of best practices.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Refrigeration Technologies (RT)
Subsubsection Text: The RT unit focuses on component business for HVAC and refrigeration applications and Data Center solutions with significant growth potential. RT supplies a wide range of standard and customized heat exchangers for cooling and removing heat from different types of data centers (hyperscale, colocation, modular etc.) using both air and liquid cooling methods. The Data Center vertical market consists of cooling solutions such as air conditioning, chilling units, economizer systems, liquid cooling systems, control systems and includes services such as consulting, installation & deployment and maintenance and support. Our product offering includes air-cooled condensers which reject heat from refrigeration systems and are often sold as part of a package of equipment with air coolers. RT’s customized air coolers are design-to-order units for industrial or OEM solutions for food processing and distribution facilities. Our product offering also includes customized radiators and dry coolers which are mainly used for power and industrial applications. Improving the energy efficiency of commercial and industrial refrigeration equipment is essential for end users looking to reduce carbon footprint and operating costs. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, RT generated 20.5% of our revenue and 19.8% of our EBITDA, respectively. As of and for the year ended December 31, 2023, the total Order Intake and Order Backlog for RT amounted to €388.4 million and €240.9 million, respectively.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Machine Cooling Systems (MCS)
Subsubsection Text: Through our MCS unit, we provide heat exchangers for power generation, power transmission, large engine applications (marine and off-highway) and green applications such as biomass, green hydrogen, or renewable energies. The business is mostly with OEM, e.g., for large engine manufacturers. However, we also engage in smaller projects, such as solar, wind or solar photovoltaic. Our product offering includes charge air coolers, which cool down combustion-air coming from the turbocharger before entering the engine. MCS’ shell and tube double safety heat exchangers assure the secure handling of safety-critical media. It further includes box coolers which are fitted in the sea chest of small and medium-sized vessels. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, MCS generated 14.3% of our revenue and 28.5% of our EBITDA, respectively. As of and for the year ended December 31, 2023, the total Order Intake and Order Backlog for MCS amounted to €209.7 million and €92.5 million, respectively. 96 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Plate Heat Exchangers (PHE)
Subsubsection Text: Through PHE, we provide a broad range of plate heat exchangers for a wide variety of applications in terms of pressure and temperature demands for a wide range of customer industries. Ranging from HVAC and refrigeration to Food & Beverage, Chemicals, Power, and Industrials. The product offering of our PHE unit includes fully welded plate heat exchangers, used to save energy in demanding high pressure and temperature applications, as well as brazed plate heat exchangers, often used for environmentally friendly heat pump applications. Our gasketed heat exchangers have are used in a variety of industries as well as for heat recovery applications. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, PHE generated 17.9% of our revenue and 11.8% of our EBITDA, respectively. As of and for the year ended December 31, 2023, the total Order Intake and Order Backlog for PHE amounted to €258.0 million and €121.6 million, respectively.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Kelvion Thermal Solutions (KTS)
Subsubsection Text: KTS’ focus is our project business for demanding applications in the Oil & Gas and Chemicals vertical markets and, similar to the RT unit, with significant growth potential in high tech data center business as well as green tech applications such as hydrogen and Carbon Capture Storage (“CCS”) solutions. The engineering expertise of KTS plays a key role in our differentiation against competitors. We benefit from a high degree of geographical diversification with sites in all key regions, including Europe, NAFTA, Latin America, China and MEA. Our product offering includes air fin coolers typically used for very large cooling requirements in different industries, _e.g., Oil & Gas and Chemicals, as well as air dryers which are used to remove humidity from an air stream in various process industries. Our focus in this product group has shifted in recent years under the High Five strategy away from traditional Oil & Gas to High Tech and Green Tech vertical markets. For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, KTS accounted for 44.6% of our revenue and 58.0% of our EBITDA, respectively. As of and for the year ended December 31, 2023, Order Intake and Order Backlog for KTS amounted to €860.1 million and €659.2 million, respectively.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our business operations are divided into four product groups: Refrigeration Technologies (“RT”), Machine Cooling Systems (“MCS”), Plate Heat Exchangers (“PHE”) and Kelvion Thermal Solutions (“KTS”). Each of our product groups primarily manages their own manufacturing and core business processes from logistics through to production and sales. However, the product groups share, to a certain extent R&D, manufacturing and testing facilities, as well as the support of various centralized Group functions, such as finance, human resources, IT and legal and compliance. Each of the product groups sells to both third-party customers and to other product groups.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: All of our product groups’ activities are complemented by a comprehensive after-sales support and services offering. We provide services both for our own products as well as for third-party products. A predictive maintenance approach to our service solutions forms one of the five strategic pillars for our operations. This enables us to tap into the megatrend of a shift towards intelligent service solutions, with recent technological developments enabling smarter and more proactive solutions and customers placing increasing value on full-service packages as a means of streamlining their operating costs. Our service offering is not a discrete business division which we run separately from our four product groups, because it is managed on a centralized and global basis across our product groups. Our network of 33 service centers worldwide offers our customers availability at their location at all times. We are continually optimizing our range of services, which include precise installation work, in-house or on-site trouble shooting, visual inspection and performance audit as part of proactive maintenance, repair and cleaning, tube replacement, provision of spare parts, and the chemical cleaning of product components in our own service workshops. We provide support and assistance to our customers throughout the entire product life cycle, with a view to avoiding unscheduled downtime due to equipment malfunctions, preventing unnecessary capex investments through equipment upgrades, replacement of parts and regular maintenance, increasing process efficiency by ensuring optimal performance of heat exchangers integrated within those processes, helping our customers manage and service the often varied brands (i.e., other than our own products) they use in their operations and ensuring the proper level of skill within our customers’ own maintenance organizations through the provision of training programs designed to ensure the competency and efficiency of their in-house maintenance personnel. Our focus is on applying our expertise and innovation to optimally ensure the quality, safety and efficiency of our products and our service packages, and thereby establish relationships of trust to secure long-term partnerships with our customers.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our products and solutions span the High Tech, Green Tech and Conventional market segments across a variety of industries, sectors and regions. Our large base of customers operates in numerous vertical markets, including Data Centers, HVAC, Power & Energy, Oil & Gas, Transportation and Food & Beverage. Our customer base comprises more than 19,000 active customers (i.e., customers that have placed an order with us in the last 24 months) and repeat orders over multiple years from more than 12,000 customers. In the year ended December 31, 2023, our ten largest customers generated approximately 46% of our Order Intake (year ended December 31, 2022: approximately 32%), with the largest customer generating approximately 25% of Order Intake in the year ended December 31, 2023 (year ended December 31, 2022: approximately 20%). Other than our largest customer, no single customer represented more than 5% of our Order Intake in the years ended December 31, 2023 and 2022. Furthermore, our largest customer generated approximately 18% of our revenue in the year ended December 31, 2023. The strength of this partnership is further demonstrated through the significant capex investment we made, supported by this customer by funding approximately €10 million of capital investments, through an earlier receipt of a higher milestone payment, which enabled us to increase capacity in one of our manufacturing plants. The primary vertical markets for RT are Data Centers, HVAC and refrigeration. The vertical markets for MCS primarily include Chemicals, Electric Power Generation and Distribution, Transportation and Heavy & Light Equipment. The end-markets for PHE primarily include HVAC and refrigeration, Food & Beverage and Electric Power Generation and distribution. The end-markets for KTS are Data Centers, Power and Oil & Gas.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We purchase goods and services locally from a few hundred suppliers across all regions in which we are active and have long-term relationships with many of our suppliers. The primary raw materials used for the manufacture of our products are steel, copper, aluminum and titanium. We typically seek to have multiple suppliers (usually two or three) for key materials and components and believe that we are not dependent on any single supplier. In the year ended December 31, 2023, our ten largest suppliers by supplier spend represented approximately 28% of our total supplier spend. Our procurement department function is embedded within our supply chain management (“SCM”) organization. It is managed centrally in line with our overarching strategy and operates at the regional/entity level, reflecting our global matrix organization. This approach is supported by a commodity management model spanning our entire SCM organization, with a view to standardizing our collaborations with suppliers while enabling us to benefit from the opportunities of a global supply base, for example through pooling purchasing volumes, expertise and technical knowledge. With the exception of the individual specific procurement contracts between individual Group companies and with their respective suppliers, we coordinate the strategic procurement for our operational product groups centrally in order to increase our purchasing power. The most important material groups are managed by a designated commodity manager and representatives of such Group companies for which the commodity is particularly relevant. The main task of this commodity team is to develop and implement commodity-specific procurement strategies. The team negotiates prices and volumes with selected suppliers in accordance with the chosen procurement strategy. In addition, local purchasing employees support our commodity teams by managing the relationship with our key suppliers. Given the increasing focus on sustainability considerations at the global level, on the one hand, and the broad array of materials we procure and the number of suppliers we have from various countries, on the other hand, our SCM function faces challenges in its efforts to harmonize systems and processes that reflect both global and local/regional ESG requirements. In order to manage these challenges, we have defined ESG requirements for our suppliers on the basis of the UN Global Compact and supplemented these with country-specific elements. The verification and validation of our suppliers’ ESG performance is conducted by means of an ESG supply chain compliance (“request for information”) questionnaire (the “ESG Supply Chain Compliance Questionnaire”) which is shared with relevant suppliers on at least an annual basis. The number of suppliers involved in the most recent ESG Supply Chain Compliance Questionnaire amounted to approximately 630 and included suppliers for both direct and indirect materials and services. This allows us to proactively address and navigate ESG concerns within our supply chain. 98 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our research and development efforts are directed towards innovative new products, applicable for Green Tech and High Tech solutions and development of new product applications. New development of products goes hand in hand with new manufacturing technologies for core processes, including Industry 4.0 and robotic technologies to respond timely to customer needs and satisfy joint development with customers. In addition, we cooperate with several universities and research institutions in various countries, including renowned partners such as Fraunhofer Institutes (e.g., Fraunhofer ISE, Fraunhofer ICT), University of Kassel, Technical University of Dresden, Nuremberg Institute of Technology Georg Simon Ohm, Helmholtz-Zentrum Dresden-Rossendorf, Research Council for Refrigeration Technology, all in Germany, Sintef Energy Research in Norway, the Stellenbosch University in South Africa, Politecnico di Milano in Italy and the French government-funded technological research organization CEA (Commissariat à l’énergie atomique et aux énergies _alternatives). These partners carry out basic and applied research for us in areas including, among others, thermodynamics_ and fluid dynamics. As of December 31, 2023, we had more than 100 employees dedicated to R&D and 19 engineering centers around the world. For the year ended December 31, 2023, research and development expenses amounted to €16.5 million (€14.0 million in the year ended December 31, 2022). For the twelve months ended March 31, 2024, research and development expenses amounted to €17.4 million.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We apply for patents in appropriate jurisdictions to protect our intellectual property, which is often the result of our R&D activities. We currently have patents and pending patent applications in Germany and other countries. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, we have more than 100 patents, trademarks and design rights registered in more than 40 jurisdictions. While these patents and patent applications are important to the business, we do not believe any individual patent is critical to our overall business. We also protect certain confidential information and know-how as trade secrets. Furthermore, we rely on certain trademarks for our business, such as the Kelvion logo and trademark.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Tender Process and Project Controlling
Subsubsection Text: We follow a standardized tender evaluation process through an internal tender review and approval system supported by a digital tender review and approval system. Our tender review and approval system is built to support an upfront assessment of risks and commercial conditions that need to be fulfilled before we submit a binding offer, including an in-depth analysis to understand the specific technical requirements of potential clients. Depending on the expected contract value, different approval levels are required, with significant contracts requiring the approval of our executive management. While we are participating in tenders, our strategy is to establish ourselves as a long-term solutions provider being able to meet customer requirements not only on a technology level, but also in terms of scale and capacity. In order to mitigate the risk of fluctuations in commodity and material process, we aim to freeze the most relevant material purchases by procurement binding offers prior to providing a quote to the customer. In addition, in recent years we have started to successfully include material price escalation clauses in contracts with our customers in order to mitigate adverse price fluctuations. In addition, we conduct weekly reviews to monitor our performance across our projects. 99 -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our regional organizational setup includes front-end sales teams in order to drive our international expansion. Front-end sales teams are backed by global solutions engineering (application engineering) teams specializing in defined industrial markets and providing support and application expertise with a strong focus on key accounts and industries. This setup allows us to benefit from the advantages of having both a local presence in the markets in which we are active, such as close contact with our customers and knowledge of local restrictions and technical specifications, and the centralized pooling of specific market segment and application know-how. It also enables the front-end Sales teams to expand our product offering as needed to address regional “white spots” (i.e., markets in which we do not yet have a sufficient presence). As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, we have approximately 650 employees working in sales related functions. Our Global Solutions Engineering teams, with their industry-specific focus, serve to continuously optimize business processes such as key account coordination, technical process development and project support, thereby acting as a bridge between the product groups and our sales teams. Our RT, MCS, PHE and KTS are responsible for manufacturing and product line management (for example, charge air coolers and radiators) and for implementing the reorganization of the manufacturing footprint through Group oversight, as well as targeting cost and lead time reductions through the consolidation, standardization and modularization of our numerous product lines. In close cooperation with the Front-End Sales and Global Solutions Engineering teams, the product areas are also driving the development of innovative products to address future market demand.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: ESG considerations are a key aspect of our corporate strategy aimed at securing our future as a strong and resilient provider of long-term value to our customers and business partners, and embodied by our “R3” approach: We aim to

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: respect all employees,** **reduce unsustainable usage of resources and** **report transparently to our business partners and
Subsubsection Title: Environment
Subsubsection Text: We attach great importance to environmental protection, climate change and energy efficiency along our entire value and production chain – from our procurement of raw materials and our product development endeavors through our internal manufacturing processes to our end products and servicing. With our waste reduction program and continuous reduction of our CO2 footprint through innovation and the use of smart technologies, we intend to meet our customer expectations of high quality and resource-efficient production and supply chain management, and to be carbon neutral by 2040. In line with our strategy, we could achieve for 2023 an increase in the consumption of energy from renewable sources, a reduction in our direct (Scope 1) greenhouse gas (“GHG”) emissions and a reduction in the disposal of both hazardous and non-hazardous waste. _CO2 Footprint_ Our environmental focus is also demonstrated by our use of green energy and our energy-saving endeavors at our plants: Since our production plant in Wuhu (China) was established in 1995, it has bundled our core competences – robust production capabilities, extensive service offerings and deep technical expertise, backed up by the innovative strength of our local R&D departments – to supply heat exchanger solutions to customers around the globe. The first solar panels were installed in Wuhu in 2022 and the entire roof of the production facility is equipped with solar panels, substantially reducing our CO2 emissions with more than 4.0 MW of green electricity generated. We believe that this initiative constitutes a strong first step towards achieving our goal of 100% usage of green energy. Our production site in Sint Maartensdijk, the Netherlands, halved its energy consumption, reducing CO2 emissions from approximately 1,000 tons per year to approximately 500 tons per year, between 2021 and 2023. This was primarily attributable to significantly lower electricity usage achieved through the implementation of a range of energy-saving measures, such as reduction of the start-up time of machines prior to working hours, checks to ensure that machines are not automatically switched on by timers or software at the weekends, remote measurement of individual appliances and heating and ongoing campaigns to raise awareness among employees of energy-saving behavior among all colleagues, including regular communication and postings on information displays, as well as an ideas box. As a next step, we are expanding our focus to include waste heat recovery: In addition to implementing internal measures in this regard, we are also collaborating with a network of local companies, as well as the city administration, to explore and implement further ideas for more sustainable production. We are working with an industrial company on a project to reduce our CO2 emissions by recovering waste heat for use in heating the production halls for our air cooler units. While our low-temperature factory heating system is already sustainable, the use of waste heat from neighboring facilities opportunistically will reduce our natural gas requirements and thereby enable us to reduce our carbon footprint.

Subsection Title: respect all employees,** **reduce unsustainable usage of resources and** **report transparently to our business partners and
Subsubsection Title: Social
Subsubsection Text: We believe that we set high standards for sustainable and environmentally conscious behavior, not only for ourselves but also for our suppliers. As a matter of principle, we have a policy not to buy any materials that are associated with the exploitation of people or with child labor, and also expect our business customers to observe these standards. We are committed to providing a safe, healthy and also inspiring working environment with fair and respectful working conditions for all members of our workforce. We continue to pursue our zero-accident strategy to eliminate the number of accidents and ensure safe conditions and practices at our facilities. We fundamentally uphold diversity, equity and inclusion (“DEI”) principles in all areas of our global operations and condemn discrimination of all kinds. These core principles are a fixed and integral part of our HR policy, and are reflected in numerous corresponding programs worldwide, such as health and safety at work initiatives and our Whistleblower Policy. 100 ----- _Safety_ We develop innovative, high-quality products and processes for our customers, and product safety is a top priority in our business operations. Our Safety Topic of the Month (“STM”) initiative relates to a monthly publication aimed at raising awareness among our workforce of one of a broad range of safety topics, which are of particular relevance for the employees at our production and service facilities. The STM material is published on our intranet and on blackboards on every production site worldwide. Each STM focuses on a specific risk and provides clear instructions for the action to be taken to reduce said risk. In addition, a safety and risk minimization checklist is made available to those responsible for occupational health and safety matters on site. As part of our Health, Safety & Environment (“HSE”) program, we have defined a global baseline with a view to improving health and safety management at all of our production sites. This involves the completion of a self-assessment questionnaire for each of our facilities based on seven categories, such as targets, qualifications and risk assessment, with 10-15 questions each. On the basis of the scores for 2023, the following steps were identified for 2024: (i) Connection of lower scoring sites with the high scoring sites for the categories in question; (ii) setting up internal calls for the discussion of the specific issues; and (iii) preparation of a cross-check audits, pursuant to which the HSE Manager for one production facility will conduct an audit of another production facility. This should help cross learning, help create standardization and drive performance improvement. The implementation of the steps identified each year for the following year ensures continual improvements in the scores achieved by our facilities and promotes the maintenance of a robust health and safety culture globally: It encourages our employees to take responsibility for their own safety and that of their colleagues, to strive to attain and follow up on HSE goals and targets, and to complete HSE qualifications and training (for staff and supervisors). It also facilitates the identification of (occupational) HSE risks, and encourages the carrying out of regular inspections by those responsible for health & safety at our production sites and also investigations into near misses and actual accidents, including root cause analyses and risk assessment reviews. We have adopted a similar approach in the areas of quality and environment. _Diversity, Equity & Inclusion (DEI)_ DEI are core values within our organization. It is our goal to have a diverse and talented workforce that also reflects the diversity of our stakeholders and business partners. We are committed to maintaining a diverse, equal and inclusive corporate culture, continually implementing corresponding improvements in all of our human resources processes to provide a working environment which is free of prejudice and in which everyone is treated equally, and to attract and retain top talent and foster greater innovation, creativity and, at the same time, productivity. Our DEI policy sets out our aims and commitments in this area and several initiatives are underway to increase understanding and awareness within our organization: Further examination of our existing human resources processes, in particular recruitment and talent management, to attract more women and individuals from diverse backgrounds to our company, mentoring and “bonding” programs for our female employees to foster networking activity and support their professional development, for example our K°Women’s Network and a new women-focused mentoring program launched in February 2024, and DEI training for employees and management.

Subsubsection Title: Governance
Subsubsection Text: Our leadership team has established a global compliance organization, a compliance group function and local subfunctions, which are supported by regional compliance officers. The fundamental principles of compliance management are set out in our central compliance organization directive. Our Group code of conduct, which applies to all of our employees worldwide, provides guidance on the most relevant compliance topics, such as environment and safety, general business conduct, antitrust and competition, anti-fraud and anti-bribery, data protection and working conditions. It describes the values, principles and modes of action which guide the entrepreneurial conduct of our enterprise, including internal policies and guidelines and create a work environment characterized by integrity, respect and fair and responsible conduct.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: respect all employees,** **reduce unsustainable usage of resources and** **report transparently to our business partners and
Subsubsection Text: stakeholders. As part of our efforts to combat climate change, we aim to make our operations climate neutral by 2040. By way of a first step, we have aligned our operations and our ESG strategy, initiatives and annual targets with the 17 Sustainability Development Goals of the United Nations, and published our first ESG report in 2023. The attainment of our CO2 reduction targets and those of our customers calls for innovation and smart technologies – all the more reason for us to continue to develop and promote our broad range of innovative heat exchange technologies that facilitate the conduct of sustainable operations in various markets around the world. As an internationally active company, we are obligated to adhere to internationally accepted conventions of a social, political and legal nature. Responsible business practices are second nature to us, and we strive to lead by example when it comes to our social responsibility towards our employees and society as a whole. Our ESG strategy aims to create a responsible company culture from a diversity, equity and inclusion (“DEI”) perspective at all company levels, and we uphold human rights, fair working conditions, environmental protection and integrity, including anti-corruption efforts.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: As of December 31, 2023, the total number of our employees amounted to 5,159 full-time equivalents (FTEs), excluding vocational trainees and inactive employment contracts (December 31, 2022; 4,817). We believe that our relationships with our employees are generally good. We have not suffered any material work stoppages or strikes in recent years. Certain of our employees are represented by works councils. Works councils have various information, consultation and co-determination rights. For example, they must be notified in advance of any employee layoffs, must consent to hirings and relocations of employees and are granted co-determination rights in social matters, such as work schedules and rules of conduct. In addition, we are subject to collective bargaining agreements with employees in various countries, including Germany, France, Spain and the Netherlands. 101 ----- _Pension Liabilities_ Our employees are offered various benefit options, primarily in the form of defined benefit and defined contribution pension plans. The defined benefit pension plan obligations mainly exist in Germany. New employees are generally only granted benefits that are partly funded by employee contributions. As part of the general benefits provided, all employees have the opportunity to voluntarily defer part of their compensation. Under this arrangement, an agreed amount of their salary plus an employer contribution of up to 100% of the deferred amount is converted into a pension benefit. A corresponding collective bargaining agreement was entered by our predecessors in 2002 and revised in 2008. The new pension plan beginning in January 2019 does not only provide for pension payments, but also capital payments and installment payments. In addition to the currently open benefit schemes, there are a number of historical pension schemes. These schemes are generally closed to new employees but are maintained unchanged for employees who were members at the time the benefit scheme was closed. As of December 31, 2023, the net carrying amount of defined benefit obligations amounted to €25,416 thousand (as of December 31, 2022: €23,439 thousand). As of the same date, the net carrying amount of unfunded obligations amounted to €24,017 thousand (as of December 31, 2022: €22,137 thousand). For additional information on our employee benefit obligations, see Note 5.4 of the 2023 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We maintain insurance policies for general and product liability, property damage and business interruption, directors’ and officers’ and other insurance with coverage which we consider to be consistent with industry practice. We consider our insurance coverage to be adequate both in terms of the nature of the risks covered and the amounts insured for our business activities. However, our insurance coverage does not cover all potential risks associated with our business or for which we may otherwise be liable. Consequently, we cannot guarantee that we will not suffer a loss or losses which are not covered by our insurance policies or which may be in excess of the amount of the insurance coverage we maintain. See “Risk Factors—Legal, Taxation and Environmental Risks—Our insurance coverage could prove to be inadequate.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: From time to time, we are involved in legal proceedings arising in the normal course of our business. We do not expect that any of these proceedings, either individually or in the aggregate, will result in a material adverse effect on our consolidated financial condition or results of operations. In addition, in connection with the financial restructuring and recapitalization of Galapagos Holding S.A. and Galapagos S.A. in 2019, a number of claims were filed against our entities in various jurisdictions. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, such claims either have been dismissed or decided in our favor in final and unappealable judgements or have been irrevocably withdrawn. On October 9, 2019, Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l. acquired the shares in Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. (together with its subsidiaries, the “Galapagos BidCo Group”). Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l., was the shareholder of Kelvion Finance GmbH, (together with its subsidiaries, the “Kelvion Group”) and in ENEXIO Management GmbH (together with its subsidiaries, the “ENEXIO Group”) at the acquisition date. The acquisition was consummated by way of a distressed disposal under an English law governed intercreditor agreement dated May 14, 2014 (the “2014 Intercreditor Agreement”) in connection with the balance sheet restructuring transaction of Galapagos S.A. and Galapagos Holding S.A., the former direct and indirect shareholders of Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l., which resulted in a recapitalization of the operating business of the Galapagos BidCo Group, a deleveraging of the Galapagos BidCo Group’s balance sheet and access to new debt facilities and instruments with longer tenors (the “Recapitalization”). In connection with the Recapitalization, the Issuer in particular issued the Existing Notes. In connection with the Recapitalization, a holder of senior unsecured notes issued by Galapagos Holdings S.A. in 2014 (the “2014 Senior Unsecured Notes”), which had been impaired as part of the Recapitalization, filed claims against Galapagos Holdings S.A., Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. and certain Group entities in the courts of the State of New York. The relevant holder of the 2014 Senior Unsecured Notes asserted, among other things, that the sale of the Galapagos BidCo Group violated the terms of the indenture governing the 2014 Senior Unsecured Notes and the 2014 Intercreditor Agreement and that the release of certain guarantees under the 2014 Senior Unsecured Notes were invalid. In response, Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l., among other things, sought certain declaratory judgments in the English courts (which are the competent courts for the interpretation of the 2014 Intercreditor Agreement), confirming that the sale of the shares in Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. to Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l. complied with the terms of the 2014 Intercreditor Agreement. In July 2023, the competent English courts granted the declaratory judgments sought by Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. Following this decision, the relevant holder of the 2014 Senior Unsecured Notes agreed to a dismissal of the claims filed in the courts of the State of New York and the relevant proceedings are closed as of the date of this Offering Memorandum. Furthermore, insolvency proceedings over Galapagos S.A. were opened in 2019 and are pending in Düsseldorf, Germany and London, United Kingdom in connection with the Recapitalization. The German insolvency administrator filed a number of claims before German and Luxembourg courts seeking to prevent and/or unwind the transfer of the shares in Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. to Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l. on the basis that such transfer constituted a voidable action and was fraudulent. The German clawback proceedings were finally dismissed in June 2023 and the relevant proceedings are closed. In January 2024, the German insolvency administrator also withdrew the corresponding proceedings in Luxembourg and the case is closed as of the date of this Offering Memorandum. For additional information, see Notes 1.2, 8.3 and 11 of the 2023 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements. 103 -----

Subsubsection Text: _The following is a discussion of our results of operations and financial condition as of and for the years ended December 31, 2021, 2022 and 2023 and the three months periods ended March 31, 2023 and 2024. The financial information has been taken or derived from the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements and the Unaudited Condensed Consolidated Interim Financial Statements, including the notes thereto, included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.
