In particular, certain financial information in the consolidated statement of financial position as of January 1, 2022 and December 31, 2022 were corrected and restated in the 2023 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements by correcting and restating the relevant financial information as of January 1, 2022 and December 31, 2022. The correction was due to the Issuer underestimating a deferred tax liability related to the Existing Notes. For additional information, see Note 9.10 of the 2023 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements. Furthermore, financial information presented in this Offering Memorandum as of and for the year ended December 31, 2021 is taken from the comparative prior year figures included in the 2022 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements or, in the case of the consolidated statement of financial position data affected by the correction of errors referred corrected (as explained above), from the restated data as of January 1, 2022 presented included in the 2023 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements. The financial information marked as “audited” in tables in this Offering Memorandum is taken from the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements. Financial information marked as “unaudited” in tables in this Offering Memorandum is not taken from the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements and was either taken from the Unaudited Condensed Consolidated Interim Financial Statements or our internal accounting or reporting systems or is based on calculations of figures of the above-mentioned sources. The following information should be read in conjunction with the information contained in “Presentation of Financial and Other Information,” “Use of Proceeds,” “Capitalization,” and the Consolidated Financial Statements, including the notes thereto, included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. In addition, some of the information contained in this discussion contain forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. You should read “Forward-Looking Statements” for a discussion of the risks related to those statements. You should also read “Business” and “Risk Factors” for more information regarding certain factors that may adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition. Our historical results do not necessarily indicate our results of operations for any future period._

Subsubsection Title: Air Emissions
Subsubsection Text: We are required to comply with various environmental laws and regulations. In particular, our operations are subject to laws and regulations designed to limit emissions. In Germany, the construction and operation of production sites requires active permits under the Federal Emissions Protection Act (Bundes-Immissionsschutzgesetz, the “BimSchG”), which encompasses various other licenses, authorizations and approvals necessary for the construction and operation of facilities pursuant to other laws. The permits typically provide for a variety of auxiliary conditions aimed at protection of other interests, such as neighbors and the environment. As part of our obligations under the BImSchG and supplementing laws, regulations and standards, we are required to observe the emission standards set under the Technical Instructions on Air Quality Control (Technische Anleitung Luft – the “TA Luft”), a revised version of which entered into force on December 1, 2021. In general, to the extent the respective facility operated in compliance with its legally definitive permits and applicable laws and regulations, the operation of the facility can generally not be challenged or contested by third parties. However, proportionate measures to mitigate any negative impact of a facility on the environment or neighbors may be required; including, _e.g., adherence to stricter emissions thresholds. For instance, permits may be amended and administrative orders under the BimSchG may impose certain limitations (e.g., stricter requirements with regard to permissible emissions or the use of the relevant facilities), with which we have to comply. To the extent certain measures based on state-of-the-art technology are impossible or economically disproportionate to implement in light of extraordinary costs, the regulator may grant certain privileges to the relevant facility (e.g., less strict emission thresholds than expected with state-of-the-art technology). To the extent new legal standards are introduced, permits are dynamic and will, in general, be adjusted so they meet the relevant new standards. Non-compliance of the operator with applicable permits, other administrative decisions, laws, regulations or standards may also lead to a (temporary) restriction or, in severe cases, a prohibition of further operation. The competent authority may also impose administrative fines or, in exceptional cases, even ask for removal of the facility. Furthermore, non-compliance may result in additional administrative, civil or even criminal liability as well as reputational damage, depending on the individual case.

Subsubsection Title: Carbon Emissions
Subsubsection Text: The EU ETS imposes an EU-wide emissions cap applying to the total amount of greenhouse gas emissions that can be emitted by in-scope operations and provides for the trade with allowances for such emissions for certain sectors and companies. The EU ETS was implemented in Germany with the German Greenhouse Gas Emission Trading Act (Treibhausgas-Emissionshandelsgesetz, the “TEHG”). The provisions of the German Greenhouse Gas Emission Trading Act provide that the facility operators subject to emissions trading are obliged to obtain a license to emit greenhouse gases, to comply with a cap on emission allowances allocated to them and to maintain a monitoring process to determine and documents their emissions. For newer facilities, this permit is typically integrated into the BImSchG permit. The regulations also provide for the possibility of trading surplus allowances on the open market. The allowances are traded in certain trading periods, which requires certain energy and industry sectors to comply with the applicable greenhouse gas emissions caps. Overall, only a limited number of allowances—determined in advance for the trading period—are available to emission sources, subject to the EU ETS. Participation in this system has been mandatory since 2005 for all industries with high energy consumption levels. The overall availability of emission allowances allocated free of charge has been constantly reduced over the different trading periods. Under the revised EU ETS, the EU-wide quantity of emission allowances allocated annually is reduced by a linear factor of 4.3% per year from 2024 compared to the average annual total quantity of emission allowances 104 ----- issued in the EU between 2008 and 2012 (which equals an annual reduction of 87,924,231 allowances to be issued in the EU) and of 4.4% as from 2028 (or 89,968,981 per year). To achieve the target of cutting EU emissions by at least 55% compared to 1990 by 2030 and to achieve climate neutrality within the EU by 2050, a further reduction of 90 million allowances in 2024 and further 27 million allowances in 2026 will be made in accordance with Regulation (EU) No 2021/1119 establishing the framework for achieving climate neutrality (the “European Climate Law”). Based on this reduction path, the total quantity of newly issued allowances will be zero in 2040. Until then, the transitional free allocation of allowances will continue on a reduced rate. On June 5, 2023, the Directive 2023/959/EU amending the Emissions Trading Directive 2003/87/EC (the “Emissions Trading Directive”) entered into force. According to the amended version of the Emissions Trading Directive, the free allocation will be reduced to 0% until 2030 for most sectors, except for district heating, which will continue to receive a free allocation of 30%. As a result, affected companies whose emissions exceed their emission allowances will have to purchase a considerable and steadily increasing proportion of increasingly pricy emission allowances in auctions, which may result in substantial additional cost for such companies. A further exemption is available for certain energy-intensive industries which are exposed to a significant risk of relocation of plants to countries with less stringent climate protection laws (“Carbon Leakage”). Since 2010, the European Commission determines every five years which industries are threatened by Carbon Leakage. The designated industries are allocated 100% emission allowances free of charge for the period until 2030. However, the allocation of 100% does not necessarily mean that the allocation is in line with the demand. The product benchmarks, which determine the amount of allowances allocated free of charge, are based on the average performance of the 10% most efficient facilities in a sector or subsector in the Union and will decline by 0.3 to 2.5% per year, calculated from the year 2008, taking into account expected emission reductions due to technological progress. Some of the Carbon Leakage industry sectors may apply for financial compensation for the increase of electricity costs due to the costs of EU ETS allowances being passed on to electricity prices. The compensation is not enforceable and is granted from funds provided in the federal budget for that purpose for the relevant year.

Subsubsection Title: Chemicals Legislation and Regulations
Subsubsection Text: We use a number of chemicals and hazardous substances in our production processes and are therefore subject to Regulation (EC) No 1907/2006 concerning the Registration, Evaluation, Authorisation and Restriction of Chemicals, as amended from time to time (“REACH”). REACH aims to ensure a high level of protection of human health and the environment, including the promotion of alternative methods for assessment of hazards of substances, as well as free movement of substances on the internal market while promoting competitiveness and innovation. REACH standardizes chemicals legislation within Europe, placing greater responsibility on industry participants – encompassing manufacturers, importers, downstream users and distributors – making them responsible for the safety of the substances, mixtures and articles placed on the market of the European Economic Area (the “EEA”) for industrial, professional and consumer use. REACH sets out general rules for the marketing of substances, mixtures and articles in the EEA, and imposes various obligations which vary according to the hazardous properties of the substances, their form, quantity and concentration, as well as the role of the actors in the supply chain. Applicable obligations may include, e.g., the duty to register substances, notify substances in articles to the European Chemicals Agency (the “ECHA”), duty to communicate information in the supply chain and down to the customers, duty to comply with restrictions and/or authorization requirements. In addition, we are subject to the provisions of the German Chemicals Act (Gesetz zum Schutz vor gefährlichen _Stoffen—Chemikaliengesetz, the “ChemG”) and related ordinances (Rechtsverordnungen), most notably the Hazardous_ Substances Regulation (Gefahrstoffverordnung). The ChemG and supplementing regulations are intended to minimize the risks from chemicals for humans and the environment. Based on the ChemG and related regulations, the competent authorities have, among other things, the authority to require that certain materials or chemicals (i) may either not be produced, marketed or used at all, (ii) may only be produced, marketed or used in a certain manner or for specific purposes, (iii) may only be used under certain circumstances or (iv) may only be distributed to certain persons. Regarding the transportation of dangerous goods at the international level the European Agreement concerning the International Carriage of Dangerous Goods by Road as of September 30, 1957 (Accord européen relative au transport _international des marchandises Dangereuses par Route, the “ADR”) as amended on January 1, 2023 and implemented_ into German law through the Dangerous Goods Regulation for Road, Rail and Inland Navigation (Gefahrgutverordnung _Straße, Eisenbahn und Binnenschifffahrt) includes provisions applicable to the carriage of dangerous goods on roads._ Pursuant to the ADR, dangerous goods, as a general rule, may be carried internationally in road vehicles subject to compliance with a number of conditions, such as packaging and labeling requirements. Specific dangerous goods (e.g., goods which are poisonous and explosive at the same time) are excluded from carriage on the road.

Subsubsection Title: Soil Contamination
Subsubsection Text: Pursuant to the German Federal Soil Protection Act _(Bundes-Bodenschutzgesetz, the “BBodSchG”), the responsibility for residual pollution and harmful changes to the soil lies with the party who caused a harmful soil change or a contaminated site (polluter), its universal successor, the relevant property owner, the occupant of the relevant real property and, if the title was transferred after March 1, 1999, the previous owner of the property, if they knew or must have 105 ----- known about the contamination. Under the BBodSchG, liability is not based on culpability, meaning that any of the abovementioned parties alone or together may be held liable for a contamination irrespective of any negligence or intent on their part. Determining the party to be held liable for contamination-related measures lies in the discretion of the competent authority. There is no predetermined statutory order in which the aforementioned parties can be required by the competent authority to carry out remediation measures. When exercising its discretion, the competent authority takes into account the effectiveness of remediation as a prevailing factor. Thus, the current owner of the contaminated property will generally be held primarily liable, as he is usually in the best position to carry out the necessary remediation work. However, the party that carried out the remediation work may be able to claim compensation from the other responsible parties irrespective of which party is held liable by the competent local authority. Unless otherwise agreed upon, the obligation to provide compensation under the BbodSchG, as well as the extent of such compensation, depends on the degree to which the hazard or damage was primarily attributable to one party or the other. Liability is not based on culpability. Therefore, the BbodSchG does not require the competent authority to prove negligence or intent on the part of the liable parties. According to the BbodSchG the competent authority may require risk inspections, investigations, remedial measures, including clean-up or containment, and other measures necessary for the protection of the soil and the prevention of residual contamination or other harmful soil changes and related (ground)water contamination. Regarding other environmental media, _e.g., (ground)water or protected natural resources, other laws, such as, _inter alia, the Federal Water Management Act (Wasserhaushaltsgesetz, the “WHG”) and the Environmental Damage Act_ (Umweltschadensgesetz, the “UschadG”) provide for further contamination-related liability of, in particular, polluters and facility operators.

Our heat exchange products are subject to certain product regulations in the countries where they are placed on the market. In the EU, product regulations such as Regulation (EU) No 2023/1230 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 14 June 2023 (the “EU Machinery Regulation”) and Directive 2014/68/EU (the “EU Pressure Equipment

Subsection Title: Directive”), which provides for strict obligations with regard to product traceability, are relevant for our product portfolio.
Subsubsection Text: These Directives provide the regulatory basis for the harmonization of the essential health and safety requirements for machinery and pressure equipment at EU level. As a manufacturer of heat exchangers, we must implement a conformity assessment procedure to ensure compliance with those requirements, issue a declaration of conformity and affix the CE marketing on the products. The EU Pressure Equipment Directive was implemented into German law by the Product Safety Act (Produktsicherheitsgesetz, the “ProdSG”), which regulates the safety requirements for products brought to the German market to ensure they do not present a risk to health and safety when properly installed, maintained, and used as intended. Further, Commission Regulation (EU) No 206/2012 on eco-design requirements for air conditioners and comfort fans and Commission Regulation (EU) No 327/2011 of March 30, 2011 with regard to eco-design requirements for fans driven by motors with an electric input power between 125 W and 500 kW apply for our products. As we are distributors of these products our customers expect compliance with eco-design requirements as with any other applicable regulation. Under these Regulations related to eco-design, air conditioners must, _e.g., comply with requirements related to energy efficiency and sound power. As we manufacture and distribute heat exchangers containing substances depleting the ozone layer we must further comply with the respective legislation. In the EU, for instance, Regulation (EU) 2024/590 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 7 February 2024, provides for a gradual phase out of hydro-chloro-fluor-carbons (HCFC), which are, inter alia, used in air conditioning equipment. In addition, the use of certain fluorinated greenhouse gases in air conditioning systems of motor vehicles is gradually prohibited through Directive 2006/40/EC of May 17, 2006. Similar restrictions may apply outside the EU in the United States implementing the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer of September 16, 1987, as amended. Compliance with product regulations is enforced by the authorities on a random sample basis, whistleblowing or notifications of competitors. The authorities may investigate the facts and issue orders, in a worst case scenario sales bans, corrective actions and product recalls.

Marketing our products we are subject to provisions on product liability and may, therefore, be held liable in cases of damage caused by a defective product manufactured by us. In the EU, for example, Directive 85/374/EEC of July 25, 1985, as amended by Directive 1999/34/EC of May 10, 1999 (the “Product Liability Directive”) applies to movables which have been industrially produced. It establishes the principle of objective liability (liability without fault of the producer) in cases of damage caused by a defective product. The Directive applies to damage caused by death or by personal injuries and damage to an item of property intended for private use or consumption, with a lower threshold of €500. The Product Liability Directive imposes no financial cap on a producer’s liability, yet it allows EU member states to cap a producer’s liability for damages from death or personal injury caused by identical items with the same defect at no less 106 ----- than €70 million. Furthermore, the Product Liability Directive does not bar EU member states from offering injured parties more comprehensive or extra rights under contractual or non-contractual liability grounds. In September 2022, the European Commission published a draft proposal to update the Product Liability Directive. This revision aims to modernize the regulations governing product liability for the digital era, create equal conditions for manufacturers inside and outside the EU, and enhance consumer protection by easing the proof required in liability claims. After preliminary discussions on this proposal, a compromised draft was agreed upon on January 24, 2024. The European Parliament officially approved the updated Product Liability Directive in March 2024. Its formal ratification by the European Council, announcement in the Official Journal of the European Union, and subsequent implementation are anticipated in the first half of 2024. Once in effect, member states will have 24 months to incorporate the revised directive into their national laws. However, the new Product Liability Directive does not allow any derogations in order to achieve a higher or lower level of protection. In Germany, the Product Liability Directive has been transposed into national law through the enactment of the Product Liability Act (Produkthaftungsgesetz, the “ProdHaftG”).

According to national and international provisions, we are in most jurisdictions obliged to take measures related to health and safety at work. Knowledge of hazardous substances and associated health and safety risks are dynamic and develop over time as the related standards do. In this context, we must, for example, perform risk assessments, maintain registers of hazardous substances and issue working instructions to ensure the safe handling of hazardous substances and manufacturing equipment by our employees. In general, compliance with employment safety regulations is subject to regulatory supervision. We ensure compliance with the applicable legal requirements to protect health and safety for humans involved in our operations. We seek to apply uniform health and safety standards across our business. We are, in particular, subject to the Workers Protection Act (Arbeitsschutzgesetz, the “ArbSchG”) and the German Hazardous Substances Regulation (Gefahrstoffverordnung, the “GefStoffV”). The latter in particular ensures the safe handling and use of hazardous substances during production, and proper classification and labeling of products, and provides comprehensive safety information to users and workers involved in maintenance and disposal activities.

We are subject to laws across several jurisdictions regarding privacy and protection of personal data. Laws and regulations related to data protection, privacy, cyber-security and other laws and regulations can be very stringent and vary from jurisdiction to jurisdiction. These laws govern how companies collect, process, and share personal data, grant rights to data subjects, and require that companies implement specific information security controls to protect certain types of information. In the European Union and the EEA, the principles on the legitimate processing of personal data are laid down in the GDPR as well as national legislation supplementing the GDPR (such as the German Federal Data Protection Act (Bundesdatenschutzgesetz, the “BDSG”). Personal data is defined broadly and includes any information related to an identified or identifiable natural person (data subject). The GDPR implements stringent requirements obligations and restrictions for, among other things, the collection, storage, transfer and other processing of personal data, in particular (without limitation) for lawful processing, transparency, data subject rights, international data transfers, storage limitation, data mapping and accountability, processor (service provider) obligations, joint controllership, notification of data breaches and the requirement to designate a data protection officer. The collection of personal data is confined strictly to specified, explicit and legitimate purposes, and the processing of this data must be in alignment with these purposes. Furthermore, personal data must be adequate, relevant, and limited to the purposes for which it is processed (principle of data minimization). The processing must be carried out in a way that guarantees transparency, fairness, and appropriate security of the personal data. As a consequence, the GDPR requires us to inform data subjects regarding, among others, the manner in which their personal data is collected, utilized, and processed, the legal justification for its processing, and the entities with which their personal data is shared. In addition, the GDPR and local data protection rules provide strict requirements on the processing of sensitive personal data (so-called special categories of personal data), like genetic and health data of individuals, including on the implementation of appropriate technical and organizational measures to ensure security of this data. Accordingly, certain cyber-security requirements must be fulfilled to ensure that data is processed and stored safely. We are required to implement appropriate technical and organizational measures to ensure a level of security appropriate to the organization’s processing requirements and risk. Organizations must notify the relevant supervisory authority about data breaches within certain time limits and, in some instances, provide notification to data subjects. 107 ----- In general, the transfer of personal data to third counties or international organizations outside the EU/EEA is permitted only when certain steps are taken to ensure an adequate level of protection. In relation to data transfers from the EU/EEA to the United States, the European Commission adopted its adequacy decision for the EU-US Privacy Shield in July 2023 to facilitate EU-US data transfers. The GDPR requirements apply not only to third-party transactions, but also to transfers of information between us and our subsidiaries, including employee information. The GDPR and the BDSG introduced substantial sanctions for non-compliance and, depending on the nature of the infringed provision, may consist of civil liabilities, cease-and-desist orders from competitors, criminal sanctions and/or administrative fines, and adverse publicity and reputational damages. Administrative fines can amount to EUR 20 million or up to 4% of the total worldwide annual sales of the preceding year, whichever is higher, for each violation. Even the perception of privacy concerns, whether valid or not, may harm our reputation. The occurrence of any of these risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. We are subject to evolving EU and national privacy laws on the use of cookies, tracking technologies and emarketing practices. In the EU, informed consent is required for the placement of certain cookies that are not technically essential for use or similar tracking technologies on an individual’s device and for direct electronic marketing. Consent is tightly defined and includes a prohibition on pre-checked consents and a requirement to obtain separate consents for each type of cookie or similar technology. In Germany, the use of internet tracking technologies is regulated in the German Telecommunications Digital Services Data Protection Act (Telekommunikation-Digitale-Dienste-Datenschutz-Gesetz, the “TDDDG”) which implements Directive 2002/58/EC (the “ePrivacy Directive”) and applies in addition to the requirements under the GDPR. Furthermore, based on the EU and German Data and Digital Strategies, there are several initiatives pending and new laws passed aimed at establishing a single, uniform digital European market with robust cyber-security requirements, including the Digital Services Act, the Data Act, the Directive EU 2022/2557 on the resilience of critical entities (so-called NIS2 Directive), and the Cyber Resilience Act. In addition, the Artificial Intelligence Act that was approved by the Council on May 21, 2024.

Subsection Title: German Supply Chain Due Diligence Act
Subsubsection Text: The German Supply Chain Due Diligence Act (Lieferkettensorgfaltspflichtengesetz, the “LkSG”) requires companies to manage certain human rights and environmental risks in their (global) supply chains by means of a cascade of risk management measures, including, e.g., risk assessment, preventive and remediation measures as well as maintaining a grievance mechanism/complaints procedure and reporting to the competent authority. Since January 2024, the LkSG obligates companies with a workforce of, in principle, at least 1,000 employees in Germany that have their headquarters, main administration, administrative headquarters, legal domicile, or a branch in Germany to ensure that the canon of protected human rights and environmental obligations set out in the law are not infringed and that corresponding risks are minimized and mitigated, both in their own business areas and in their wider supply chain. The protected legal positions under the LkSG include, in particular, protection from child and forced labor, slavery, disregard of occupational safety obligations and freedom of association, protection from discrimination and withholding of adequate wages, protection from certain environmental pollutions, as well as land expropriation, torture and cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment. Companies must also consider environmental obligations from a set of three internationally recognized agreements, namely the Minamata Convention, the Stockholm Convention on Persistent Organic Pollutants, and the Basel Convention. The specific content of the statutorily required systemic and dynamic corporate risk management depends on a variety of factors, such as the nature and scope of the business (including the risks of the specific industry and business and the type of products), as well as the company’s ability to influence the immediate cause. All supply chain due diligence risk management is required to be on-going, as it should be carried out and/or its effectiveness reviewed annually as well as on an ad hoc basis if the in-scope company has reason to expect a significantly changed or significantly expanded risk situation in the supply chain, e.g., due to the introduction of new products, projects or new business fields, or information received through the complaints procedure/grievance mechanism. Enforcement rests with a federal authority, the BAFA, and may be initiated ex officio or by individual application of an affected party. Should enterprises not adhere to their legal responsibilities, they could face administrative penalties. These penalties can reach up to 2% of the enterprise’s yearly worldwide turnover. The system of fines based on revenue is specifically applicable to enterprises generating over €400 million in annual revenue. Additionally, enterprises might be disqualified from receiving public contracts if they are subjected to an administrative fine that exceeds a specified minimum threshold. 108 -----

Subsection Title: European Corporate Sustainability Due Diligence Directive
Subsubsection Text: In addition, the European Commission, the Council of the European Union and the European Parliament have agreed on a joint draft of the Corporate Sustainability Due Diligence Directive (“CSDDD”) on December 14, 2023. The EU Parliament adopted the CSDDD on April 24, 2024 and the Council of the EU formally adopted the CSDDD on May 24, 2024. The CSDDD still needs to be transposed into national law. The CSDDD will affect companies of more than 1,000 employees with a turnover of more than EUR 450 million. It aims to foster sustainable and responsible corporate behavior in companies’ operations and across their global value chains. To this end, the directive establishes a corporate due diligence duty for companies, requiring them to identify, prevent, mitigate, address, and account for potential and actual adverse human rights and the environment impacts in the company’s own operations, their subsidiaries and, where related to their value chain(s), those of their business partners. Additionally, the CSDDD obligates large companies to adopt and put into effect, through best efforts, a transition plan for climate change mitigation aligned with the 2050 climate neutrality objective of the Paris Agreement as well as intermediate targets under EU climate law. Under the CSDDD, companies are expected to integrate due diligence into their policies and management systems. They must conduct due diligence regularly, take appropriate measures to address potential and actual adverse impacts and risks, and publicly communicate on their due diligence efforts. The CSDDD also includes provisions for enforcement and access to legal remedies for those affected by companies’ failure to comply with their risk management and due diligence obligations. It aims to level the playing field for businesses in the EU by ensuring that all companies adhere to the same high standards of corporate responsibility, thereby contributing to a sustainable economy and a better future. 109 -----

Our business, and in particular the operation of our production sites and marketing of products, is subject to various regulatory requirements. Applicable laws and regulations may differ from site to site as well as markets due to different national and local laws. The regulatory requirements relate in particular to our production processes and include, _inter alia, laws and regulations relating to (occupational) health and safety measures for employees, the technical safety_ requirements for operating machines, the use and handling of chemicals, air emissions, soil contamination and the management and disposal of waste, hazardous and toxic substances and other materials. For our sites and operations, we are required to obtain and hold various permits and to comply with the requirements specified therein as well as requirements under applicable laws, regulations and standards. We are further subject to foreign trade laws and may be required to pay export duties or customs duties on materials and products that we export or import. We are subject to further regulations in the various jurisdictions in which we operate, including antitrust laws and zoning and occupancy laws that generally apply to manufacturing businesses. Further, marketing and placement activities with respect to our products and our relationships with customers, suppliers and competitors are subject to regulatory requirements. The following is an overview of the main laws and regulations that are relevant to our activities in Germany. Local laws and regulations that deal with similar aspects apply in other jurisdictions in which we operate production sites or sell our products.

Founded in 1997 and owned by its partners, Triton is a leading European mid-market sector-specialist investor. Triton focuses on investing in businesses that provide mission critical goods and services in its three core sectors of Business Services, Industrial Tech, and Healthcare. Triton has more than €18 billion of committed capital across its funds. Triton has over 200 investment professionals across eleven offices and invests through three complementary “All Weather” strategies: Mid-Market Private Equity, Smaller Mid-Cap Private Equity, and Opportunistic Credit. 110 -----

The Issuer is a private limited liability company (société à responsabilité limitée) incorporated under the laws of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg on July 11, 2019 and registered with the Luxembourg Trade and Companies Register with registration number B236258. The address if its registered office is 2, rue Edward Steichen, L-2540 Luxembourg. The managers of the Issuer are Matthew Crill and Joakim Lindström-Formicola.

Kelvion Holding GmbH manages the business operations of the Kelvion group of operating subsidiaries. Its managing directors (Geschäftsführer) are Mark Bevan and Harald Gössl. The Group has a shareholder committee (the “Shareholder Committee”), which is currently comprised of the members listed in the table below. The Shareholder Committee is responsible for advising and monitoring the executive management team. The Shareholder Committee is authorized to pass instructions to the executive management team, to request reports on, for example, its legal and business relations with associated companies as well as business processes having a material impact on the situations of the Company and it is further authorized to inspect and examine the Company’s books and records. Certain corporate actions of the Group require pre-approval by the Shareholder Committee.

For the year ended December 31, 2023, the total remuneration of key operating management of the Group amounted to €3,846 thousand (2022: €2,567 thousand). For additional information, see Note 9.4 of the 2023 Audited Consolidated Financial Statements.
For the year ended December 31, 2023, shareholder committee costs amounted to €260 thousand.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsubsection Text: The sole shareholder Mangrove LuxCo II S.à r.l. granted a loan of €140 million to the Issuer on October 9, 2019 during the acquisition of Galapagos BidCo Group. The loan did not carry interest for the first six months after inception. On March 9, 2020, the shareholder contributed the loan receivable into the capital contribution account of the Issuer. With shareholder resolution as of December 22, 2020, the sole shareholder of the Issuer, Mangrove LuxCo II S.à r.l. acknowledged to convert an aggregate amount of €136,528,353 into tracking preferred equity certificates. As of December 31, 2023, the tracking preferred equity certificates are recognized at €170,580,799 including an interest of €11,350,815 (2022: €11,350,815).

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsubsection Text: Other related parties are our subsidiaries that are not included in the consolidated financial statements. Income and expenses from transactions with our subsidiaries and joint ventures or non-consolidated subsidiaries not included in the consolidated financial statements mainly result from regular deliveries of goods and services. In the year ended December 31, 2023, we incurred advisory costs from a Triton related advisory company amounting to €293 thousand (2022: €365 thousand). Additionally, as of December 31, 2023, we had financial liabilities towards Triton Fund IV amounting to €4,172 thousand (2022: €1,343 thousand) as well as €542 thousand (2022: €542 thousand) towards Galapagos MidCo S.à r.l. and €22 thousand (2022: €22 thousand) towards Triton MasterluxCo S.à r.l.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsubsection Text: In 2020, certain management personnel were invited to participate in our management incentive plan (the “Mangrove MIP”). This investment takes the form of part-ownership of Mangrove Management Invest S.C.A; an entity which has a part-ownership of Mangrove LuxCo II S.à r.l., the parent company of the Issuer. In order to participate in the Mangrove MIP, an initial cash investment was required from the management personnel, at a price not less than the fair value of such investments. During the year 2022, an additional management incentive plan was implemented. Again, certain management personnel were invited to participate in a management incentive plan of the new Kelvion Thermal Solutions Group (the “KTS MIP”). This investment takes the form of part-ownership of TESCO Management S.C.A, an entity which has a minority stake in TES LuxCo S.à r.l. TES LuxCo S.à r.l. is the parent company of Mangrove’s product group, Kelvion Thermal Solutions Group. Similar to the Mangrove MIP, the investment is structured in such a way that the management personnel have taken part-ownership of a holding company via an investment vehicle. In order to participate in the KTS MIP, in a first step the management personnel sold their contribution in the Mangrove MIP at fair value to Mangrove LuxCo I S.à r.l. In the amount of this receivable from Mangrove LuxCo I S.à r.l., the management personnel received an investment in the KTS MIP. The initial cash-related investment of the management personnel (receivable from Mangrove LuxCo I S.à r.l.) in the KTS MIP was at a price not less than the fair value of the investment in any case. The nature of the Mangrove MIP and the KTS MIP is such that personnel management investments will only be realized upon exit of our current shareholders, with exception of specific events (for example management personnel leaving our employment). It is anticipated that the management personnel will participate in the management incentive plans until such exit is achieved. The lead investor is permitted to issue further equity, and each management personnel has the explicit right to participate further in the management incentive plans, such that their investment is not diluted. 113 -----

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsubsection Text: _In accordance with IAS 24, transactions with persons or companies that are, inter alia, members of the same group as the Issuer or that are in control of or controlled by the Issuer must be disclosed unless they are already included as consolidated companies in the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements. Control exists if a shareholder owns more than one half of the voting rights in a company or, by virtue of an agreement, has the power to control the financial and operating policies of a company’s management. The disclosure requirements under IAS 24 also extend to transactions with associated companies (including joint ventures) as well as transactions with persons who have significant influence on the Issuer’s financial and operating policies, including close family members and intermediate entities. This includes the members of the executive management of the Issuer and close members of their families, as well as those entities over which the members of the executive management of the Issuer or their close family members are able to exercise a significant influence or in which they hold a significant share of the voting rights._ Related parties of the Group in accordance with IAS 24 primarily comprise the shareholders of the Issuer and our subsidiaries.

Subsubsection Title: Overview and structure
Subsubsection Text: The Issuer and the Initial Guarantors are parties to a €235.0 million super senior facilities agreement to be dated on or around the date of this Offering Memorandum (“Super Senior Facilities Agreement” and the multi-currency revolving credit facility thereunder shall be referred to as the “Cash RCF Facility” and the bank guarantee Facility thereunder shall be referred to as the “L/G RCF **Facility,” and the Cash RCF Facility and the L/G RCF Facility shall jointly be referred to as the “Super Senior Facilities”) with, among others, DEUTSCHE BANK AKTIENGESELLSCHAFT, COMMERZBANK Aktiengesellschaft, ING Bank N.V., J.P. Morgan SE, National Westminster Bank Plc, UniCredit Bank GmbH and Zurich Insurance Europe AG as mandated lead arrangers (together the “Mandated Lead Arrangers”), certain affiliates of the Mandated Lead Arrangers and certain other institutions as original lenders (together the “Original Lenders”), Deutsche Bank AG, London Branch as agent (the “Agent”) and as security agent (the “Security Agent”). The Super Senior Facilities Agreement provides for borrowings under the Cash RCF Facility of up to an aggregate initial principal amount of €65.0 million and guarantees under the L/G RCF Facility of up to an aggregate principal amount of €170.0 million on a committed basis. In addition, the Super Senior Facilities Agreement permits the incurrence of “additional revolving facilities” and “additional guarantee facilities” (see “Description of Certain Financing _Arrangements—Super Senior Facilities Agreement—Additional facilities”)._ The Cash RCF Facility may be utilized by any current or future borrower (subject to certain restrictions) under the Cash RCF Facility in euro or certain other currencies by the drawing of cash advances and by way of ancillary facilities; and the L/G RCF Facility may be utilized by any current or future borrower (subject to certain restrictions) under the L/G RCF Facility in euro or certain other currencies by way of ancillary facilities. Subject to certain exceptions, loans and guarantees may be borrowed, repaid and re-borrowed at any time. Borrowings under the Cash RCF Facility are available to be used to (directly or indirectly) finance or refinance the general corporate purposes and/or working capital requirements of the Issuer and its restricted subsidiaries (the “Restricted Group”) including, without limitation, to refinance and/or repay existing revolving credit and receivables financing arrangements of the Restricted Group (including factoring, securitization and other similar receivables financings) and the financing and/or refinancing of (i) capital expenditure and related costs and expenses, (ii) acquisitions, investments, joint ventures and related costs and expenses, (iii) operational restructurings and reorganizations of the Restricted Group and related costs and expenses, (iv) payments (including to be made to vendors) in respect of working capital related adjustments (howsoever structured) relating to or in connection with any acquisition, (v) payment of any refundable VAT on any fees, costs or expenses related to or incurred or charged in connection with the finance documents for the Notes, Super Senior Facilities and any other document designated as a “Transaction Document” under the Super Senior Facilities Agreement by the Agent and Mangrove LuxCo IV or any acquisition and any original issue discount, fees, flex and/or other related financing costs and/or (vi) interest payments due in respect of the Notes and any other indebtedness. Amounts utilized under the L/G RCF Facility shall be applied by the Issuer and its Restricted Group towards (i) refinancing existing letters of credit and performance bonds of the types listed under sub-paragraph (ii) entered into, used and/or needed by the Group and (ii) in the ordinary course of business of the Restricted Group, including but not limited to operational business requirements of the Restricted Group such as warranty obligations, performance obligations, advance payment obligations, tender obligations, rental obligations, customs obligations and similar letters of credit to guarantee obligations of the Restricted Group in the ordinary course of business including, for the avoidance of doubt, (y) back to back guarantees (issued to, inter alios, financial institutions) for outstanding obligations under such instruments and (z) any existing guarantees which are rolled in, but excluding in each case any letter of credit or similar instrument which constitutes a credit guarantee or similar credit security instrument securing financial obligations. Mangrove LuxCo IV (the “Company”) and Kelvion Holding GmbH will be the “original borrowers” and the Issuer, together with the Initial Guarantors, will be the “original guarantors” under the Super Senior Facilities. 114 -----

Subsubsection Title: Interest Rate and Fees
Subsubsection Text: _Interest rates_ The interest rate on cash advances under the Cash RCF Facility will be the rate per annum equal to the aggregate of the applicable margin and (a) in respect of Term Rate Loans, EURIBOR in relation to cash advances in euro, Term SOFR in relation to cash advances in U.S. dollars or the applicable Term Reference Rate for cash advances in any other currency (in each case as such term is defined in the Super Senior Facilities Agreement) and (b) in respect of Compounded Rate Loans, the Compounded Reference Rate for that day for that Compounded Rate Currency (in each case as such term is defined in the Super Senior Facilities Agreement) (each with a zero floor). Following the date that is the end of the second full fiscal quarter date after the Issue Date and provided that no Material Event of Default or Compliance Certificate Event of Default (as each such term is defined in the Super Senior Facilities Agreement) has occurred and is continuing, the margin on the Cash RCF Facility will be subject to reduction if certain “senior secured net leverage ratios” (which are to be calculated in the same way as the “Consolidated Senior Secured Net Leverage Ratio” under and as defined in the Indenture for the Notes (see “Description of the Notes—Certain Definitions”) are met. _Commitment fees_ A commitment fee will be payable on the aggregate undrawn and uncancelled amount of the Cash RCF Facility from (and including) the Issue Date to (and including) the last day of the availability period for the Cash RCF Facility cat a rate of the applicable percentage of the then applicable margin for the Cash RCF Facility. The commitment fee will be payable quarterly in arrears, on the last day of the availability period of the Cash RCF Facility and on the date the Cash RCF Facility is cancelled in full or on the date on which a lender cancels its commitment. A commitment fee will be payable on the aggregate undrawn and uncancelled amount of the L/G RCF Facility from (and including) the Issue Date to (and including) the last day of the availability period for the L/G RCF Facility computed at a rate set out in the relevant ancillary facility but in any event not exceeding a rate of the applicable percentage of the applicable guarantee fee for the L/G RCF Facility. The commitment fee will be payable quarterly in arrears, on the last day of the availability period of the L/G RCF Facility and on the date the L/G RCF Facility is cancelled in full or on the date on which a lender cancels its commitment. The guarantee fee for letters of credit or guarantees issued under the L/G RCF Facility will be agreed with each ancillary lender under the L/G RCF Facility on a bilateral basis. If letters of credit are cash collateralized and continue to be provided, the guarantee fee shall be as agreed between the Company and the relevant ancillary lender. The Company or the relevant Borrower shall also pay (or procure that payment is made) to the relevant ancillary lender under an ancillary facility related to the L/G RCF Facility an issuance/administration fee in the amount and at the times specified in the relevant ancillary facility agreement. In relation to any additional Cash RCF Facility and/or additional L/G RCF Facility (the “Additional **Facility”), the Company shall pay (or shall procure that another Obligor shall pay) to the Agent (for the account of each relevant Additional Facility Lender (as defined in the Super Senior Facilities Agreement)) a commitment fee (if any) in the amounts, and at the times, specified in any relevant Additional Facility Notice (as defined in the Super Senior Facilities Agreement). No commitment fee shall be payable unless the Issue Date occurs. The Company is not required to pay any commitment fees to a lender for so long as such lender is a defaulting lender. Default interest will, to the fullest extent permitted by law, subject to being in compliance with Article 1154 of the Luxembourg Civil Code, be calculated as an additional 1% on the overdue amount. _Other fees_ The Company is also required to pay customary agency fees to the Agent and the Security Agent in connection with the Super Senior Facilities.

Subsubsection Title: Availability
Subsubsection Text: The Cash RCF Facility may, subject to satisfaction of customary conditions precedent, be utilized from (and including) the Issue Date to (and including) the date falling one month prior to its maturity date. The L/G RCF Facility may, subject to satisfaction of customary conditions precedent, be utilized from (and including) the Issue Date to (and including) the date falling one day prior to its maturity date. 115 -----

Subsubsection Title: Prepayment
Subsubsection Text: The Super Senior Facilities Agreement allows for voluntary prepayments (subject to a minimum amount and notice requirements). The Super Senior Facilities Agreement also permits each lender to require the mandatory prepayment of all amounts due to that lender upon: - a “change of control” (which comprises, generally, (i) the Issuer ceasing to directly own 100% of the total issued share capital or all of the voting rights of the Company and (ii) the scenarios set out under the definition of “Change of Control” under the caption “Description of the Notes—Certain Definitions”); or - if it becomes unlawful for the lender to perform any of its obligations (as applicable) under the Super Senior Facilities or to fund, issue or maintain its participation in any Utilization (as defined in the Super Senior Facilities Agreement). If the Company or a restricted subsidiary has consummated an asset disposition and the net cash proceeds received in connection therewith which exceed €35.0 million have not been applied for certain purposes specified in the Super Senior Facilities Agreement within 360 days of the date of the receipt of such net cash proceeds, the Company shall also mandatorily prepay any outstanding Cash RCF Facility loans in an amount equal to the pro rata share of the Cash RCF Facility in such net cash proceeds within three business days. Notwithstanding the foregoing, any ancillary lender may, as between itself and the relevant member of the Restricted Group, agree to continue to provide such ancillary facility (with such arrangements continuing on a bilateral basis and not as part of, or under, the finance documents for any Facility and the transaction security for such Facility shall not, following release by the Security Agent, secure any such ancillary facility in respect of any claims that arise after such cancellation). To the extent that the commitments of a lender under the Cash RCF Facility are voluntarily cancelled by the Issuer in full which the Company is entitled to do by giving five business days’ prior written notice to the Agent of such cancellation, such lender under the Cash RCF Facility shall have the right to cancel its commitments under the L/G RCF Facility in full within 30 days of its commitments under the Cash RCF Facility being cancelled in full, by giving not less than 5 Business Days’ prior notice to the Issuer and the Agent, provided that the Issuer shall have 30 days after the relevant lender giving notice of such cancellation of the commitments under the L/G RCF Facility to the Issuer and the Agent, to cash-collateralize, replace or provide counter-guarantees for any guarantees or letters of credit then outstanding under the relevant ancillary facility provided under the L/G RCF Facility. This shall not apply to the extent that the commitments of all lenders under the Cash RCF Facility are reduced prior to the Acquisition Closing Date on a pro rata basis.

Subsubsection Title: Additional Facilities
Subsubsection Text: The Super Senior Facilities Agreement contemplates the incurrence of uncommitted “additional revolving facilities” and “additional guarantee facilities” in a maximum amount not to exceed the aggregate sum of: - in respect of the Cash RCF Facility (i) the greater of (x) €65.0 million and (y) an amount equal to 45% of consolidated earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization plus certain adjustments, similar to those in Consolidated EBITDA as set out in “Description of the Notes,” of the Restricted Group, on a pro forma basis for the most recently ended four full fiscal quarters for which internal consolidated financial statements are available prior to such incurrence (after giving pro forma effect to the relevant transactions) less (ii) the total Cash 116 ----- RCF Facility commitment immediately before giving effect to the amount of the additional revolving facility; and - in respect of the L/G RCF Facility (i) the greater of (x) €190.0 million and (y) an amount equal to 130% of consolidated earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization plus certain adjustments, similar to those in Consolidated EBITDA as set out in “Description of the Notes,” of the Restricted Group, on a pro forma basis for the most recently ended four full fiscal quarters for which internal consolidated financial statements are available prior to such incurrence (after giving pro forma effect to the relevant transactions) less (ii) the total L/G RCF Facility commitment immediately before giving effect to the amount of the_ additional L/G RCF Facility, Such additional revolving facilities and guarantee facilities may be incurred under the Super Senior Facilities Agreement either as a new Cash RCF Facility, a new L/G RCF Facility and/or as an additional tranche of any existing Cash RCF facility and/or L/G RCF Facility and/or by increasing the commitments under an existing Cash RCF Facility or an existing L/G RCF Facility. Such additional revolving facilities and/or guarantee facilities will be secured and shall rank _pari passu with the Super Senior Facilities and be prepaid on a_ _pro rata basis (including with respect to mandatory_ prepayments). The lenders of any such additional revolving facilities and/or guarantee facilities may not have the benefit of guarantees from any member of the Restricted Group which is not a borrower or guarantor of the Super Senior Facilities or security over assets other than the then existing transaction security for the Super Senior Facilities (except where the same security (to the extent permitted by law) is granted in respect of the other facilities under the Super Senior Facilities). The availability, maturity, pricing and other terms of any Additional Facility will be those agreed between the Issuer and the relevant lenders of that Additional Facility, provided that (i) (in relation to an additional revolving facility) the final maturity date of the additional revolving facility is no earlier than the Termination Date applicable to the Cash RCF Facility (or, in each case, if at such time the Revolving Facility has been cancelled in full or would be repaid and cancelled in full after giving effect to the application of the proceeds of the relevant Additional Facility, any final maturity date under the Super Senior Facilities Agreement); and (in relation to an additional guarantee facility) the final maturity date of the additional guarantee facility is no earlier than the Termination Date applicable to the L/G RCF Facility (or, in each case, if at such time the L/G RCF Facility has been cancelled in full or would be repaid and cancelled in full after giving effect to the application of the proceeds of the relevant Additional Facility, any final maturity date under the Super Senior Facilities Agreement), (ii) no “material event of default” has occurred and is continuing at the time the relevant Additional Facility is committed (unless the proceeds of the relevant Additional Facility are used to refinance existing additional revolving facilities or guarantee facilities) and (iii) no member of the Restricted Group may provide an Additional Facility.

Subsubsection Title: Guarantees
Subsubsection Text: The Super Senior Facilities is guaranteed by the Issuer and the Initial Guarantors and will be guaranteed by the Post-Issue Date Guarantors within 120 days of the Issue Date. The Super Senior Facilities Agreement requires that, subject to certain “agreed security principles” set out in the Super Senior Facilities Agreement, each member of the Restricted Group that is, or becomes, a “material company” (which is generally defined under the Super Senior Facilities Agreement to include, among other things, certain members of the Restricted Group that have earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization representing 5% or more of the consolidated earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization of the Restricted Group, and certain members of the Restricted Group that are a direct or indirect holding company of a “material company”) after the Issue Date by reference to the annual consolidated financial statements (the “Annual Financial Statements”) most recently delivered to the Agent, or, at the discretion of the Company, a more recent set of financial statements of the Restricted Group for an LTM Period; and/or if a Subsidiary has been acquired since the date as at which the latest Annual Financial Statements of the Restricted Group were prepared, the latest annual financial statements of the relevant Subsidiary for the relevant financial year (consolidated in the case of a Subsidiary which itself has Subsidiaries), or, if such financial statements are not available or required by law, such other accounts as are available (commencing with the first complete fiscal year ending after the Issue Date) will be required to become a guarantor under the Super Senior Facilities Agreement within 120 days of the date of delivery of the relevant annual consolidated or combined, as applicable, financial statements of the Issuer for the relevant fiscal year. Furthermore, if on the last day of each financial year of the Company (commencing with the first complete financial year after the Acquisition Closing Date), the guarantors represent less than 80% of the consolidated earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization of the members of the Restricted Group (subject to certain exceptions) (the “Guarantor Coverage Test”), within 120 days of delivery of the annual financial statements for the relevant financial year (commencing with the first complete financial year after the Issue Date), such other members of the Restricted Group (subject to the agreed security principles and certain other exceptions) are required to become guarantors until the Guarantor Coverage Test is satisfied (to be calculated as if such additional guarantors had been guarantors on the last day of the 117 ----- relevant financial year). Members of the Restricted Group may be excluded from such calculation if (i) they are incorporated in an Excluded Jurisdiction (as defined in the Super Senior Facilities Agreement) or (ii) there is a restriction applicable to it in relation to becoming a guarantor. The Company shall also ensure that the Guarantor Coverage Test is satisfied by the date which is 120 days after (and excluding) the Issue Date (or such later date as the Agent may agree in its reasonable discretion).

Subsubsection Title: Security
Subsubsection Text: The Super Senior Facilities (subject to the agreed security principles set out in the Super Senior Facilities Agreement) are secured by the Collateral as further described under “Description of the Notes—Security.” Each direct and indirect holding company of any “material company” (provided that such holding company is a wholly-owned member of the Restricted Group in each case with certain members of the Restricted Group being excluded, which becomes a guarantor under any Facility is required (subject to the “agreed security principles”) to grant security over the shares it holds in such material company in favor of the Security Agent. In addition, any “material company” or other member of the Restricted Group which becomes a guarantor of the Super Senior Facilities is required (subject to the agreed security principles) to grant security over certain of its material assets in favor of the Security Agent. Under the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, proceeds from the enforcement of the collateral (whether or not shared with the holders of the Notes) will be required to be applied to repay indebtedness outstanding under the Super Senior Facilities, as well as certain hedging obligations and cash management obligations, in priority to the Notes.

Subsubsection Title: Representations and Warranties
Subsubsection Text: The Super Senior Facilities Agreement contains certain customary representations and warranties (subject to certain customary materiality, actual knowledge and other qualifications, exceptions and baskets, and with certain representations and warranties being repeated on the date of each utilization request made after the Issue Date and on the first day of each interest period), including without limitation: (i) status; (ii) binding obligations; (iii) non-conflict with other obligations; (iv) power and authority; (v) validity and admissibility in evidence; (vi) consents and filings; (vii) governing law and enforcement; (viii) no insolvency; (ix) no proceedings pending or threatened; (x) no filing or stamp taxes; (xi) no events of default; (xii) taxation; (xiii) deduction of tax; (xiv) consents and filing; (xv) no filing and stamp taxes); (xvi) pari passu ranking; (xvii) legal and beneficial ownership; (xviii) financial model; (xix) group structure; (xx) centre of main interest; (xxi) compliance with ERISA, (xxii) margin stock; (xxiii) investment company act; (xxiv) anticorruption, anti-terrorism laws and sanctions; (xxv) no breach of laws; (xxvi) good title to assets and (xxvii) financial statements.

Subsubsection Title: Covenants
Subsubsection Text: The Super Senior Facilities Agreement contains certain of the same incurrence covenants and related definitions (with certain adjustments) that will apply to the Notes as included under the caption “Description _of the Notes—Certain _Covenants.”_ In addition, the Super Senior Facilities Agreement also contains certain affirmative and negative covenants, and the Super Senior Facilities Agreement also contains a financial covenant for the benefit of lenders under the Cash RCF Facility only. Set forth below is a brief description of such covenants, all of which are subject to customary materiality, actual knowledge or other qualifications, exceptions and baskets. _Affirmative Covenants_ The affirmative covenants include, among others: (i) providing certain financial information in respect of the Restricted Group, including annual audited and quarterly financial statements and compliance certificates; (ii) authorizations; (iii) compliance with laws; (iv) payment of taxes; (v) maintenance of pari passu ranking of the Super Senior Facilities; (vi) access for the agent; (vii) compliance with environmental permits and laws; (viii) acquisitions; (ix) maintenance of the guarantor and security coverage; (x) further assurance provisions and (xi) compliance with sanctions and anti-corruption laws. _Negative Covenants_ The negative covenants include certain restrictions, among others, with respect to (i) activity by the Issuer other than a holding company activity; (ii) changing the center of main interest of a borrower or guarantor under any Facility; and (iii) Notes purchases. Otherwise, the negative covenants in the Super Senior Facilities are substantially the same as the negative covenants that will be in the Indenture. 118 ----- Certain of the incurrence covenants under the Super Senior Facilities Agreement may be suspended upon (i) the occurrence of a “Listing” (as defined in the Super Senior Facilities Agreement) (that does not result in a “change of control”) and the achievement of a “consolidated net leverage ratio” of the Restricted Group is equal to or less than 2.00:1.00 (generally, _pro forma for any prepayment of the Cash RCF Facility from the proceeds of such initial public offering) or (ii) a member of the Restricted Group or a holding company of the Issuer having achieved an investment grade status (Baa3/BBB- or better by Moody’s or S&P, respectively). The Super Senior Facilities Agreement also contain a “note purchase condition” covenant, which provides, subject to certain exceptions set out in the Super Senior Facilities Agreement, that the Issuer may not, and shall procure that no other member of the Restricted Group will, prepay, purchase, redeem, retire or otherwise acquire for value any of the principal amount of the Notes prior to the scheduled repayment date. The exceptions to such covenant include, inter alia (and provided that no event of default under any Super Senior Facility is continuing or would result from such note purchase): (i) notes purchases funded with, _inter alia, certain permitted indebtedness under the Super Senior Facilities Agreement (other than the Cash RCF Facility); (ii) note purchases that do not exceed 50% of the aggregate face value of the Notes in existence at the Issue Date or incurred afterwards (and any permitted refinancing thereof); or (iii) the Super Senior Facilities (including any additional facilities) are cancelled (and if applicable prepaid) in the same or greater proportion as the proportion of the note purchase to the aggregate face value of the Notes then outstanding, provided that (A) the revolving facility commitments shall in no circumstances be required to be reduced below an amount equal to 60% of the total revolving facility commitments outstanding at that time; and (B) the guarantee facility commitments shall in no circumstances be required to be reduced below 80% of the total guarantee facility commitments outstanding at that time. _Financial Covenant_ The Super Senior Facilities Agreement requires the Issuer to comply with a consolidated “senior secured net leverage” financial covenant for the benefit of the lenders under the Cash RCF Facility and any additional revolving facility which benefits from the financial covenant. The financial covenant will be tested quarterly on a rolling basis, generally, subject to (i) the first test date falling on the date that is the end of the second full fiscal quarter date after the Issue Date and (ii) the “test condition” being met on the relevant test date, such condition being (A) the aggregate of all outstanding loans under the Cash RCF Facility and any springing covenant revolving facility and all outstanding cash drawings and any letters of credit or guarantees which have been called and which remain outstanding under Ancillary Facilities (as defined in the Super Senior Facilities Agreement) under the Cash RCF Facility or any springing covenant revolving facility less cash and cash equivalents held by members of the Restricted Group as at such test date, which exceeds (B) 40% of the aggregate of Cash RCF Facility commitments as at the date of the Super Senior Facilities Agreement and additional revolving facilities established following the date of the Super Senior Facilities Agreement. The Issuer is permitted to prevent or cure breaches of the financial covenant by applying a “cure” amount (generally, amounts received by the Issuer in cash pursuant to any new equity or permitted shareholder subordinated debt), including as if “consolidated earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization” had been reduced by such amount. There is no requirement to apply any such cure amount in prepayment of the Super Senior Facilities. No more than five (in aggregate) different cure amounts may be taken into account prior to the original termination date of the Super Senior Facilities Agreement out of which no more than two may be remedied pursuant to an EBITDA cure and more than two EBITDA or prepayment cure amounts in any four consecutive financial quarters are not permitted.

Subsubsection Title: Events of Default
Subsubsection Text: The Super Senior Facilities Agreement provides for some of the same events of default, with certain adjustments, as those applicable for the Notes as set forth in the section entitled “Description of the Notes—Events of Default.” In addition, the Super Senior Facilities provides for certain customary events of default, all of which are subject to customary materiality and other qualifications, exceptions, baskets and/or grace periods, as appropriate, comprising without limitation: (i) for the benefit of lenders under the Cash RCF Facility only, breach of the financial covenant subject to possibilities to cure the financial covenant breach; (ii) breach of other obligations subject to a 20 business day grace period; (iii) representations or warranties found to be untrue or misleading in any material respect when made or deemed repeated subject to a 20 business day grace period; (iv) material litigation, arbitration or administrative, governmental, regulatory or other proceedings in relation to the finance documents or against any member of the Restricted Group or its material assets; (v) cross default subject to thresholds; (vi) unlawfulness and invalidity subject to a 20 business day grace period; (vii) failure to comply with a material term of the Intercreditor Agreement by a member of the Restricted Group or any affiliate of the Issuer which is not a member of the Restricted Group subject to a 20 business day grace period; (viii) repudiation and rescission of the finance documents and (ix) cessation of business. 119 -----

Subsubsection Title: Governing Law
Subsubsection Text: The Super Senior Facilities Agreement will be governed by English law, _provided that the events of default, incurrence covenants and related definitions for the Notes to be included (with certain adjustments) in the Super Senior Facilities Agreement will be interpreted in accordance with the law of the State of New York.

Each Super Senior Facility matures on the date falling on the earlier of (i) the date falling 4 years and six months after the date of the Super Senior Facilities Agreement and (ii) the date falling six months prior to the Maturity Date of the Notes. Each advance under the Cash RCF Facility will be repaid on the last day of the interest period relating thereto, subject to a netting mechanism against amounts to be drawn on such date. All outstanding amounts under a Facility must be repaid in full on or prior to the maturity date for the relevant Facility. Amounts repaid by the borrowers on loans made under the Cash RCF Facility may be re-borrowed during the availability period for that facility, subject to certain conditions.

Subsubsection Title: Overview
Subsubsection Text: The Intercreditor Agreement sets out, among other things: - The relative ranking of certain debt of the Restricted Group in respect of “Super Senior Liabilities”, “Senior

To establish the relative rights of certain of our creditors under certain of our financing arrangements, the Issuer and the Initial Guarantors, among others, will enter into an intercreditor agreement (the “Intercreditor Agreement”) on or about the date of this Offering Memorandum together with the Agent, the Original Lenders and the Mandated Lead Arrangers and the Security Agent, to which the Trustee will accede as a “senior secured notes trustee” on or prior to the Issue Date. By accepting a Note, the relevant holder thereof shall be deemed to have agreed to, and accepted the terms and conditions of, the Intercreditor Agreement and shall be deemed to have authorized the Trustee to enter into the Intercreditor Agreement on its behalf as Trustee. The following description is a summary of certain provisions, among others, that will be contained in the Intercreditor Agreement and which relate to the rights and obligations of the holders of the Notes. It does not restate the Intercreditor Agreement in its entirety. As such, you are urged to read the Intercreditor Agreement because it, and not the description that follows, defines certain rights of the holders of the Notes. Unless expressly stated otherwise in the Intercreditor Agreement, in the event of a conflict between the terms of the Super Senior Facilities Agreement, the Indenture and the Intercreditor Agreement, the provisions of the Intercreditor Agreement will prevail.

Subsection Title: Credit Facility Liabilities,” “Senior Subordinated Liabilities,” “Cash Management Liabilities,” “Non- Priority Hedging Liabilities,” “Priority Hedging Liabilities” and “Senior Secured Notes Liabilities” (each as
Subsubsection Text: defined below); - the relative ranking of certain security granted by certain members of the Restricted Group and by Third Party Security Providers for the benefit of certain creditors under certain of our financing arrangements; - when payments can be made in respect of certain indebtedness of the Restricted Group; - when enforcement action (including acceleration and/or demand for payment and certain similar actions) (“Enforcement Action”) can be taken in respect of the “Transaction Security” (as defined below); - the requirement to turnover amounts received from enforcement of the Transaction Security and certain guarantees provided by certain members of the Restricted Group and by Third Party Security Providers; - when the Transaction Security and guarantee(s) issued by certain members of the Restricted Group and by Third Party Security Providers will be released to permit an enforcement sale; - the circumstances under which creditors’ claims (including the claims of holders of the Notes against the Company) might be required to be transferred to third parties or released to assist in enforcement; and - the order for applying proceeds from the enforcement of the Transaction Security, certain guarantees and other amounts received by the Security Agent. _Incurrence of Additional Indebtedness_ The Intercreditor Agreement will contain customary provisions regulating certain additional indebtedness permitted to be incurred by members of the Restricted Group and which is contemplated to be secured by the documents creating security (including over the Collateral) (the “Transaction Security”) granted by certain members of the Restricted Group and by Third Party Security Providers (together, the “Transaction Security **Documents”). 120 ----- Such additional indebtedness may either, with respect to the Transaction Security (and the proceeds thereof): (a) be in the form of a “credit facility” ranking senior to the liabilities in respect of the Notes with respect to the proceeds of enforcement of the Transaction Security, in which case it will vote in, and share in the proceeds of, enforcement of Transaction Security with the lenders under the Super Senior Facilities and any Hedging Agreements in respect of the Priority Hedging Liabilities (such additional credit facilities, solely for the purposes of this description of the Intercreditor Agreement, the “Additional Super Senior Facilities” and, the lenders of such indebtedness, the “Additional Super Senior Lenders”): (ii) be in the form of a “credit facility” and have equivalent rights to the rights of the holders of the Notes under the Intercreditor Agreement, in which case it will vote in, and share in the proceeds of, enforcement of the Transaction Security with the same class of creditors as the holders of Notes Liabilities (the “Senior Credit Facility Liabilities”) or (ii) to the extent that it benefits from Transaction Security, be in the form of loans, credit or debt facilities or notes (among other things) and rank junior to the liabilities in respect of the Notes, in which case it will share in the proceeds of enforcement of the Transaction Security expressed to secure it on a junior basis to the holders of the Notes (such indebtedness, “Senior Subordinated Debt,” and the lenders or holders of such indebtedness, the “Senior Subordinated

Subsubsection Title: Ranking and Priority
Subsubsection Text: _Priority of Indebtedness_ The Intercreditor Agreement will provide that the liabilities of the Obligors, as the case may be, in respect of the Senior Credit Facilities (the “Senior Credit Facility Liabilities”), the Notes and any additional notes issued from time to time under the Indenture (together, the “Senior Secured Notes,” and the liabilities in respect thereof, the “Senior Secured

_Hedging Transactions_ The Intercreditor Agreement will contain provisions that will permit certain members of the Group to enter into hedging agreements with certain hedge counterparties, which may also be secured by the Transaction Security. The hedging agreements may either, with respect to the Transaction Security (and the proceeds thereof): (i) be secured on a senior basis to the liabilities in respect of the Notes with respect to the proceeds of enforcement of the Transaction Security, in which case it will vote in, and share in the proceeds of, enforcement of the Transaction Security with the lenders and creditors under the Super Senior Facilities (such hedge counterparties, the “Priority Hedge 121 -----
