See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes, the Guarantees and the Collateral—There may not be an _active trading market for the Notes, in which case your ability to sell the Notes may be limited.” Each purchaser of the_ Notes, by its purchase of the Notes, will be deemed to have made certain acknowledgements, representations, warranties and agreements as set forth under “Notice to Investors,” “Notice to EEA Investors” and “Notice to Certain Other Investors.” In connection with the offering, Deutsche Bank Aktiengesellschaft (the “Stabilizing Manager”) (or persons acting on its behalf) may purchase and sell Notes in the open market. These transactions may include over allotment, stabilizing transactions, syndicate covering transactions and penalty bids. Over allotment involves sales in excess of the offering size, which creates a short position for the Initial Purchasers. Stabilizing transactions involve bids to purchase the Notes in the open market for the purpose of pegging, fixing or maintaining the price of the Notes. Syndicate covering 271 ----- transactions involve purchases of the Notes in the open market after the distribution has been completed in order to cover short positions. Penalty bids permit the Initial Purchasers to reclaim a selling concession from a broker/dealer when the Notes originally sold by such broker/dealer are purchased in a stabilizing or covering transaction to cover short positions. These transactions may be effected in the over the counter market or otherwise. These activities may stabilize, maintain or otherwise affect the market price of the Notes. As a result, the price of the Notes may be higher than the prices that otherwise might exist in the open market. Neither the Issuer nor the Initial Purchasers make any representation or prediction as to the direction or magnitude of any effect that the transactions described above may have on the price of the Notes. In addition, there is no obligation on the Stabilizing Manager to engage in such transactions and neither the Issuer nor the Initial Purchasers make any representation that the Stabilizing Manager will engage in these transactions or that these transactions, once commenced, will not be discontinued without notice. Any stabilizing action, if commenced, must end no later than the earlier of 30 days after the Issue Date and 60 days after the date of the allotment of the Notes. The Initial Purchasers and their affiliates are full service financial institutions engaged in various activities, which may include securities trading, commercial and investment banking, financial advisory, investment management, principal investment, hedging, financing and brokerage activities. The Initial Purchasers or their respective affiliates from time to time have provided in the past and may provide in the future investment banking, financial advisory and commercial banking services (including, among others, hedging, financing, guarantee business, cash management and various other banking services and activities) to the Issuer and its affiliates, or to the Issuer and its affiliates in the ordinary course of business for which they have received or may receive customary fees and commissions. The Initial Purchasers or their respective affiliates have received, and expect to receive, customary fees and commissions for the Transactions. In particular, the Initial Purchasers or certain of their affiliates are mandated lead arrangers and lenders under the Super Senior Facilities, and such entities have received or will receive customary fees for their services in such capacities. Furthermore, certain of the Initial Purchasers or their respective affiliates are lenders under the Existing RCF Facility Agreement and the Existing L/G Facility Agreement and have received or will receive customary fees for their services. Following the completion of the Offering, the Existing RCF Facility Agreement and the Existing L/G Facility Agreement will be cancelled in full and any outstanding utilizations thereunder will be repaid. The Initial Purchasers or their respective affiliates are, or will become, lenders under the super Senior Facilities Agreement and have received or will receive customary fees for their services. In addition, in the ordinary course of their business activities, the Initial Purchasers and their affiliates may make or hold a broad array of investments and actively trade debt and equity securities (or related derivative securities) and financial instruments (including bank loans) for their own account and for the accounts of their customers. Such investments and securities activities may involve securities and/or instruments of the Issuer, the Guarantors or their respective affiliates. The Initial Purchasers and their affiliates may also receive allocations of the Notes. The Initial Purchasers and their respective affiliates may also, in the future, act as hedge counterparties to the Issuer consistent with their customary risk management policies. Typically, such Initial Purchasers and their affiliates would hedge such exposure by entering into transactions which consist of either the purchase of credit default swaps or the creation of short positions in securities, including potentially the Notes. Any such short positions could adversely affect future trading prices of Notes. The Initial Purchasers and their affiliates may also make investment recommendations and/or publish or express independent research views with respect to such securities or financial instruments and may hold, or recommend to clients that they acquire, long and/or short positions in such securities and instruments. 272 -----

However, the Initial Purchasers are under no obligation to do so and may discontinue any market-making activities at any time without notice. In addition, any such market-making activity will be subject to the limits imposed by the US Securities Act and the US Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended (the “US Exchange Act”). Accordingly, it cannot be assured that any market for the Notes will develop, or that such market will be liquid if it does develop, or that an investor will be able to sell any Notes at a particular time or at a price which will be favorable. To the extent that such Initial Purchasers intend to effect sales of the Notes in the United States, they will do so only through one or more U.S. registered broker-dealers or otherwise as permitted by applicable U.S. law. The Notes and the Guarantees have not been and will not be registered under the US Securities Act or qualified for sale under the securities laws of any US state or any jurisdiction outside the United States and may not be offered or sold within the United States except to QIBs in reliance on Rule 144A and outside the United States in offshore transactions in reliance on Regulation S. Accordingly, the Notes will be subject to significant restrictions on resale and transfer as described under “Notice to Investors,” “Notice to EEA Investors,” “Notice to Certain Other Investors” and “Transfer _Restrictions.” Any offer or sale of Notes in the United States in reliance on Rule 144A will be made by broker dealers who_ are registered as such under the US Exchange Act. Until 40 days after the later of (i) the commencement of this offering and (ii) the issue date of the Notes, an offer or sale of the Notes initially sold in reliance on Regulation S within the United States by a dealer (whether or not participating in the offering) may violate the registration requirements of the US Securities Act if such offer or sale is made otherwise than in accordance with Rule 144A under the US Securities Act. Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF CIVIL LIABILITIES
Subsubsection Text: The Issuer is incorporated under the laws of Luxembourg. A substantial portion of the assets of the Issuer is located outside the United States. As a result, it may not be possible for investors to effect service of process within the United States upon the Issuer or to enforce against it judgments of U.S. courts predicated upon the civil liability provisions of U.S. federal or state securities laws. In Luxembourg, it may be possible for investors to effect service of process upon the Issuer and the Luxembourg Guarantors incorporated and existing under Luxembourg law within Luxembourg in accordance with the Hague Convention on the Service Abroad of Judicial and Extrajudicial Documents in Civil or Commercial Matters of November 15, 1965. The United States and Luxembourg are not currently bound by a treaty providing for reciprocal recognition and enforcement of judgments, other than arbitral awards rendered in civil and commercial matters. An enforceable judgment for the payment of monies rendered by any U.S. Federal or state court based on civil liability, whether or not predicated solely upon the US securities laws, would not directly be enforceable in Luxembourg. However, a party who received such favorable judgment in a U.S. court may initiate enforcement proceedings in Luxembourg (exequatur) by requesting enforcement of the U.S. judgment by the District Court (Tribunal d’Arrondissement) pursuant to Section 678 of the New Luxembourg Code of Civil Procedure. The District Court will authorize the enforcement in Luxembourg of the U.S. judgment if it is satisfied that all of the following conditions are met: - the U.S. judgment is enforceable (exécutoire) in the United States; - the U.S. court awarding the judgment must have had jurisdiction to adjudicate the respective matter both under applicable U.S. Federal or state jurisdictions rules, and under applicable Luxembourg international private law conflict of jurisdiction rules and local law; - the U.S. court has applied the substantive law as designated by Luxembourg conflict of laws rules, or at least, the order must not contravene the principles underlying those rules (based on case law and legal doctrine, it is not certain that this condition would still be required for an exequatur to be granted by a Luxembourg court); - the U.S. judgment does not contravene international public policy or order as understood under the laws of Luxembourg or has not been given in proceedings of a tax, penal or criminal nature (which would include awards of damages made under civil liabilities provisions of the U.S. federal securities laws, or other laws, to the extent that the same would be classified by Luxembourg courts as being of a penal or punitive nature (for example, fines or punitive damages)). Ordinarily an award of monetary damages would not be considered as a penalty, but if the monetary damages include punitive damages, such punitive damages may be considered as a penalty; - the U.S. court has acted in accordance with its own procedural laws; - the principles of fair trial and due process have been complied with and in particular the U.S. judgment was granted following proceedings where the counterparty had the opportunity to appear, and if it appeared, to present a defense; and - the U.S. judgment was not granted pursuant to an evasion of Luxembourg law (fraude à la loi _luxembourgeoise)._ Subject to the above conditions, Luxembourg courts tend not to review the merits of a foreign judgment, although there is no statutory prohibition to do so. If an original action is brought in Luxembourg, Luxembourg courts may refuse to apply the designated law (i) if the choice of such law was not made bona fide and (ii) if its application contravenes Luxembourg public policy or is 273 ----- manifestly incompatible with Luxembourg international policy rules. In an action brought in Luxembourg on the basis of U.S. federal or state securities laws, Luxembourg courts may not have the requisite power to grant the remedies sought. Also, an exequatur may be refused in respect of punitive damages. Further, in the event of any proceedings being brought in a Luxembourg court in respect of a monetary obligation expressed to be payable in a currency other than euro, a Luxembourg court would have power to give judgment expressed as an order to pay a currency other than euro. However, enforcement of the judgment against any party in Luxembourg would be available only in euro and for such purposes all claims or debts would be converted into euro.

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF CIVIL LIABILITIES
Subsubsection Text: The Issuer has been advised by its German counsel that there is doubt as to the enforceability in Germany of civil liabilities based on US federal or state securities laws, either in an original action or in an action to enforce a judgment obtained in US federal or state courts. The United States and the Federal Republic of Germany currently do not have a treaty providing for the reciprocal recognition and enforcement of judgments, other than arbitration awards, in civil and commercial matters. Consequently, a final judgment by any US federal or state court for payment, whether or not predicated solely upon US federal or state securities laws, would not automatically be enforceable in Germany. A final judgment by a US federal or state court, however, may be recognized and enforced in Germany in an action before a court of competent jurisdiction in accordance with the proceedings set forth by the German Code of Civil Procedure (Zivilprozessordnung). In such an action, a German court generally would not reinvestigate the merits of the original matter decided by a US court, except as noted below. German courts will, in particular, not recognize and enforce such judgements if any of the reasons for excluding enforceability set forth in Sections 723(2), 328(1) of the German Code of Civil Procedure (Zivilprozessordnung) exist: - the judgment is final under US federal or state law; - if, pursuant to German law, the courts in the country of the court having rendered the foreign judgement did not have jurisdiction; - if process has not been duly served or has not been served in a timely fashion to permit a defense, provided that the defendant did not actively participate in such process and pleads accordingly; - if the judgement is incompatible with a prior judgement rendered by a German court or by a foreign court which is to be recognized in Germany; - if the proceeding resulting in the judgement to be recognized is incompatible with a previously pending (rechtshängig) proceeding in Germany; - if a recognition of the judgement would be obviously incompatible with fundamental principles of German law (order public), in particular, if the recognition would be incompatible with the civil rights under the German Constitution (Grundgesetz); and if reciprocity is not ensured (i.e., the courts of the country where the judgement was issued would not recognize and enforce a comparable judgement by a German court in equivalent circumstances). Subject to the foregoing, purchasers of securities may be able to enforce judgments in civil and commercial matters obtained from US federal or state courts in Germany. The Issuer cannot, however, assure you that attempts to enforce judgments in Germany will be successful. In addition, in the past the recognition and enforcement of punitive damages has been denied by German courts as incompatible with the fundamental principles of German law. Moreover, a German court may reduce the amount of damages granted by a US court and recognize damages only to the extent that they are necessary to compensate actual losses or damages. Consequently, judgements awarding monetary damages under civil liabilities provisions of the US federal securities laws may not be enforceable to the extent they provide for a compensation that would qualify as being of a penal or punitive nature. German civil procedure differs substantially from US civil procedure in a number of aspects, including the possibilities for obtaining evidence. With respect to the production of evidence, for example, US federal and state law and the laws of several other jurisdictions based on common law provide for pre-trial discovery, a process by which parties to the proceedings may, prior to trial, compel the production of documents by adverse or third parties and the deposition of witnesses. Evidence obtained in this manner may be decisive in the outcome of any proceeding. No such pre-trial discovery process exists under German law. If the party in whose favor the final US federal or state judgement is rendered brings a new lawsuit in the same matter in a competent court in Germany, such party may submit to the German courts the final judgement rendered in the 274 ----- United States. Under such circumstances, a judgement by a US federal or state court will be regarded by the German court only as evidence of the outcome of the dispute to which such judgement relates. A German court may choose to re-hear the dispute and may render a judgement that is not in line with the judgement rendered by the US federal or state court, but the latitude to deviate from the foreign judgment is limited. The German court is free to issue a completely new decision if there are grounds for non-recognition under 328(1) of the German Code of Civil Procedure, but must otherwise take the foreign decision into account (i.e., the foreign judgement has a certain binding effect). Enforcement is also subject to the effect of any applicable bankruptcy, insolvency, reorganization, liquidation or moratorium as well as other similar laws affecting rights of creditors generally.

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF CIVIL LIABILITIES
Subsubsection Text: The recognition and enforcement of judgments of foreign courts in Poland is subject to limitations (i) specified in the relevant EU laws (including in particular Council Regulation (EC) Regulation (EU) No. 1215/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of December 12, 2012 on jurisdiction and the recognition and enforcement of judgments in civil and commercial matters if the judgment was issued in a Member State of the European Union); (ii) under international agreements, if a relevant bilateral/multilateral treaty provides for such enforcement (including in particular the Hague Convention of June 30, 2005 on Choice of Court Agreements); or (iii) on the basis of the rules of the Polish Code of Civil Procedure if (i) and (ii) above do not apply. There is currently no treaty between the United States and Poland providing for the reciprocal recognition and enforcement of judgments (other than arbitration awards) rendered in civil and commercial matters. Therefore, in such a case, the rules of the Polish Code of Civil Procedure apply. Under that procedure, any final and conclusive judgment against the Issuer or Guarantor with its registered office in Poland obtained in a court of the United States and arising out of or in relation to the obligations of the Issuer or Guarantors with its registered office in Poland, would be recognized ex lege in Poland, unless: - the judgment is not final and binding in the US; - the judgment was issued on an issue which is within the exclusive jurisdiction of Polish courts (such as matters relating to real property located in Poland); - the defendant who has not entered the dispute as to the essence of the disputed issue has not been served the complaint in the manner enabling the defendant to defend himself; - a party was deprived of the ability to defend itself in the course of the proceeding; - proceedings related to the same claim between the same parties had been commenced in Poland before it was initiated in the US court; - the judgment is contrary to a previously issued final and binding judgment of a Polish court or of a foreign court judgment fulfilling the prerequisites for its recognition in Poland and was issued in proceedings related to the same claim between the same parties; or - the recognition of the judgment would be contrary to the fundamental principles of legal order of Poland (the public policy clause). Enforceability of any final and conclusive judgment against the Issuer or a given Guarantor with its registered office in Poland obtained in a court of the United States and arising out of or in relation to the obligations of the Issuer or Guarantors, further requires that a Polish court issues a decision confirming that given judgment of the US court is enforceable in Poland (which will be issued provided that given judgment is enforceable in the US and all the conditions referred to above are met). Once the motion to declare enforceability is considered and approved, the court issues a decision to grant an enforceability clause (klauzula wykonalności). Enforcement pursuant to such a decision may be initiated as soon as the decision granting the enforceability clause becomes final and binding. Finally, it should be noted that the enforcement actions conducted by the court executive officer (bailiff) may be challenged and, therefore, the enforcement of obligations sometimes may not be successful or may be lengthy, even if the US judgment is recognized and enforceable in Poland. 275 -----

Section Title: SERVICE OF PROCESS AND ENFORCEMENT OF CIVIL LIABILITIES
Subsubsection Text: The Issuer is incorporated under the laws of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg and the Guarantors are organized under the laws of Germany, the Netherlands, Poland and the United States. None of the members of board or other executives of the Issuer and the Non-US Guarantors are residents or citizens of the United States. Therefore, you may be unable to effect service of process within the United States on such directors, officers or executives. Furthermore, since the assets of the Issuer and each of the Non-US Guarantors, and their respective directors and officers are located outside the United States, any judgment obtained in the United States against the Issuer or a Non-US Guarantor or any such other person, including judgments with respect to the payment of principal, premium (if any) and interest on the Notes or any judgment of a US court predicated upon civil liabilities under US Federal or state securities laws, may not be collectible in the United States.

The consolidated financial statements of Mangrove LuxCo III S.à r.l. and its subsidiaries as of and for the years ended December 31, 2022 and 2023, which were prepared on the basis of the International Financial Reporting Standards, as adopted by the EU (“IFRS”), have been audited by KPMG Audit, S.à r.l. Luxembourg (“KPMG”), independent auditors, as stated in their reports reproduced in this Offering Memorandum. . 276 -----

Each purchaser of the Notes from the Initial Purchasers will be furnished with a copy of this Offering Memorandum and any amendments or supplements to this Offering Memorandum. Each person receiving this Offering Memorandum and any related amendments or supplements to the Offering Memorandum acknowledges that: - such person has been afforded an opportunity to request from the Issuer and has received and reviewed all additional information considered by it to be necessary to verify the accuracy and completeness of the information contained herein; - such person has not relied on information provided or representations made by the Initial Purchasers or any person affiliated with the Initial Purchasers in connection with its investigation of the accuracy of such information or its investment decision; and - except as provided pursuant to the first bullet above, no person has been authorized to give any information or to make any representation concerning the Notes offered hereby other than those contained herein and, if given or made, such other information or representation should not be relied upon as having been authorized by the Issuer or the Initial Purchasers. For so long as any of the Notes are “restricted securities” within the meaning of the Rule 144(a)(3) under the US Securities Act, the Issuer will, during any period in which the Issuer is neither subject to the reporting requirements of Section 13 or 15(d) of the US Exchange Act, nor exempt from the reporting requirements under Rule 12g3-2(b) of the US Exchange Act, provide to the holder or beneficial owner of such restricted securities or to any prospective purchaser of such restricted securities designated by such holder or beneficial owner, in each case upon the written request of such holder, beneficial owner or prospective purchaser, the information required to be provided by Rule 144A(d)(4) under the US Securities Act. Pursuant to the Indenture and so long as the Notes are outstanding, anyone who has received this Offering Memorandum may, following the Issue Date, obtain a copy of the Indenture, the Notes, the Guarantees, the Security Documents and the Intercreditor Agreement, without charge, in each case, by writing to the Paying Agent. Copies of such documents are also available at the specified office of the Paying Agent and the registered office of the Issuer. Pursuant to the Indenture and so long as the Notes are outstanding, the Issuer will furnish periodic information to holders of the Notes. See “Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants—Reports.” Copies of the Indenture will be available to be inspected and obtained by holders of the Notes at the specified office of the Paying Agent during normal business hours. 277 -----

Subsection Title: LISTING AND GENERAL INFORMATION Listing Information
Subsubsection Text: Application will be made to the Authority for the listing of and permission to deal in the Notes on the Official List of the Exchange. There can be no assurance that the Notes will be listed on the Official List of the Exchange, that such permission to deal in the Notes will be granted or that such listing will be maintained. The admission of the Notes to the Official List of the Exchange shall not constitute a warranty or representation by the Authority as to the competence of the service providers to, or any other party connected with, the Issuer, the adequacy and accuracy of information contained in this Offering Memorandum or the suitability of the Issuer for investment or for any other purpose. The Notes are only intended to be offered in the primary market to, and held by, investors who are particularly knowledgeable in investment matters. A copy of this Offering Memorandum will be available for inspection at the offices of the Issuer during normal business hours for a period of 14 days following the listing of the Notes on the Official List of the Exchange.

The Issuer expects that the Notes sold pursuant to Regulation S and the Notes sold pursuant to Rule 144A will be accepted for clearance and settlement through the facilities of Euroclear and Clearstream. Except as disclosed in this Offering Memorandum: - there has been no material adverse change in in the financial or trading condition or the capitalization of the Issuer since March 31, 2024, the date of the Issuer’s most recent consolidated financial statements; and - none of the Issuer or the Guarantors or any of their respective subsidiaries is involved in any litigation, arbitration, governmental or administrative proceedings which would, individually or in the aggregate, have a material adverse effect on its results of operations, condition (financial or other) or general affairs and, so far as the Issuer, the Guarantors and their respective subsidiaries are aware, no such proceeding is pending or threatened. The Issuer accepts responsibility for the information contained in this Offering Memorandum. The information contained in this Offering Memorandum is in accordance with the facts and does not omit anything likely to affect the import of this Offering Memorandum. This Offering Memorandum includes particulars given in compliance with the Listing Rules of the Authority for the purpose of giving information with regard to the Notes and comprises this Offering Memorandum. The Listing Agent is acting for the Issuer and for no one else in connection with the issue and listing of the Notes and will not be responsible to anyone other than the Issuer. The Listing Agent has not separately verified the information contained in this Offering Memorandum. Accordingly, the Listing Agent does not make any representation or recommendation and does not give any warranty, express or implied, regarding the accuracy, adequacy, reasonableness or completeness of the information contained herein or in any further information, notice or other document which may at any time be supplied in connection with the Notes or their distribution and the Listing Agent accepts no responsibility or liability therefor. The Listing Agent neither undertakes to review the financial condition or affairs of the Issuer during the life of the arrangements contemplated by this Offering Memorandum nor to advise any investor or potential investor in the Notes of any information coming to the attention of the Listing Agent. 279 -----

The Issuer has obtained all necessary consents, approvals and authorizations (if any) in connection with the issue of the Notes. The issue of the Notes was approved by the Issuer prior to the Issue Date.

Subsubsection Title: Issuer
Subsubsection Text: The Issuer is incorporated under the name Mangrove LuxCo III S.à r.l. as a private limited liability company (société à responsabilité limitée) under the laws of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg. It is registered with the Luxembourg Trade and Companies Register (Registre de Commerce et des Sociétés Luxembourg) under number B 236258. The Issuer’s LEI is 549300GLJSZN1PU7T586. The Issuer’s registered office is at 2, rue Edward Steichen, L-2540 Luxembourg, Grand Duchy of Luxembourg. The issued nominal share capital of the Issuer amounts to €12,000 and its corporate object is the acquisition, holding and disposal of interests in Luxembourg and/or in foreign companies and undertakings, as well as the administration, development and management of such interests. The Issuer may provide loans and financing in any other kind or form, or grant guarantees or security in any other kind or form, for the benefit of the companies and undertakings forming part of the group of which the Issuer is a member. The Issuer may also invest in real estate, in intellectual property rights or any other movable or immovable assets in any kind or form. The Issuer may borrow in any kind or form and issue bonds, notes or any other debt instruments as well as warrants or other share subscription rights. In a general fashion, the Issuer may carry out any commercial, industrial or financial operation, which it may deem useful in the accomplishment and development of its object.

It is registered with the trade register of the Dutch Chamber of Commerce under number 09067358. Its registered business address is at Vlijstraat 25, 7005 BN Doetinchem, the Netherlands. Fundamental information about the Group #### 1.1 Company information Mangrove LuxCo III S.à r.l., Luxembourg, hereinafter also referred to as "Mangrove LuxCo III" or the "company" is a public limited liability company (Société à responsabilité limitée) incorporated under the laws of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, having its registered office at 2, rue Edward Steichen, L-2540 Luxembourg, and registered with the Luxembourg Trade and Companies Register (Registre de Commerce et des Sociétés Luxembourg) with registration number B236258. Sole shareholder of the company is Mangrove LuxCo II S.à r.l., Luxembourg, which itself is a direct subsidiary of Galapagos LuxCo I S.à r.l., Luxembourg. The Company was incorporated on July 11, 2019. The Beneficial Owner (investor) is Triton Fund IV L.P which is owner of Mangrove LuxCo III. In the following, Mangrove LuxCo III and its consolidated direct and indirect subsidiaries is referred to as "Mangrove Group" or “the Group”. #### 1.2 Description of the business The Mangrove Group is a leading global manufacturer of heat exchangers and other cooling & heating products. The Group is active in multiple end markets such as Data Center, HVAC (Heating, Ventilation, Air Conditioning) & Refrigeration, Oil & Gas, Chemicals, Power & Energy, Transportation, Heavy & Light Equipment, Food & Beverage. In those markets, the Group services a broad, diversified, and long-standing customer base in more than 130 countries. #### 1.3 Acquisition of Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. and its subsidiaries and successful Refinancing on October 9, 2019 With an effective date October 9, 2019, Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l., Luxembourg, a 100 percent subsidiary of Mangrove LuxCo III, bought 100 percent of the shares in Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l., Luxembourg and all its subsidiaries (together “Galapagos BidCo Group”). Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l., Luxembourg, was 100 percent shareholder of the shares in Kelvion Finance GmbH, Germany including all of its subsidiaries (together “Kelvion Group”) and in ENEXIO Management GmbH, Germany including all of its subsidiaries (together “ENEXIO Group”) at the acquisition date. Before the acquisition of Galapagos BidCo Group, the Company did not have any operational activities. The Acquisition was consummated in connection with the balance sheet restructuring transaction of the Galapagos Group, the former shareholder of Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l., which has resulted in a major recapitalization of the operating business of the Mangrove LuxCo III, Mangrove LuxCo IV and the newly acquired subsidiaries (collectively, the “Mangrove Group”), a deleveraging of the Mangrove Group’s balance sheet and access to new debt facilities and instruments with longer tenors (the “Restructuring”). In connection with the Restructuring, the Company issued EUR 356,233,492 in aggregate principal amount of 7.775 percent senior secured fixed rate notes due on October 9, 2025 (the “New Notes”). In preparation of the aforesaid acquisition of Galapagos BidCo Group the Company incorporated or acquired the following direct and indirect subsidiaries: Incorporation of Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l., Luxembourg on July 11, 2019, and indirectly via the participation in Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l. the following holding entities in Germany were acquired on October 9, 2019: Mangrove GermanCo I GmbH, Germany and Mangrove GermanCo II GmbH, Germany. In the following, Mangrove LuxCo III and its consolidated direct and indirect subsidiaries is referred to as "Mangrove Group" or “the Group”. ----- ## 2. Reporting principles #### 2.1 Going-concern basis of accounting ###### Preparation of Condensed consolidated financial statements With effective date December 21, 2022, the Group agreed with the lenders to reset the financial covenants, to which the Actual 2023 met sufficient headroom. Based on the good start to the year in Q1 2024, management of the Group expects the financial performance for the full year to exceed budget. With current market conditions and business performance, the Group does not see any current risk to complying with future covenant requirements and consequently the management does not see any risk to the going concern of the Group. Based on actual Q1 2024 performance and current forward planning the Group anticipate they will currently be in the position to meet future financial obligations.

The Group is in the process of refinancing all long-term financing instruments: Revolving Credit Facility, Senior Guarantee Facility, and bonds – which it started in May 2024. Completion of the refinancing is planned for Q3 2024. The management of the Group currently expects that the Group will be able to meet its covenants. Therefore, the Condensed consolidated financial statements of Group, for Q1 2024, have been prepared on a going-concern basis. #### 2.2 Basis of preparation Pursuant to clause 4.03(a)(2) of the Indenture, dated October 09, 2019, between the Company and GLAS Trustees Limited (as Trustee), Global Loan Agency Services Limited (as Paying Agent), GLAS SAS (as Registrar and Transfer Agent) and GLAS Trust Corporation Limited (as Security Agent) (the “Mangrove Notes Indenture”), the Company is required to set up Condensed consolidated Financial Statements. #### 2.3 Group accounting principles and methods This Condensed consolidated financial report ending 31 March 2024 has been prepared in accordance with IAS 34 (“Interim Financial Reporting”), which governs interim financial reporting under International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) issued by the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB), London, which are endorsed by the European Union, and the Interpretations of the IFRS Interpretations Committee (IFRIC) in effect at the reporting date. As these are Condensed consolidated financial statements, they do not include all the information required by IFRS for full consolidated financial statements at the end of a financial year. The comparable Condensed consolidated Statement of Financial Position refers to the consolidated Statement of Financial Position as of December 31, 2023. The comparable Condensed consolidated Statement of Profit and Loss Statement as well as the comparable Condensed consolidated Cash Flow Statement, refer to the three months ended March 31, 2023. Reference should be made as appropriate to the Notes to the consolidated Financial Statements for the fiscal year 2023, particularly with regard to the main recognition and measurement principles, except where financial reporting standards have been applied for the first time in 2024 or accounting principles have changed. Sales-related and cyclical items are accrued throughout the year, insofar as they are significant. The interim Financial Statements are prepared in euros (EUR). All amounts, including the comparative figures, are presented in thousands of euros (EUR thousand). Due to rounding, figures presented may result in differences of EUR 1 thousand in certain cases. ----- #### 2.4 Presentation of the condensed consolidated Financial Statements For information on presentation principles, estimates, assumptions, and significant judgements that have the greatest impact on the amounts recognised in these condensed consolidated statements for the period January 1 to March 31, 2024, please refer to corresponding explanations in consolidated Financial Statements of Mangrove Group as of December 31, 2023. #### 2.5 Accounting regulations applied for the first time in the year 2024 The following standards and amendments to existing standards of possible relevance to the Group, which were adopted into EU law (endorsement mechanism) which are effective since January 1 2024, have not been applied early, but are applied by the Group since start of the fiscal year 2024. - **Amendments to IAS 1 (Effective January 1, 2024) Classification of Liabilities as Current or Non-current: The amendments to IAS 1 only affect the presentation of liabilities in the statement of financial position. They clarify that a liability is classified as non-current if the entity has a substantive right at the reporting date to defer settlement of the liability for at least twelve months after the reporting date. The mere existence of a substantial right is sufficient; the company does not have to intend to exercise this right. This change did not result in a significant effect on the Condensed consolidated financial statements. Non-current Liabilities with Covenants: The supplementary amendment to IAS 1 clarifies that if the right to defer payment is linked to the fulfilment of conditions that must be met within twelve months of the balance sheet date, these conditions have no influence on the classification as current or non-current. Extended disclosures on liabilities classified as non-current with covenants are required for risk assessment. This change did also not result in a significant change on the Condensed consolidated financial statements. - **Amendments to IFRS 16 (Effective January 1, 2024) Lease Liability in a Sale and Leaseback: The objective of the Amendments is to specify how a seller-lessee subsequently measures sale and leaseback transactions that satisfy the requirements in IFRS 15 Revenue from Contracts with Customers to be accounted for as a sale. The lease liability must be measured in such a way that no gain or loss arises on subsequent measurement in relation to the retained right-of-use asset. There are no material effects on the Condensed consolidated financial statements. - **Amendments to IAS7 and IFRS7 (Effective January 1, 2024) Supplier Finance Arrangements: The amendments introduce two new disclosure objectives – one in IAS 7 and another in IFRS 7 – for a company to provide information about its supplier finance arrangements that would enable users (investors) to assess the effects of these arrangements on the company’s liabilities and cash flows, and the company’s exposure to liquidity risk. There are no material effects on the Condensed consolidated financial statements. #### 2.6 International Tax Reform – Pillar Two Model Rules The Mangrove Group has adopted "International Tax Reform - Pillar Two Model Rules” (Amendments to IAS 12) upon their release on 23 May 2023. The amendments provide a temporary mandatory exception from deferred tax accounting for the top-up tax, which is effective immediately, and require new disclosures about the Pillar Two exposure, which are addressed in section "Income Taxes - Global minimum top-up tax". ----- The mandatory exception applies retrospectively. However, because no new legislation to implement the top-up tax was enacted or substantively enacted at the 31 March 2024, in any jurisdiction in which the Mangrove Group operates and no related deferred tax was recognised at that date, the retrospective application has no impact on the Mangrove Group 's Condensed consolidated financial statements. The Mangrove Group has determined that the global minimum top-up tax - which is required to pay under Pillar Two legislation - is an income tax in the scope of IAS 12. The Group has applied a temporary mandatory relief from deferred tax accounting for the impacts of the top-up tax and accounts for it as a current tax when it is incurred. #### 2.7 Interim financial reporting principles These interim Financial Statements present a true and fair view of the Group's results of operations, financial position, and net assets in the reporting period. The preparation of interim Financial Statements requires management to make certain estimates and assumptions that may affect the Group's assets, liabilities, provisions, and deferred tax assets and liabilities, as well as its income and expenses. Although management makes such estimates and assumptions carefully and in good faith, actual amounts may differ from the estimates used in these interim Financial Statements. Factors that may cause amounts to fall below expectations include deterioration in the global economic situation, movements in exchange rates and interest rates, as well as material litigation and changes in environmental or other legislations and errors in internal operating processes. The loss of key customers and rising borrowing costs may also adversely affect the Group’s future performance. ## 3. Basis of consolidation As of March 31, 2024, the Mangrove Group comprises 4 companies domiciled in Luxembourg and 50 foreign companies (totalling 54 as at year-end). Subsidiaries are entities controlled by the company. Control is assumed, when the following three criteria are fulfilled: (1) the parent company holds decision-making power over the relevant activities of the investee, (2) the company has rights to variable returns from the investee and (3) the parent company can use its decision-making power to affect the variable returns. The fulfilment of these criteria is assessed based on corporate governance and potential supplementary agreements. Companies that are dormant or do not have significant impact on the financial position and results of operation of the Group are not included in the Condensed consolidated financial statements. A total of two companies are not consolidated. The aggregate assets, equity, revenues, and earnings of these companies are not material to the Condensed consolidated financial statements. The subsidiaries are recognised at cost as non-current other financial assets. Management deems the influence to the Group as absolutely insignificant and hence, the disclosure required under IFRS has not been made due to materiality reason. The disclosure of this information is not suitable to communicate additional information. ## 4. Financial Covenants The Group has entered into the following financing agreements in the course of financing the acquisition of Galapagos BidCo Group: - € 65,000,000 Revolving Credit Facility Agreement (“RCF”, “RCF Facility Agreement”) ----- - € 260,000,000 Senior Guarantee Facility Agreement (“SGF”, “SGF Facility Agreement”) - € 234,921,656.23 Cash Collateral Loan Agreement (“Cash Cover Loan Agreement”) - € 84,640,713.21 Multilateral Guarantee Facility Agreement (“MGFA”) - €356,233,492 Senior Secured Fixed Rate Notes The RCF Facility Agreement, the SGF (together, the “Facilities”), the Cash Cover Loan Agreement and the MGFA were entered into by the Company as parent and certain of its subsidiaries (as borrowers and guarantors). On May 27, 2020, the process of refinancing the Group’s guarantee and “Letter of Credit” portfolio was completed, and the associated cash cover loan was fully repaid. With effective date December 21, 2022, the Group agreed with the lenders to reset the financial covenants set forth in the facility agreements and make certain additional amendments including, but not limited to, a reduction of the total commitments under and as defined in the SGF from EUR 260 million to EUR 190 million. The amended Facilities provide for the following financial covenants: a) **Minimum EBITDA[1]** – (consolidated EBITDA (normalized Earnings before interest, taxation, depreciation, and amortization) as defined in the RCF Facility Agreement) - the Group shall be required to meet a minimum amount of EBITDA in respect of each relevant period. The minimum EBITDA covenant amount is €72,600,000 (the Minimum EBITDA Amount, as amended) as of March 31, 2024. b) **Total net leverage – the Group shall be required not to exceed a certain leverage ratio in respect of each relevant period (such ratio based on consolidated total net debt (i.e., the aggregate amount of cash and cash equivalents minus financial indebtedness of the Group as defined in the RCF Facility Agreement) to consolidated EBITDA). The total required net leverage ratio covenant (as amended) is 5.30 as of March 31, 2024. c) **Minimum liquidity – the Group shall be required to provide reporting on its liquidity (i.e., freely available cash and cash equivalents as defined by the RCF Facility Agreement). If liquidity is less than €25,000,000 (but equal to, or greater than €20,000,000), a “Soft Minimum Liquidity Breach” shall occur. If liquidity is less than €20,000,000 a “Hard Minimum Liquidity Breach” shall occur. The financial covenants set out in paragraphs (a) and (b) above shall be tested on a quarterly basis. The minimum liquidity set out in paragraph (c) shall be tested on a monthly basis. As of March 31, 2024, the Group complied with all financial covenants as set out above. According to the financing agreements the Facilities mature on the date falling four years from the date of acquisition of Galapagos BidCo Group (i.e., October 8, 2023), subject to an automatic one-year extension (i.e., October 9, 2024). The extension occurs provided that the annual financial statements delivered by the Issuer for the period ending December 31, 2023, do not contain any qualification as to the ability of the New Group to continue as a going concern (unless that qualification arises as a result of the RCF maturing on the Original Termination Date). As the annual financial statements for the period ending December 31, 2023, did not contain such qualification, which was reported to the Agent of the Facilities on 12 June 2023. In Q1 2024 the maturity of the facilities had been extended to June 9[th], 2025. The interest rates have been increased by 0,5%. ## 5. Financial risk management As a global Group, Mangrove Group is in its normal course of business exposed to various financial risks such as liquidity, currency, interest rate, procurement prices, and credit risks that could affect its net assets, financial position, and results of operations. It is the company’s policy to use derivative financial instruments to reduce the risks associated with operating 1 EBITDA LTM – last twelve months, for Q1 2024 it’s a period from April 01, 2023, till March 31, 2024 ----- activities and the resulting financing requirements. The Group does not invest in derivatives for trading purposes. The various risks and the current exposure have not significantly changed compared to the risks described within Note 3 to the Consolidated Financial Statements of Mangrove Group as of December 31, 2023 (we refer to page 66 of the Consolidated Financial Statements 2023 of the Group). ## 6. Capital reserve Based on the shareholder resolution dated March 11, 2020, the sole shareholder Mangrove LuxCo II S.à. r.l. contributed EUR 140,000,000 to the capital contribution account (account 115 “apport en capitaux propres non rémunéré par des titres” of the Luxembourg Standard Chart of Accounts) of the Company. Pursuant to a shareholder resolution as of December 22, 2020, the Company’s sole shareholder Mangrove LuxCo II S.à. r.l. acknowledged to convert an aggregated amount of EUR 136,528,353 into tracking preferred equity certificates (“TPECs”). The Company issued 13,652,835,300 TPECs, holding a value of EUR 0.01 each, representing a total issue of EUR 136,528,353. The subscription of the TPECs was dated December 31, 2020. Following the TPECs issuance and as part of the required security package in relation to certain facilities agreements entered into by the Company (including a EUR 65 million revolving facility, a EUR 190 million facilities agreement and a senior secured note indenture), the Company granted the TPECs pledge to the benefit of the Security Agent and entered into the TPECs pledge agreement for the purpose thereof. The capital reserve as of March 31, 2024, amounts to EUR 3,471,647 (as of December 31, 2023: EUR 3,471,647). ## 7. Tracking preferred equity certificates / Shareholder loan The company acquired Galapagos BidCo Group on October 9, 2019. Financing of the acquisition was done inter alia by a bridge loan of EUR 140,000 thousand provided to the Company by the indirect shareholder Mangrove LuxCo I S. à r.l. on October 9, 2019. The final maturity date for the loan is four years after the date of the transaction, i.e., October 8, 2023. The loan does not accrue interest for the first six months after the transaction date. After the transaction date Mangrove LuxCo I S.à r.l. transferred the loan agreement and the EUR 140.000.000 loan receivable to its subsidiary Mangrove LuxCo II S.à r.l. which is the sole shareholder of the Company. On March 11, 2020, Mangrove LuxCo II S.à r.l. contributed the loan receivable in the full amount of EUR 140,000 thousand to the capital contribution account (account 115 “apport en capitaux proprex non rémunéré par des titres” of the Luxembourg Standard Chart of Accounts) of the Company. With Shareholder resolution as of December 22, 2020, the sole shareholder Mangrove LuxCo II S.à r.l. to convert an aggregated amount of EUR 136,528.353 thousand into tracking preferred equity certificates (“TPECS”). The company issued 13,652,835,300 TPECS, having a value of EUR 0.01 each, representing a total issue of EUR 136,528.353 thousand. As of March 31, 2024, TPECs are recognized at EUR 173,410.429 thousand including an interest of EUR 2,829.929 thousand (March 31, 2023: EUR 2,798.831 thousand). Following the TPECs issuance and as security package in relation to certain facilities agreements entered into by the Company (including a EUR 65 million revolving facility, a EUR 190 million facilities agreement and a senior secured note indenture), the Company granting the TPECs Pledge to the benefit of the Security Agent and entered into the TPECs Pledge Agreement for the purpose thereof. These TPECs are junior to all other debt of the Group and cannot be withdrawn by the shareholder under the existing financing agreements. Therefore, these TPECs are equity like instruments and are being disclosed in the Condensed consolidated Statement of Financial Position of the Group between equity and liabilities and are summed up together with the equity to the line item “Equity and tracking preferred equity certificates / shareholder loan”. ----- ## 8. Financial instruments The following tables provide an overview of the composition of financial instruments as of March 31, 2024, by class within the meaning of IFRS 7 as well as by measurement category. Trade receivables´ measurement in accordance with IFRS 15 (Trade receivables) includes primarily capitalized contract costs, PoC-gross profit earned to date less progress billings. Other financial assets measured in accordance with other IFRS consist mainly lease liabilities measured in accordance with IFRS 16. The following financial instruments mostly fall under the amortized cost category as these are “hold” to collect contractual cash flows: trade receivables (not tendered), cash and other financial assets (e.g., other operating receivables). These financial assets measured at amortised cost meet the SPPI test. Other financial investments which include mainly derivatives are recognised under the Fair Value through profit and loss. The remeasurement of the investments has not revealed any significant changes to the book value. -----

Financial assets and liabilities that are measured at fair value, or for which a fair value is disclosed in the Notes to the Condensed consolidated financial statements, are required to be categorized according to the fair value hierarchy as described in the following. Categorization within the levels of the fair value hierarchy is based on the measurement of the underlying inputs: Level 1 inputs: quoted prices (unadjusted) in active markets for identical financial assets and liabilities. Level 2 inputs: quoted market prices that are observable as direct (prices) or indirect (derived from prices) inputs used to measure fair value and that are not quoted prices as defined by Level 1. Level 3 inputs: inputs that are not based on observable market data. The disclosure obligation under IAS 24 furthermore extends to transactions with persons who exercise a significant influence on the financial and business policies of the Mangrove Group. A significant influence on the financial and business policies of the Mangrove Group can hereby be based on a shareholding of 20 percent or more of Mangrove, a seat in the management board of Mangrove Group or another key management position on board either of the parent of Mangrove Group or on lower level holding company. Related parties of the Mangrove Group in accordance with IAS 24 primarily comprise the shareholders of the Mangrove and the subsidiaries of Mangrove Group, which are not consolidated due to materiality reasons. All transactions with related parties are conducted on an arm's length basis. As of the reporting date, no transactions between Mangrove Group companies and joint ventures or non-consolidated companies were occurred.

A major part of the lines is granted by a bank consortium (total line EUR 190 million, thereof EUR 88,1 million utilised). ## 14.Litigation A number of claims have been brought arising out of the financial restructuring of 2019 (the “Restructuring”). These have now either been irrevocably withdrawn (Luxembourg, NY) or the relevant Mangrove entities prevailed in now final and unappealable judgments (Germany, England) ----- The insolvency proceedings in respect of Galapagos SA remain contested as between Kebekus (Germany) and the Official Receiver (UK), however management (based on legal advice and the judgments in England and Germany) does not perceive there to be any risk to the efficacy of the restructuring nor of claims against Mangrove entities, as a result of such proceedings. Neither of the insolvency practitioners has suggested it will seek to assert a claim against any of the Mangrove entities and the types of claim that would be theoretically possible have already been resolved via the binding judgments noted above. ## 15.Global economic outlook 2024 As described in the section about the macroeconomic environment in this report, the Mangrove Group as a global engineering company considers global growth in gross GDP and the corresponding forecasts to be a benchmark for its own performance. The Group prepared its financial budget in the fourth quarter of FY 2023 and approved it mid-December 2023 as part of the update of its H5 Strategy in late 2023 as explained. The 2024 budget is based on the growth expectations according to the IMF World Economic Outlook (WEO) from October 2023 regarding the development of the global economy as well as estimates and expectations on the markets for heat exchange provided by a leading strategic consulting firm in 2023 and further external sources regarding outlook from the second half of 2023 on the development of key markets. For more details, please refer to chapter 7.3 of the management report in the Annual Financial Statements of the Group (Page 23 ff). ## 16.Events after the end of the reporting period End of April 2024, the Group announced a restructuring to lower the capacity in two German sites. The program impact around 150 employees. Following appropriate review and approvals the necessary provisions will be accrued in Q2 2024. In addition, the Group started the process of refinancing all long-term financing instruments (Revolving Credit Facility, Senior Guarantee Facility, and bonds) in Q2 2024. General information ##### 1.1 Company information Mangrove LuxCo III S.à r.l., Luxembourg, hereinafter also referred to as "Mangrove LuxCo III" or the "company" is a public limited liability company (Société à responsabilité limitée) incorporated under the laws of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, having its registered office at 2, rue Edward Steichen, L-2540 Luxembourg, and registered with the Luxembourg Trade and Companies Register (Registre de Commerce et des Sociétés Luxembourg) with registration number B236258. Sole shareholder of the company is Mangrove LuxCo II S.à r.l., Luxembourg, which itself is a direct subsidiary of Galapagos LuxCo I S.à r.l., Luxembourg. The Company was incorporated on July 11, 2019. The purpose of the Company is the acquisition, holding and disposal of interests in Luxembourg and/or foreign companies and undertakings as well as the administration, development and management of such interests. ##### 1.2 Acquisition of Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. and its subsidiaries and successful Refinancing on October 9, 2019 With an effective date October 9, 2019, Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l., Luxembourg, a 100 percent subsidiary of Mangrove LuxCo III, bought 100 percent of the shares in Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l., Luxembourg and all its subsidiaries (together “Galapagos BidCo Group”). Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l., Luxembourg, was 100 percent shareholder of the shares in Kelvion Finance GmbH, Germany including all of its subsidiaries (together “Kelvion Group”) and in ENEXIO Management GmbH, Germany including all of its subsidiaries (together “ENEXIO Group”) at the acquisition date. Before the acquisition of Galapagos BidCo Group, the Company did not have any operational activities. The Acquisition was consummated in connection with the balance sheet restructuring transaction of the Galapagos Group, the former shareholder of Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l., which has resulted in a major recapitalization of the operating business of the Mangrove LuxCo III, Mangrove LuxCo IV and the newly acquired subsidiaries (collectively, the “Mangrove Group”), a deleveraging of the Mangrove Group’s balance sheet and access to new debt facilities and instruments with longer tenors (the “Restructuring”). In connection with the Restructuring, the Company issued EUR 356,233,492 in aggregate principal amount of 7.775 percent senior secured fixed rate notes due on October 9, 2025 (the “New Notes”). In preparation of the aforesaid acquisition of Galapagos BidCo Group the Company incorporated or acquired the following direct and indirect subsidiaries: Incorporation of Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l., Luxembourg on July 11, 2019 and indirectly via the participation in Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l. the following holding entities in Germany were acquired on October 9, 2019: Mangrove GermanCo I GmbH, Germany and Mangrove GermanCo II GmbH, Germany. In the following, Mangrove LuxCo III and its consolidated direct and indirect subsidiaries is referred to as "Mangrove Group" or “the Group”. ##### 1.3 Description of the business The Mangrove Group is a leading global manufacturer of heat exchangers and other cooling & heating ----- products. The Group is active in multiple end markets such as Data Center, HVAC (Heating, Ventilation, Air Conditioning) & Refrigeration, Oil & Gas, Chemicals, Power & Energy, Transportation, Heavy & Light Equipment, Food & Beverage. In those markets, the Group services a broad, diversified, and long-standing customer base in more than 130 countries. ##### 1.4 Segment Reporting Mangrove Group operates through the four Kelvion segments, “Refrigeration Technologies” (“RT”), “Machine Cooling Systems” (“MCS”), “Plate Heat Exchangers” (“PHE”) and “Thermal Solutions” (“KTS”). ##### 1.5 The four segments of Mangrove Group The four segments of Mangrove Group focus on distinct technologies and product portfolios: - **Refrigeration Technologies (RT) focuses on component business for refrigeration applications with significant growth potential in the data center industry. RT supplies a wide range of standard and customized heat exchangers for cooling and removing heat from different types of data centers (hyperscale, colocation, modular etc.) using both air and liquid cooling methods. The data center market consists of cooling solutions such as air conditioning, chilling units, economizer systems, liquid cooling systems, control systems and includes services such as consulting, installation & deployment and maintenance and support. The heat exchanger solutions are also used in the refrigeration market in cold chain warehouses, supermarkets, non-residential buildings, and industrial production. Product offering includes air cooled condensers which reject heat from refrigeration systems and are often sold as part of a package of equipment with air coolers. RT’s customized air coolers are design-to-order units for industrial or OEM solutions for food processing and distribution facilities. Product offering includes also customized radiators and dry coolers which are mainly used for power and industrial applications. Improving the energy efficiency of commercial and industrial refrigeration equipment is essential for end users looking to reduce carbon footprint and operating costs. - **Machine Cooling Systems (MCS) is a leading player in heat exchangers for power and engine applications with substantial growth opportunities by leveraging its global installed base. MCS supplies heat exchangers for power generation, power transmission, large engine applications (marine and off-highway) and green applications like biomass, green hydrogen, or renewable energies. The business is mostly with OEM, e.g., for large engine manufacturers, but MCS also engages in smaller projects, like solar, wind or solar photovoltaic. Product offering includes charge air coolers, which cool down combustion-air coming from the turbocharger before entering the engine. MCS’ shell and tube double safety heat exchangers assure the secure handling of safety-critical media. Product offering also includes box coolers which are fitted in the sea chest of small and medium-sized vessels. - **Thermal Solutions (KTS), is Kelvion’s largest segment, focusing on project business for demanding applications in the Oil & Gas, Chemicals Industries and, like RT, with significant growth potential in high tech data center business as well as green tech applications such as hydrogen and Carbon Capture and Storage (CCS). KTS’ engineering expertise plays a key role in differentiation against competitors. High degree of geographical diversification with sites in all key region, including Europe, NAFTA, Latin America, China and MEA. Product offering includes air fin coolers typically used for very large cooling requirements in different industries, e.g., Oil & Gas and Chemicals, as well as air dryers which are used to remove humidity from an air stream in various process industries. KTS’ shell & tube heat exchangers are used to heat, cool, or condense water and other media in different process industries. The focus of the BU has shifted in the recent years from Oil & Gas and Petrochemicals to high and green tech business. ----- - **Plate Heat Exchangers (PHE) provides a broad range of plate heat exchangers for a wide variety of applications in terms of pressure and temperature demands for a wide range of customer industries, ranging from HVAC and Refrigeration to Food & Beverages, Chemicals, Power, and Industrials. Product offering includes fully welded plate heat exchangers which are used to save energy in demanding high pressure and temperature applications, as well as brazed plate heat exchangers, often used for environmentally friendly heat pump applications. PHE’s gasketed heat exchangers have the highest efficiency and flexibility and are used in a variety of industries as well as for heat recovery applications. In contrast to the project driven segment KTS, the three segments RT, MCS and PHE represent the component type business of the Group and form together “Kelvion Products” (“KP”). All four segments hold strong favorable market positions in their respective markets. MCS and PHE are among the TOP 3, RT amongst the Top 5 and KTS is niche-market leader. In addition to the above segments there is the fifth Service segment, which is a virtual segment, i.e., Service is not separated from the four segments but managed globally and centrally across segments. ----- ### 2. Reporting and Accounting principles ##### 2.1 Going-concern basis of accounting

With effective date December 21, 2022, the Group agreed with the lenders to reset the financial covenants, to which the Actual 2023 met sufficient headroom. Based on the good start to the year, management of the Group expects the financial performance for the full year to exceed budget. With current market conditions and business performance, the Group does not see any current risk to complying with future covenant requirements and consequently the management does not see any risk to the going concern of the Group. Based on actual planning the Group will be at every time and in the upcoming year in the position to meet all financial obligations. Therefore, the consolidated financial statements of Mangrove Group have been prepared on a going concern basis. ##### 2.2 Basis of presentation The presented consolidated financial statements cover the period from January 1, 2023 to December 31, 2023 with the prior period from January 1, 2022 to December 31, 2022. The consolidated financial statements of Mangrove Group - which comprise the consolidated statement of financial position, consolidated statement of profit or loss, consolidated statement of comprehensive income, consolidated statement of cash flows, consolidated statement of changes in equity and the notes to the consolidated financial statements - include Mangrove LuxCo III and its direct and indirect subsidiaries (hereinafter referred to as “Mangrove Group” or the “Group”). The consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with the IFRS Accounting standards as adopted by the EU. All IFRS Accounting standards and interpretations in effect for fiscal years beginning on or after January 1, 2023, have been applied. The consolidated financial statements are prepared in euro (EUR), the functional currency of the group, and presented in thousand of euros (EUR thousand) or in millions of euros (EUR million). Due to rounding, figures presented may result in differences of EUR 1 thousand in certain cases. To improve the clarity of presentation, various items in the consolidated balance sheet and consolidated income statement have been aggregated and are explained accordingly in the Notes. Assets and liabilities are classified into current and non-current items. Current assets are expected to be realised within 12 months after the reporting period and current liabilities are due to be settled within 12 months after the reporting period. The consolidated income statement is prepared using the cost of sales method. The consolidated statement of cash flows is prepared using the indirect method for cash flows from operating activities and the direct method for cash flows from investing and financing activities. The accounting and measurement principles are presented and explained in detail in note 2.8. The consolidated financial statements were authorised for issue by the Board of Managers on April 15, 2024. ##### 2.3 First-time adoption of new accounting pronouncements The Group applied for the first time all standards and amendments, which are effective for annual periods beginning on January 1, 2023. The impact on the consolidated financial statements of the Group is not significant. The Group has not early adopted any other standard, interpretation or amendments that were ----- issued but are not yet effective. ##### 2.3.1 Accounting regulations applied for the first time in the year 2023 - **Amendments to IFRS 17 (Effective January 1, 2023) IFRS 17 Insurance Contracts replaces IFRS 4 and for the first time sets out standard requirements for the recognition, measurement, presentation and disclosure of insurance contracts, reinsurance contracts and investment contracts with discretionary participation features. Under the IFRS 17 measurement model, groups of insurance contracts are measured based on the expected value of discounted cash flows with an explicit risk adjustment for non-financial risks as well as a contractual service margin that results in the recognition of profit in line with the provision of services. The amendments add a transition option aimed to improve the usefulness of comparative information presented on initial application of both IFRS 17 and IFRS 9 and introduce the option of applying a "classification overlay approach". This option can be applied when IFRS 17 and IFRS 9 are applied simultaneously for the first time and no "restatement" of a financial asset with regard to the comparative information of IFRS 9 in 2022 is made. - **Amendments to IAS 1 and IFRS Practice Statement 2 (Effective January 1, 2023) Disclosure of Accounting Policies: The amendment to IAS 1 requires that only "material" accounting policies are presented in the notes instead of significant accounting policies. It clarifyies that accounting policies related to immaterial transactions, other events or conditions are themselves immaterial and do not need to be disclosed; and that not all accounting policies relating to material transactions, other events or conditions are themselves material. The amendments to Practice Statement 2 accordingly indicate how the concept of materiality is applied to the disclosure of accounting policies. - **Amendments to IAS 8 (Effective January 1, 2023) Definition of Accounting Estimates: The amendments clarify how companies should distinguish changes in accounting policies from changes in accounting estimates, taking into account that changes in accounting policies are applied retrospectively, whereas changes in accounting estimates are applied prospectively. The changes to IAS 8 focus entirely on accounting estimates and clarify the definition of a change in accounting estimates by introducing a new definition of accounting estimates. Under the new definition, acounting estimates are “monetary amounts in financial statements that are subject to measurement uncertainty”. - **Amendments to IAS 12 (Effective January 1, 2023) Deferred Tax related to Assets and Liabilities arising from a Single Transaction: The amendment restricts the exemption from (initial) recognition of deferred taxes to the extent that it no longer applies to transactions in which companies recognise both an asset and a liability (for example, leases and asset retirement obligations). Deferred tax assets and liabilities must be recognised for such transactions in future, insofar as deductible and taxable temporary differences of the same amount arise. - **Amendments to IAS 12 (International Tax Reform – Pillar Two Model Rules) The KELVION group has adopted "International Tax Reform - Pillar Two Model Rules” ----- (Amendments to IAS 12) upon their release on 23 May 2023. The amendments provide a temporary mandatory exception from deferred tax accounting for the top-up tax, which is effective immediately, and require new disclosures about the Pillar Two exposure, which are addressed in section "Income Taxes - Global minimum top-up tax". The mandatory exception applies retrospectively. However, because no new legislation to implement the top-up tax was enacted or substantively enacted at 31 December 2022, in any jurisdiction in which the KELVION group operates and no related deferred tax was recognised at that date, the retrospective application has no impact on the KELVION group 's consolidated financial statements. ##### 2.3.2 Accounting regulations not applied in advance of their effective date The following standards and amendments to existing standards of possible relevance to the Group, which were adopted into EU law (endorsement mechanism) but are not yet mandatory, have not been applied early: - **Amendments to IAS 1 (Effective January 1, 2024) Classification of Liabilities as Current or Non-current: The amendments to IAS 1 only affect the presentation of liabilities in the statement of financial position. They clarify that a liability is classified as non-current if the entity has a substantive right at the reporting date to defer settlement of the liability for at least twelve months after the reporting date. The mere existence of a substantial right is sufficient; the company does not have to intend to exercise this right. Significant effects on the consolidated financial statements are not expected. Due to the COVID 19 pandemic, the date of initial application was postponed to 1 January 2024. Non-current Liabilities with Covenants: The supplementary amendment to IAS 1 clarifies that if the right to defer payment is linked to the fulfilment of conditions that must be met within twelve months of the balance sheet date, these conditions have no influence on the classification as current or non-current. Extended disclosures on liabilities classified as non-current with covenants are required for risk assessment. No material effects on the consolidated financial statements are expected. - **Ammendments to IFRS 16 (Effective January 1, 2024) Lease Liability in a Sale and Leaseback: The objective of the Amendments is to specify how a seller lessee subsequently measures sale and leaseback transactions that satisfy the requirements in IFRS 15 Revenue from Contracts with Customers to be accounted for as a sale. The lease liability must be measured in such a way that no gain or loss arises on subsequent measurement in relation to the retained right-of-use asset. The Amendments become effective for annual periods beginning on or after 1 January 2024, with earlier application permitted. No material effects on the consolidated financial statements are expected. These new standards and amendments to existing standards will be applied by the Group starting in fiscal 2024 or later. ##### 2.4 Accounting pronouncements not yet endorsed by the EU The IASB issued the following standards and amendments to existing standards of relevance to the Group, which still have to be adopted into EU law (endorsement mechanism) before they become applicable: ----- - **Amendments to IAS 21 (Effective January 1, 2025) Lack of Exchangeability: The amendment clarifies how to specify when a currency is exchangeable into another currency and how a company estimates a spot rate when a currency lacks exchangeability (e.g. due to government directives). A currency is exchangeable when an entity is able to exchange that currency for the other currency through markets or exchange mechanisms that create enforceable rights and obligations without undue delay at the measurement date and for a specified purpose. A currency is not exchangeable into the other currency if an entity can only obtain an insignificant amount of the other currency. When a currency is not exchangeable, a company needs to estimate a spot rate. The amendments apply for annual reporting periods beginning on or after 1 January 2025. Earlier application is permitted. Significant effects on the consolidated financial statements are not expected. - **Amendments to IAS 7 and IFRS 7 (Effective January 1, 2024) Supplier Finance Arrangements: The amendments introduce additional disclosure requirements for companies that enter into these arrangements. They do not change the classification and presentation of the related liabilities and cash flows. The amendments relate to disclosure requirements in connection with supplier financing arrangements (supply chain financing, trade payables financing or reverse factoring arrangements) and include - disclosures on terms and conditions of those financing arrangements, - the amounts of the liabilities that are the subject of such agreements, - for which part of these arrangements the suppliers have already received payments from the financiers, - under which item these liabilities are recognised in the balance sheet, - maturity date ranges and - information on liquidity risk. The amendments are to be applied for financial years beginning on or after 1 January 2024, but for the Group only after corresponding EU endorsement. Significant effects on the consolidated financial statements are not expected. ##### 2.5 Basis of consolidation

The consolidated financial statements comprise the financial statements of Mangrove LuxCo III and its direct and indirect subsidiaries as of December 31, 2023. The financial statements of the subsidiaries are generally prepared for the same reporting period as the parent company, except of the Indian subsidiary and the Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l., Luxembourg, consistently applying group IFRS accounting policies. The financial year ends due to local Indian commercial law on March 31, each year. This company was incorporated in the consolidated financial statements of Mangrove Group on the basis of interim financial statements. All intra-group balances and transactions, and any unrealised income and expenses arising from intra-group transactions, are eliminated. The consolidated financial statements of Mangrove Group include Mangrove LuxCo III and all material companies which Mangrove LuxCo III controls directly or indirectly. Companies are consolidated as of the date on which control is obtained by Mangrove LuxCo III. They are deconsolidated as of the date on which control is lost. In addition to the ultimate parent company, 54 (2022: 55 companies) were consolidated. ----- In May 2023, the former fully consolidated ENEXIO ACC GmbH, Bochum was sold and deconsolidated. The scope of consolidation changed as follows:
