The Group recognises loss allowances for expected credit losses (“ECLs”) on financial assets measured at amortised cost, debt investments measured at FVOCI and contract assets. The Group measures loss allowances at an amount equal to lifetime ECLs, except for the following, which are measured at 12-month (a) ECLs debt securities that are determined to have low credit risk at the reporting date; (b) and other debt securities and bank balances for which credit risk (i.e. the risk of default occurring over the expected life of the financial instrument) has not increased significantly since initial recognition. Loss allowances for trade receivables (including lease receivables) and contract assets are always measured at an amount equal to lifetime ECLs. When determining whether the credit risk of a financial asset has increased significantly since initial recognition and when estimating ECLs, the Group considers reasonable and supportable information that is relevant and available without undue cost or effort. This includes both quantitative and qualitative information and analysis, based on the Group’s historical experience and informed credit assessment, that includes forward-looking information. The Group assumes that the credit risk on a financial asset has increased significantly if it is more than 30 days past due. The Group considers a financial asset to be in default when (a) the debtor is unlikely to pay its credit obligations to the Group in full, without recourse by the Group to actions such as realising security (if any is held); or the financial asset is more than 90 days past due. At each reporting date, the Group assesses whether financial assets carried at amortised cost and debt securities at FVOCI are credit-impaired. A financial asset is ‘credit-impaired’ when one or more events that have a detrimental impact on the estimated future cash flows of the financial asset have occurred. Evidence that a financial asset is credit-impaired includes the following observable data: (a) significant financial difficulty of the debtor or it is probable that the debtor will enter bankruptcy or other financial reorganisation. Loss allowances for financial assets measured at amortised cost are deducted from the gross carrying amount of the assets. For debt securities at FVOCI, the loss allowance is charged to profit or loss and is recognised in OCI. The gross carrying amount of a financial asset is written off when the Group has no reasonable expectations of recovering a financial asset in its entirety or a portion thereof. The Group recognises loss allowances for ECLs on financial assets measured at amortised cost, debt investments measured at FVOCI and contract assets. The Group measures loss allowances at an amount equal to lifetime ECLs, except for the following, which are measured at 12-month (a) ECLs debt securities that are determined to have low credit risk at the reporting date; (b) and other debt securities and bank balances for which credit risk (i.e. the risk of default occurring over the expected life of the financial instrument) has not increased significantly since initial recognition. Loss allowances for trade receivables (including lease receivables) and contract assets are always measured at an amount equal to lifetime ECLs. When determining whether the credit risk of a financial asset has increased significantly since initial recognition and when estimating ECLs, the Group considers reasonable and supportable information that is relevant and available without undue cost or effort. This includes both quantitative and qualitative information and analysis, based on the Group’s historical experience and informed credit assessment, that includes forward-looking information. The Group assumes that the credit risk on a financial asset has increased significantly if it is more than 30 days past due. The Group considers a financial asset to be in default when (a) the debtor is unlikely to pay its credit obligations to the Group in full, without recourse by the Group to actions such as realising security (if any is held); or the financial asset is more than 90 days past due. At each reporting date, the Group assesses whether financial assets carried at amortised cost and debt securities at FVOCI are credit-impaired. A financial asset is ‘credit-impaired’ when one or more events that have a detrimental impact on the estimated future cash flows of the financial asset have occurred. Evidence that a financial asset is credit-impaired includes the following observable data: (a) significant financial difficulty of the debtor or it is probable that the debtor will enter bankruptcy or other financial reorganization. Loss allowances for financial assets measured at amortised cost are deducted from the gross carrying amount of the assets. For debt securities at FVOCI, the loss allowance is charged to profit or loss and is recognised in OCI. The gross carrying amount of a financial asset is written off when the Group has no reasonable expectations of recovering a financial asset in its entirety or a portion thereof.

Subsection Title: Recognition and measurement on deferred tax assets and income tax uncertainties
Subsubsection Text: Mangrove Group operates in a large number of countries and is therefore subject to different tax jurisdictions. Calculating tax liabilities requires management to make various estimates. Management believes that it has made a reasonable estimate of tax uncertainties. However, no assurance can be given that the actual outcome of these uncertainties will correspond to the estimates made. Any deviations may have an impact on the level of tax liabilities or deferred taxes in the year of the decision. When assessing the recoverability of deferred tax assets, management judges the extent to which realisation of the deferred tax assets is sufficiently likely. The question of whether the deferred tax assets can actually be realised depends on whether sufficient future taxable income can be generated against ----- which the temporary differences or tax loss carryforwards can be offset. Management therefore analyses the times at which the deferred tax liabilities reverse, and expected future taxable income. Management forecasts whether deferred tax assets can be realised on the basis of expected future taxable income. Deferred tax assets decline if the estimate of planned taxable income decreases, tax benefits available as a result of tax strategies are reduced, or the amount or timing of future tax benefits is restricted by changes in law (see Note 6.7). IFRIC 23 clarifies the application of the recognition and measurement requirements of IAS 12 when there is uncertainty about the income tax treatment. For recognition and measurement, estimates and assumptions must be made, e.g. whether an estimate is made separately or together with other uncertainties, a most likely amount or expected amount for the uncertainty is used and whether changes have occurred compared to the previous period. The risk of detection from tax authorities is irrelevant for the recognition of uncertain balance sheet items. Accounting is based on the assumption that the tax authorities are investigating the matter in question and that they have all relevant information at their disposal. Subsection Title: Recognition and calculation of construction contracts
Subsubsection Text: Identification and definition of performance obligation, as well as timing of revenue recognition are based on managements estimates. Further the recognition of construction contracts using the percentage of completion method is based on management’s estimates of the cost to complete the contracts. Changes in estimates or differences between the estimated cost and the actual cost to complete have a direct effect on recognised earnings from construction contracts. The operating units continuously review the estimates and adjust them if required. Changes in estimates or differences between the estimated cost and the actual cost to complete have a direct effect on recognised earnings from construction contracts. The operating units continuously review the estimates and adjust them if required.

In some cases, Mangrove Group companies are parties to litigation. The outcome of this litigation could have a material effect on Mangrove Group’s net assets, financial position, and results of operations. Management regularly analyses current information on these legal disputes and recognises provisions for probable obligations including legal costs. Both internal counsels and external lawyers make this assessment. When deciding on the need to recognise provisions, management takes into account the probability of an unfavorable outcome and its ability to estimate the amount of the obligation with sufficient reliability. Subsection Title: Determination of fair value of financial instruments
Subsubsection Text: ----- The level of management judgement, required in establishing the fair value of financial instruments for which there is a quoted price in an active market, is usually minimal. Similarly there is little subjectivity or judgement required for instruments valued using valuation models which are standard across the industry and where all input parameters are quoted in active markets (e.g. for foreign exchange rate derivatives). The level of subjectivity and degree of management judgement required is more significant for those instruments valued using models and techniques where some or all of the parameter inputs are less or not observable. Management judgement is required in the selection and application of appropriate parameters, assumptions and modelling techniques. This applies especially in establishing the fair value of the embedded derivatives. ----- ### 3. Financial risk management Mangrove Group applies guidelines and instruments, to manage and hence largely limit or hedge financial risks throughout the Group. The objectives with regard to protecting assets, eliminating gaps in security, and improving efficiency in identifying and analyzing risks are clearly defined, as are the relevant organizational structures, powers, and responsibilities. The guidelines are based on the principles of system security, separation of functions, transparency, and immediate documentation. Mangrove Group is exposed to currency, interest rate, commodity price, credit, and liquidity risk in the course of its ordinary activities. Mangrove Group’s financial risk management aims to reduce this risk through the appropriate use of derivative and non-derivative hedging instruments and avoids on principal concentrations of risk. Mangrove Group’s financial risk management aims to reduce this risk through the appropriate use of derivative and non-derivative hedging instruments and avoids on principal concentrations of risk.

The Mangrove Group has significant assets and liabilities outside the Eurozone, particularly in China, USA, South Africa, Brazil, India, Poland, Czech Republic as well as Great Britain. These assets and liabilities are denominated in local currency. When the net asset values are converted into euro, the currency fluctuations result in period to period changes in those net asset values. The equity position of the Group reflects these changes in net asset values. The Mangrove Group also has transactional currency exposures which arise mostly from sales or purchases in currencies other than the functional currency. In order to mitigate the impact of currency exchange rate fluctuations for the operating business, all companies are required to economically hedge foreign currency items, as they arise in order to fix prices on the basis of hedging rates. Currency risks are economically hedged for recognized assets and liabilities, unrecognized firm commitments, and highly probable forecasted transactions, when denominated in another currency than the functional currency of the company. The hedging periods are determined by the maturity of the economical hedged items and are usually up to twelve months but may also exceed that period significantly in exceptional cases. Hedge Accounting in the sense of IFRS 9 is not applied. All economic hedging transactions - to the extent being legally permissible - are handled by Mangrove Group Treasury. The group companies report their exposures to Group Treasury, which enters on behalf of the respective companies into corresponding derivative transactions with banks. The economical hedging transactions are closely monitored by Mangrove Group Treasury. Besides the hedging requirement, currency fluctuations may affect business opportunities outside the Eurozone. The Mangrove Group is exposed to interest rate risks which mainly relate to debt obligations, as the Group borrows funds at both fixed and floating interest rates. The interest rate risk is monitored by using the cash flow sensitivity of the Group’s cash flows due to floating interest loans. The interest rate risk is monitored by using the cash flow sensitivity of the Group’s cash flows due to floating interest loans.

As part of its operating activities, Mangrove Group requires various raw materials, whose purchase prices can be subject to substantial fluctuations depending on the market situation. Long-term supply agreements have been entered into with various suppliers in order to reduce commodity price risk. ----- As part of its operating activities, Mangrove Group requires various raw materials, whose purchase prices ----- can be subject to substantial fluctuations depending on the market situation. The credit risk refers to the risk that counterparties may default on their contractual obligations resulting in a financial loss to the Mangrove Group. In general Mangrove Group has adopted a policy of only dealing with creditworthy counterparties and obtaining sufficient collateral in form of advanced payments where appropriate, as a means of mitigating the risk of financial loss from defaults. The Mangrove Group monitors the exposure and the credit ratings of its existing and potential counterparties continuously. Companies active in the component business use credit limits to assess their counterparty default risk, whereas a maximum risk limit is defined for each party. In most cases this limit is derived from recognized credit rating agencies and credit default swaps if available. Appropriate action is taken if the individual limit is exceeded. Companies active in the project business ascertain the financial standing of potential customers on a case by case basis using all available financial information. Before a project order is accepted the assessment is additionally reviewed in an internal risk board procedure. An appropriate credit management, including a credit insurance, is also conducted to reduce credit risk. In the case of export transactions, confirmed and unconfirmed letters of credit are used alongside sureties, guarantees, and cover notes, including from export credit agencies. Trade receivables consist of a large number of customers, spread across different industries and regions. Hence there is no concentration of risk. Valuation allowances take account of specific credit risks. Derivative financial instruments are concluded only with financial institutions with high credit-ratings assigned by international credit-rating agencies so as to reduce the credit risk involved. The Mangrove Group does not have any critical credit risk exposure to any single counterparty or any group of counterparties having similar characteristics. The credit risk on cash and cash equivalents is limited because the counterparties are banks with high credit-ratings assigned by international credit-rating agencies and also typically are lenders to the Group. Therefore, credit quality of financial assets which are neither past due nor impaired is assessed to be good. The maximum exposure to credit risk of financial assets is the carrying amount. -----

Mangrove Group is exposed to liquidity risk in a way that it may be unable to meet payment obligations because it has insufficient cash funds at its disposal. To manage Mangrove Group’s short, medium and long term funding and liquidity requirements the management has established an appropriate liquidity risk control framework consisting inter alia of a multi-year financial plan and a rolling month-by-month cash forecast. The Group manages the liquidity risk by maintaining adequate reserves, banking facilities, and reserve borrowing facilities as well as by monitoring forecasted cash flows at regular intervals. The cash flow from operating activities is the most important source of liquidity. In order to optimize borrowing and the use of cash funds within the Group, cash pools in various countries are established. The cash pools automatically balance the accounts of the participating companies every day by crediting or debiting a target account. This prevents separate cash investments and borrowings by these companies to a large extent. Mangrove Group companies are always exposed to foreign currency risk if their cash flows are denominated in a currency other than their own functional currency. Foreign currency risk is economically hedged using suitable instruments, thus largely offsetting fluctuations arising from the economical hedged item and the economical hedging transaction over their term. The foreign currency risk presented in the sensitivity analysis results from the following transactions: - Currency derivatives that are terminated for hedging of previously unrecognized economical hedged items, i.e., for contractually agreed or expected transactions. These hedging derivatives are affecting profit or loss by exchange rate risk. - Unsecured foreign currency transactions - The translation of foreign currency receivables or liabilities at the closing rate has a direct effect on earnings. A major part of the foreign currency cash flows is settled in the currency pairs that are named in the following table. The foreign currencies are included as relevant risk variables in the foreign currency sensitivity analysis. An interest rate sensitivity analysis presents the effects of changes in market interest rates on interest payments, and interest income and expenses. A sensitivity analyses is not done due to the following assumptions and instruments: - Non-derivative fixed-income financial instruments are only subject to balance sheet interest rate risk if they are measured at fair value. Mangrove Group measures such financial instruments at amortized cost. - Non-derivative variable rate financial instruments whose interest payments are not included as hedged items in an economical hedging relationship that is recognized as a cash flow hedge are subject to interest rate risk both in the income statement and in cash flow (cash flow interest rate risk and interest rate risk recognized in profit or loss). The issued fixed rate senior secured bond is the only material financial instrument. Thus, no interest rase rate sensitive analysis is applicable. - Embedded derivatives that were separated from the bonds do not include material interest rate risk due to a change in fair value which derives from various early redemption options. - Currency derivatives are not subject to material interest rate risk and therefore have no effect on interest rate sensitivity. An interest rate sensitivity analysis presents the effects of changes in market interest rates on interest payments, and interest income and expenses. A sensitivity analyses is not done due to the following assumptions and instruments: - Non-derivative fixed-income financial instruments are only subject to balance-sheet interest rate risk if they are measured at fair value. Mangrove Group measures such financial instruments at amortized cost. - Non-derivative variable rate financial instruments whose interest payments are not included as hedged items in an economical hedging relationship that is recognized as a cash flow hedge are subject to interest rate risk both in the income statement and in cash flow (cash flow interest rate risk and interest rate risk recognized in profit or loss). The issued fixed rate senior secured bond is the only material financial instrument. Thus, no interest rase rate sensitive analysis is applicable. - Embedded derivatives that were separated from the bonds do not include material interest rate risk due to a change in fair value which derives from various early redemption options. - Currency derivatives are not subject to material interest rate risk and therefore have no effect on interest rate sensitivity.

Mangrove Group’s capital management covers both equity and liabilities. An objective is to maintain sufficient and equal levels of working capital, current assets, and current liabilities. Due to the broad product range and the activities on global markets, under normal economic conditions Mangrove Group generates predictable and sustainable cash flows. Resources are allocated within the Mangrove Group primarily on the basis of strategic and medium-term planning. This provides the framework for preparing key decisions on core technologies, sales markets, and other strategically important variables. ----- Acquisitions and expansion investments are assessed not only on the basis of key performance indicators showing potential returns, but also in terms of their importance for achieving the Group’s strategic goals. The key economic criterion for evaluating rationalization and expansion investments is the net present value of future cash flows associated with these investments. The payback period (i.e., the time until the initial cash out from the investment has been recovered) is also calculated as an additional benchmark for assessing the risk arising from changing economic conditions. Working capital is another key element of capital employed. Working capital management begins before an order is accepted with the payment terms that are offered or negotiated. The capital structure is monitored with various key financial indicators of which the total net leverage ratio is one of the key financial indicators. The ratio of total net debt to consolidated EBITDA as defined in the RCF, is an important financial ratio (debt ratio) used in the Mangrove Group, especially for the covenants calculations, as described in above sections of this report. Subsubsection Text: The acquisition of Galapagos BidCo Group was consummated in connection with the balance-sheet restructuring transaction of the former Galapagos Group on October 9, 2019 (the “Restructuring”). A number of claims have been brought arising out of the Restructuring. More information on legal risks is included in Note “8.3 Litigation”. ----- ### 4. Consolidated statement of financial position disclosures: Assets ##### 4.1 Goodwill Goodwill represents the excess of the aggregate purchase price over the fair value of the net assets acquired in business combinations. Goodwill is tested for impairment annually at the end of the fiscal year and whenever there is any indication of a potential impairment. The units to which the goodwill is allocated represent the smallest identifiable groups of assets that generate cash flows that are largely independent of cash flows from other (groups of) assets and the lowest level within the Group at which the goodwill is monitored for internal management purposes. In the Mangrove Group, the 4 CGU-segments are coming from four business units Refrigeration Technologies, Machine Cooling Systems, Kelvion Thermal Solutions and Plate Heat Exchangers. The goodwill arose from the acquisition of the Galapagos BidCo Group on October 9, 2019. Goodwill primarily derives from future growth that is expected with new customers and new technological developments. No goodwill was allocated to the former cash-generating unit ENEXIO, as the economic situation does not justify a goodwill. Subsubsection Text: The recoverable amount of each cash-generating unit of the Group as of December 31, 2023 is determined by calculating an individual value in use by applying the discounted cash flow method taking into account existing business developments as well as long-term expectations. The business plan consists of a detailed planning for the year 2024 as well as a strategic planning for the years 2025 and 2026. This detailed planning has been expanded by two years, of which the year 2027 is a transitional period and the year 2028 is used as terminal value. The business plan for the Mangrove Group is based on CGU-specific assumptions about the trend in key macroeconomic parameters such as gross domestic product, market share, trends in labor costs, as well as trends in the cost of raw materials and regulatory framework conditions. Based on this, plan key figures are developed for each CGU for the three-year planning period, which are used to derive at net cash flows to complete the planning process prepared by segment's key management and discussed in shareholder committees. In the base case scenario of the business plan no impairment incurred as shown in the table below:

Subsubsection Text: ----- Although the estimation of the discounted future cash flows is believed to be appropriate, changes in assumptions or circumstances could require changes in the analysis. The goodwill impairment test as of December 31, 2023 leads to no impairment, as the recoverable amounts of the segments are higher than the carrying amount of the respective segment assets. The net cash inflows are discounted at a rate equivalent to the weighted average cost of equity and debt capital. To account for the different risk and return profiles of the Mangrove Group’s principal businesses, the after-tax cost of capital is calculated separately for each unit and a specific capital structure is defined by benchmarking against comparable companies in the same industry sector. The cost of equity corresponds to the return expected by stockholders, while the cost of debt is based on the conditions on which comparable companies can obtain long-term financing. Both components are derived from capital market information. The value in use is based on the following key assumptions: For the period beyond the detailed planning horizon, cash flows are based on an extrapolation using a growth rate of 1.00 percent (FY 2022: 1.50 percent). This underlying growth rate does not exceed the average long-term growth for the markets in which the segments operate. The CGU-specific total cost of capital assumed for discounting is based on a risk-free long-term interest rate of 2.75 percent and a market risk premium of 6.68 percent. Additionally, beta factors, a borrowing risk premium as well as capital structures were derived from a peer group for each cash-generating unit. Also, unit-specific tax rates were applied. Financing of the acquisition was done inter alia by a bridge loan of EUR 140,000,000 provided to the Company by the indirect shareholder Mangrove LuxCo I S.à r.l. on October 9, 2019. The final maturity date for the loan is four years after the date of the transaction, i.e. October 8, 2023. The loan does not accrue interest for the first six months after the transaction date. After the transaction date Mangrove LuxCo I S.à r.l. transferred the loan agreement and the EUR 140,000,000 loan receivable to its subsidiary Mangrove LuxCo II S.à r.l. which is the sole shareholder of the Company. On March 11, 2020 Mangrove LuxCo II S.à r.l. contributed the loan receivable in the full amount of EUR 140,000,000 to the capital contribution account (account 115 “apport en capitaux propres non rémunéré par des titres“of the Luxembourg Standard Chart of Accounts) of the Company. With Shareholder resolution as of December 22, 2020 the sole shareholder Mangrove LuxCo II S.à. r.l. to convert an aggregated amount of EUR 136,528,353 into tracking preferred equity certificates (“TPECs”). The company issued 13,652,835,300 TPECs, having a value of EUR 0.01 each, representing a total issue of EUR 136,528,353. As of December 31, 2022 TPECs are recognized at EUR 159,229,983 including an interest of EUR 11,350,815 (2021: EUR 11,350,815). Following the TPECs issuance and as security package in relation to certain facilities agreements entered into by the Company (including a EUR 65 million revolving facility, a EUR 260 million facilities agreement and a senior secured note indenture), the Company granting the TPECs Pledge to the benefit of the Security Agent and entered into the TPECs Pledge Agreement for the purpose thereof. These TPECs are junior to all other debt of the Group and cannot be withdrawn by the shareholder under the existing financing agreements. Therefore, these TPECs are equity like instruments and are being disclosed in the consolidated balance sheet of the Group between equity and liabilities and are summed up together with the equity to the line item “Equity and tracking preferred equity certificates / shareholder loan”. ----- #### 6.3 Provisions The following table shows the composition of and changes in provisions in 2021 and 2022:

Provisions for guarantees and warranties relate to warranty commitments for products and equipment, as it is customary in the industry. The guarantees and warranties on which they are based are granted in connection with certain performance criteria relating to products or equipment. Warranties usually have a contractual term of between one and two years from the date on which the products or equipment are accepted. In addition to warranties explicitly agreed under contract, product liability rules apply in many countries and may also stipulate that the manufacturer is liable beyond the contractually defined term of the warranty. In some cases, recourse claims exist in the form of insurance refunds or subcontractor guarantees. The level of provisions is based on management’s best estimate. Subsection Title: Current employee benefit obligations** **50,430** **30,785 Total employee benefit obligations** **82,858** **59,243
Subsubsection Text: ##### 5.4.1 Defined benefit pension plans Mangrove Group employees are offered various benefit options mainly in the form of defined benefit and defined contribution pension plans. The defined benefit pension plan obligations mainly exist in Germany. Mangrove Group grants old-age, disability, and survivors’ benefits to many of its employees. New employees are generally only granted benefits that are partly funded by employee contributions. As part of the general benefits provided all employees have the opportunity to voluntarily defer part of their compensation. Under this arrangement an agreed amount of their salary plus an employer contribution of up to 100 percent of the deferred amount is converted into a pension benefit. A corresponding collective bargaining agreement was entered by the predecessors of the Group in 2002 and revised in 2008. The new pension plan beginning in January 2019 does not only provide for pension payments, but also capital payments and installment payments. The post-retirement benefits are adjusted by minimum of 1 percent each year, according to the occupational retirement act (§ 16 Betriebsrentengesetz). In 2023 post-retirement benefits are adjusted by 2.1 percent. In addition to the currently open benefit schemes, there are a number of historical pension schemes in the company. These schemes are generally closed to new employees but are maintained unchanged for employees who were members at the time the scheme was closed. The pension liabilities are partly covered by reinsurance policies. All liabilities were actuarially valued as of December 31, 2023. Mangrove Group views granting pension benefits as an opportunity to foster employee loyalty and engagement. It is therefore an integral part of the remuneration concept and has an appropriate employee contribution component. In connection with this, Mangrove Group observes developments on the human resources market and regularly checks that the benefits it grants are appropriate and in line with the market. Mangrove Group does not believe that the pension liabilities pose any risks over and above the customary extent and the general risks described above. -----

As of the relevant reporting date, the following weighted actuarial assumptions were used to calculate the present value of the defined benefit obligation relating to pension plans. These assumptions are used to calculate the net pension expenses in the following year: (Percent) **12/31/2023** **12/31/2022 Discount factor 3.0 4.0 Inflation 2.0 2.0 derived: wage and salary increase rate 3.0 3.0 derived: pension increase rate 2.0 2.0 The actuarial measurement factors for German pension plans are established by Mangrove Group in consultation with actuarial experts. The corresponding assumptions for the few pension plans outside Germany are determined taking into account country-specific conditions. The discount rate is established using a recognized method based on the return on high quality corporate bonds determined as of the reporting date, taking into account the currency and maturities of the underlying liabilities. All other assumptions correspond to the long-term expectations of Mangrove Group. The nominal rate of wage and salary increases is calculated based on expected inflation and a real rate of increase. The rate of pension increases in Germany is also determined based on inflation, provided that the pension adjustments are determined in accordance with the rise in the cost of living. If a firm pension adjustment commitment has been made, this is taken into account accordingly. On 4 October 2018, Heubeck AG published new mortality tables (Heubeck mortality tables 2018G), for the valuation of all German plans as at 31 December 2023, these tables are used. On this basis, the life expectancy of a 65-year-old pensioner as of the reporting date is 21.63 years for men and 24.97 years for women. The sensitivities presented below were applied to the discount rate and inflation, which have been identified as actuarial assumptions that have a significant influence on Mangrove Group’s benefit obligations. Since the wage and salary increase rate and the pension increase rate are derived from inflation, sensitivity to inflation was used to measure the sensitivity of these assumptions together. The same calculation methods were used for sensitivities as for the recognized provisions. The ranges used to compute the sensitivities of the assumptions are based on the changes that are deemed possible until the next reporting date, given historical experience. The meaningfulness of historical experience for forecasts of future outcomes and neglecting to update a number of assumptions simultaneously may represent limitations of these methods. An increase of 50 basis points in the discount rate decreases the present value of the defined benefit obligation by 6.12 percent. If the assumed inflation rate declines by 25 basis points, the present value of the defined benefit obligation decreases by 0.18 percent. On October 9, 2019, the Company has issued EUR 356.233,492 thousand in aggregate principal amount of New Notes (“SSNs”) in connection with the acquisition of Galapagos BidCo Group as described elsewhere in these notes (e.g. in Sections 1. and 4.). The notes are due on the October 8, 2025, at which date the principal shall be payable in full. The notes were issued under an indenture among, inter alia, the issuer, Mangrove LuxCo III S.à r.l. as well as the issuer’s subsidiaries that guarantee the notes. Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. and Kelvion Finance GmbH, and GLAS Trustee Limited act as trustee. On October 9, 2019 the Company has issued €356,233,492 in aggregate principal amount of New Notes (“SSNs”) in connection with the acquisition of Galapagos BidCo Group as described elsewhere in these notes (e.g. in Sections 1. and 4.). The notes are due on the October 8, 2025 at which date the principal shall be payable in full. The notes were issued under an indenture among, inter alia, the issuer, Mangrove LuxCo III S.à r.l. as well as the issuer’s subsidiaries that guarantee the notes. Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. and Kelvion Finance GmbH, and GLAS Trustee Limited act as trustee.

Subsection Title: Interest on the notes and right to defer interest payments in cash in 2022 and 2023
Subsubsection Text: The Notes bear interest at a rate of 7.775% per annum and will be payable in cash, semi-annually in arrears on June 15 and December 15 of each year; provided that with respect to the interest periods ending June 15, 2022, December 15, 2022, June 15, 2023 and/or December 15, 2023, the Company, in its sole discretion, elect (if such election is necessary to ensure compliance with the minimum liquidity covenant and clean ----- down provision as per the terms of the New RCF on the relevant interest payment date and the twelve months following thereafter) to capitalize part of its interest payments for those periods, with the remainder payable in cash (an “Interest Election”). Following an Interest Election, interest due for the relevant interest period will be equal to an aggregate amount of 9.00% and shall comprise the following elements: (i) 0.25% per annum cash-pay interest; and (ii) 8.75% per annum payment-in-kind interest (increasing the principal amount of the outstanding Notes or by issuing additional New Notes, in each case, in a principal amount equal to an amount corresponding to an interest rate of 8.75% per annum on 100% of the then outstanding principal amount of the Notes).

Since October 09, 2023, the second anniversary of the Restructuring Effective Time, the Company is entitled, at its option, to redeem all or a portion of the Notes at a redemption price as described in the Notes Indenture and accrued and unpaid interest to (but not including) the date of redemption. In the event of certain developments affecting taxation, the Issuer may redeem all, but not less than all, of the Notes. At any time prior to the second anniversary of the Restructuring Effective Time, the Issuer will be entitled, at its option, to redeem all or a portion of the Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the Notes redeemed plus the applicable “make whole” premium described in the Notes Indenture and accrued and unpaid interest to (but not including) the date of redemption. At any time prior to the second anniversary of the Acquisition of Galapagos BidCo Group (i.e. October 9, 2023), the Company will be entitled, at its option, during each calendar year, to redeem up to 10% of the aggregate principal amount of Notes at a redemption price equal to 103.8875% of the principal amount redeemed plus accrued and unpaid interest to (but not including) the date of redemption. At any time on or after the second anniversary of the Restructuring Effective Time, the Company will be entitled, at its option, to redeem all or a portion of the Notes at a redemption price as described in the Notes Indenture and accrued and unpaid interest to (but not including) the date of redemption. In the event of certain developments affecting taxation, the Issuer may redeem all, but not less than all, of the Notes.

Subsection Title: Mandatory repayment upon request in case of change of control
Subsubsection Text: Upon certain events defined as constituting a change of control, each holder of the Notes will have the right to require the Company to repurchase such holders’ Notes at a price in cash equal to 101% of the aggregate principal amount thereof plus accrued and unpaid interest to (but not including) the date of redemption. Following certain public equity offerings by the Parent or any Parent Entity (as defined in the Notes Indenture), the Company will be required to use the net cash proceeds of the relevant public equity offering to make an offer to redeem the Notes at the redemption prices described in the Notes Indenture. Upon certain events defined as constituting a change of control, each holder of the Notes will have the right to require the Company to repurchase such holders’ Notes at a price in cash equal to 101% of the aggregate principal amount thereof plus accrued and unpaid interest to (but not including) the date of redemption. Following certain public equity offerings by the Parent or any Parent Entity (as defined in the Notes ----- Indenture), the Company will be required to use the net cash proceeds of the relevant public equity offering to make an offer to redeem the Notes at the redemption prices described in the Notes Indenture.

Pursuant to the security agreements under the Mangrove Finance Agreements, securities will be enforced by the lenders upon occurrence of a so-called acceleration event. An acceleration event requires the existence of a material event of default, which cannot be remedied. Material events of default are for example non-payment of interest or principal, financial covenant is not satisfied or insolvency of Mangrove LuxCo III S.à r.l. As of the reporting date and until the release of this report, no material event of default has been occurred. -----

Categorization within the levels of the fair value hierarchy is based on the measurement of the underlying inputs: Level 1 inputs: quoted prices (unadjusted) in active markets for identical financial assets and liabilities. Level 2 inputs: quoted market prices that are observable as direct (prices) or indirect (derived from prices) inputs used to measure fair value and that are not quoted prices as defined by Level 1. Level 3 inputs: inputs that are not based on observable market data. As a result, their fair values correspond to the carrying amounts. Regarding Tracking preferred equity certificates / shareholder loan we refer to note “5.2 Tracking preferred equity certificates / shareholder loan”. The carrying amount of the trade payables and other current liabilities that are subject to the measurement rules of IFRS 9 corresponds to their fair value. The fair value of fixed-interest liabilities is the present value of their expected future cash flows. They are discounted at the rates prevailing at the reporting date. The carrying amount of variable-rate liabilities corresponds to their fair value. The fair value of derivatives and embedded derivatives are calculated using quoted exchange rates and yield curves observable in the market. Accordingly, they are categorized within Level 2 of the fair value hierarchy. The fair value of senior secured notes is categorized within Level 1. Fair Value is calculated according to its quoted (unadjusted) price in active market. The fair value of other financial assets of shares in non-consolidated subsidiaries and other equity investments is measured on the basis of available financial information, such as transaction prices for financing rounds or business plans to the extent that this information is reliable, or, as an approximation, as cost, which is considered an appropriate estimate of fair value as no more suitable information is available. A review is carried out on a quarterly basis using all information available on the equity investments to establish whether cost is still representative of fair value. This would not be the case, for example, in the event of a significant change in the market in which the equity investments are active. As cost is the sole input factor for fair value, a percentage change in cost results in an equal change in fair value. The estimated fair value would increase (decrease) with any increase (decrease) in cost. A 1% increase (decrease) would not materially affect fair value. Accordingly, they are categorized within Level 3 of the fair value hierarchy.

The fair value of currency forwards at the reporting date is calculated on the basis of the spot exchange rate, taking into account forward premiums and discounts corresponding to the relevant remaining maturities. Forward premiums and discounts are derived from yield curves observable at the reporting date. The fair value of currency options is calculated on the basis of recognized measurement models. Fair value is affected by the remaining term of the option, the current exchange rate, the volatility of the exchange rate, and the underlying yield curves. Mangrove Group enters into derivative transactions under netting agreements with banks under the German Master Agreement for Financial Derivatives Transactions. In general, under such agreements, the amounts owed by each counterparty on a single day in respect of all transactions outstanding in the same currency are aggregated into a single net amount that is payable by one party to the other, in certain circumstances – e.g. when a credit event such as a default occurs - all outstanding transactions under the agreement are terminated, the termination value is assessed and only a single net amount is payable in settlement of all transactions. The potential offsetting volume is insignificant. The group is in the process of enacting new legislation to implementation the global minimum top-up tax, expectedly from fiscal year 2024 onwards and is in the process of adopting the necessary internal measures to fully comply with upcoming legislation. To measure the impact, if the global minimum tax legislation had applied in 2023 already, the group tested the Transitional CbCR Safe Harbour rules provided by said upcoming legislation, based on financial and tax data for the year 2022. Based on this, all jurisdictions where the group operates, would have been covered and deemed to have a zero top-up tax and thus no subsidiary in these jurisdictions would have been subject to the full global minimum tax legislation. Since the newly enacted legislation in Luxembourg is only effective from 1 January 2024, there is no current tax impact for the year ended 31 December 2023. The group has applied a temporary mandatory relief from deferred tax accounting for the impacts of the top-up tax and accounts for it as a current tax when it is incurred. -----

A transfer pricing audit was carried out at an Indian subsidiary for the 2019/2020 and 2020/2021 financial years by the Indian tax authorities and results in a contingent liability. The uncertain tax treatment relates to the interpretation of how the tax legislation is to be applied to the transfer prices for the company. The company has already started an appeal process against the assessment notes for transfer pricing which is still pending. No tax amounts were accrued for this topic since the company is convinced to get a relief for most of the findings in the appeal processes and because of the huge amount of loss carry-forwards of this entity (no deferred taxes were recognized on the tax loss-carry-forward amounts). The impact of the transfer pricing adjustment in the amount of EUR 2,750 thousand would reduce the tax-loss-carryforward correspondingly. ----- ### 7. Lease A lease is an agreement that conveys the right to control the use of an identified asset for a defined period of time in return for a number of payments. The Group is a lessee mainly of land and buildings, machinery, transportation and technical equipment.

With the adoption of IFRS 16, the lessee is no longer required to differentiate between operating and finance leases. As lessee, Mangrove now accounts for nearly all leases, recognising right-of-use assets for leased assets and liabilities for lease agreements. The following principles are considered: - Mangrove exercises the exemption for lease agreements with a maximum term of 12 months from the date of provision and low-value assets. Low-value assets are generally defined as leased with aggregated payments of EUR 20,000 or less. - Mangrove separates non-lease components, such as services, from lease payments. - Lease liabilities are measured at the present value of the remaining lease payments. Lease payments are discounted at the rate implicit in the lease if that rate can readily be determined. Otherwise, discounting is at the incremental borrowing rate. The incremental borrowing rate, which is mainly applied, is based on risk-adjusted interest rates, and determined for the respective lease terms and currencies. - A right-of-use asset is initially recognised at the same amount as the lease liability. Differences may arise from lease payments before commencement date and initial direct costs. - After capitalisation at commencement date, the right-of use asset is measured at cost and depreciated over the lease term using the straight-line method. - Extension and termination options are part of a number of leases particularly of real estate. Extension and termination options are taken into account on recognition of the lease liability only if it is reasonably certain that these options will be exercised in the future. When contract terms are being determined, consideration is given to all facts and circumstances that offer an economic incentive for exercising extension options or not exercising termination options. Changes in lease terms arising from the exercise of an extension option or non-exercise of a termination option are only considered when determining lease terms if sufficient certainty exists. Estimates and expectations which are asserted at the commencement date of the lease liability and the right-of-use asset and pertain to future payments not yet determined on the date of provision are assessed continuously during the lease term. If subsequently improved or changed knowledge influences the expected payment profile over time, the lease liability is remeasured. Contingent liabilities, other financial obligations and litigation ##### 8.1 Contingent liabilities A Contingent liability is according to IAS 37.10 a “possible obligation that arises from past events and whose existence will be confirmed only by the occurrence or non-occurrence of one or more uncertain future events not wholly within the control of the entity; or a present obligation that arises from past events but is not recognized because: (i) it is not probable that an outflow of resources embodying economic benefits will be required to settle the obligation; or (ii) the amount of the obligation cannot be measured with sufficient reliability.”, i.e., uncertainties for which the outcome has not been determined. If the occurrence is probable and the outcome can be estimated reliable, a liability is recorded in the balance sheet. As of December 31, 2023, Mangrove Group has a recognized contingent liability relating to the SSNs which amounts to EUR 17,787 thousand (2022: EUR 26,412 thousand) as of December 31, 2023. This contingent liability was recognized via purchase price allocation. Several companies of Mangrove Group have issued or instructed the issuance of bank guarantees in favor of customers or lenders. These bank guarantees are not considered to be contingent liabilities because these guarantees are linked to a performance obligation to be rendered by Mangrove Group. ##### 8.2 Other financial obligations Other financial obligations as of December 31, 2023 related to purchase commitments and bank guarantees.

##### 8.3 Litigation A number of claims have been brought arising out of the financial restructuring as described below (the “Restructuring”). On October 9, 2019, Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l. acquired the shares in Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. as described elsewhere in these notes (e.g. chapter “1.2 Acquisition of Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. and its subsidiaries and successful Refinancing on October 9, 2019”), associated preferred equity certificates and any intercompany payables owed by Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. to its former parent company Galapagos S.A. The acquisition was made in connection with the Restructuring, which was completed on October 9, 2019. A number of sets of internationally recognized advisors were involved in the Restructuring and latest decisions show that the Restructuring was fully legally effective and complied with all obligations, including under the applicable finance documents. The following claims have been brought which arise out of the Restructuring: - Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. had commenced proceedings in England against inter alios the Security Trustee under the Intercreditor Agreement which effected the Restructuring, the trustee which held rights on behalf of the Galapagos Senior Notes and each of the plaintiffs in the New York, German and Luxembourg proceedings described below, requesting that the English Court makes a series of declarations inter alia that the Restructuring complied with the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement. The English proceedings do not contain any claim for damages. On 28 July 2023 the English Court issued its judgment, ruling in favour of Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l., by confirming that the Restructuring complied with the Intercreditor Agreement. The decision is legally binding. This is closed now. - A claim in the Supreme Court of the State of New York by a beneficial holder of the Galapagos Senior Notes (“NY Claimant”) against inter alios Galapagos Holding (former indirect parent of Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l.) and certain of its subsidiaries (now being subsidiaries of Mangrove Group) relating to the Restructuring. The plaintiff alleged that the Restructuring wrongly deprived it of value by diverting assets away from the Group and releasing certain guarantees. The plaintiff ssought: (i) damages; and (ii) a reversal of the steps taken to affect the Restructuring. In addition, the plaintiff sought a declaration that the release of liabilities under the Galapagos Senior Notes Indenture pursuant to the provisions of the former Intercreditor Agreement applying to certain liabilities of the Group was invalid (in other words, that this part of the Restructuring also be reversed). The Supreme Court of the State of New York decided on 22 July 2020 to stay this action pending a decision from the English Court as to its jurisdiction in these matters (as referred to above). Following the decision of the English Court on 28 July 2023, the NY Claimant agreed to a joint stipulation regarding the dismissal of its claim with prejudice, i.e., the dismissal is legally binding on all parties. This is closed now. - On October 31, 2019 main insolvency proceedings were opened over the assets of Galapagos S.A. in Düsseldorf, Germany. Two appeals were lodged at the German Federal Supreme Court on ----- the jurisdiction of the Düsseldorf insolvency court. Following such appeals, on December 17, 2020, the German Federal Court of Justice referred certain legal questions concerning matters of European insolvency law (and, consequently, the jurisdiction of the Düsseldorf court in such insolvency proceedings) to the Court of Justice of the European Union for determination. The Court of Justice of the European Union rendered its decision on 24 March 2022, which confirmed that the German courts did not have authority to appoint the administrator on 23 August 2019, given that the European regime applied to the UK at this time. Following this decision, on 30 June 2022 the English insolvency court made a winding-up order with regard to Galapagos S.A. and has therefore asserted its jurisdiction over the insolvency proceedings (after it had stayed the insolvency proceedings in England in August 2019 due to the court in Düsseldorf, Germany, claiming its jurisdiction). The German Federal Court of Justice rendered its decision (based on the Court of Justice of the European Union decision) on 8 December 2022, declaring that since the English courts did not make their winding-up order prior to the Brexit transition period, i.e. 31 December 2020 such that the German courts are no longer bound by the EU Insolvency regulation when considering proceedings opened in England, the German courts had retrospective authority to appoint the administrator on 23 August 2019. Thus, the German insolvency proceedings remain in place, alongside the competing equivalent English proceedings. - The purported administrator of Galapagos S.A., Luxembourg (former 100 percent shareholder of Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l.) has brought a claim against Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l. and Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. in Luxembourg detailing his allegations that the Restructuring (i.e. the refinancing of Galapagos Group and the sale of Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. to Mangrove Group) involved a fraudulent exercise of a Luxembourg share pledge and that it should, therefore, be unwound. However, no steps have been taken by the administrator to progress this claw back action. In addition, the administrator has brought a separate action challenging the 2021 restructuring of the assets of Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. This action raises similar allegations to those made in the claw back action. The Luxembourg Court has yet to order a timetable for Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l. and Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l’ to file their defence. The purported administrator of Galapagos S.A., had initiated a claw back action against inter alios Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l.  This proceeding was dismissed by the District Court of Düsseldorf on 15 June 2023. The dismissal is legally binding. This is closed now. Based on legal advice of leading international law firms based in the UK, Luxembourg, Germany and the US (privilege in respect of which is not waived) and based on the final decisions of the courts in England, New York and Germany, Management assesses the risk from the above-mentioned ongoing litigation as well as future litigation as follows: 1) The risk that the Restructuring would be unwound is considered remote; and 2) The risk of having to pay damages to former holders of the Galapagos Senior Notes or any other third party is considered unlikely. Pursuant to IAS 24 persons or entities that (jointly) control or are (jointly) controlled by Mangrove Group shall be disclosed, unless they are included in the consolidated financial statements. The disclosure obligation under IAS 24 furthermore extends to transactions with persons who exercise a significant influence on the financial and business policies of the Mangrove Group. A significant influence on the financial and business policies of the Mangrove Group can hereby be based on a shareholding of 20 percent or more of Mangrove, a seat in the management board of Mangrove Group or another key management position on board either of the parent of Mangrove Group or on lower level holding company. Related parties of the Mangrove Group in accordance with IAS 24 primarily comprise the shareholders of the Mangrove and the subsidiaries of Mangrove Group, which are not consolidated due to materiality reasons. ##### 9.3.2Transactions with key management personnel In 2023 the members of the Board of Managers of the parent company earned EUR 9 thousand (2022: EUR 9 thousand) of salaries and attendance fees. For more details regarding the share-based payments we refer to note “9.5 Share based payments” ##### 9.5 Share based payments In 2020 certain management personnel (“co-investors”) were invited to participate in the Mangrove Group’s Management Incentive Plan (“Mangrove MIP”). This investment takes the form of part-ownership of Mangrove Management Invest S.C.A; an entity which has a part-ownership of Mangrove LuxCo II S.à r.l., the parent company of Mangrove LuxCo III S.à r.l.. In order to participate in the MIP, an initial cash investment was required from the co-investors, which was at not less than the fair value of the investments. During the year 2022 an additional Management Incentive Plan was launched. Again, certain management personnel were invited to participate in the new Kelvion Thermal Solutions Group’s Management Incentive Plan (“KTS MIP”). This investment takes the form of part-ownership of TESCO Management S.C.A; an entity which has a minority of TES LuxCo S.à r.l.. TES LuxCo S.à r.l. is the parent company of the Mangrove´s business unit Kelvion Thermal Solutions Group. Similar to the first MIP (“Mangrove MIP”) launched in 2020, the investment is structured in a way that the co-investors are taking a part ownership of a holding company via an investment vehicle. In order to participate in the KTS MIP, in a first step the co-investors sold their contribution in the Mangrove MIP at fair value to Mangrove LuxCo I S.à r.l.. In the amount of this receivable from Mangrove LuxCo I S.à r.l., the co-investors received an investment in the new KTS MIP. The initial cash related investment of the co-investors (receivable from Mangrove LuxCo I S.à r.l.) in KTS MIP was not less than to the fair value of the investment in any case. The nature of both schemes is such that co-investors’ investments will only be realised upon “exit” of the Group’s current shareholders, with exception of specific events (for example co-investors leaving the employment of the Group). It is anticipated that co-investors will participate in the MIPs until such exit is achieved. The lead investor is permitted to issue further equity, and each co-investor has the explicit right to participate further in the MIPs, such that their investment is not diluted. In the context of IFRS 2, both MIPs are considered to be equity-settled share-based payment arrangements. ##### 9.6 Company bodies The board members of Mangrove LuxCo III S.à r.l. are: Matthew Crill Joakim Lindström-Formicola ##### 9.7 Shareholder committees The members of Kelvion's shareholder committee are: - Hubertus Mühlhäuser - Michael Gahleitner ----- - Claus von Hermann In total, the Group incurred shareholder committee costs amounting to EUR 260 thousand. ##### 9.8 Disclosure of Audit Fees KPMG Audit, S.à r.l., Luxembourg, and other member firms of the KPMG network, provided the following services during the past two financial years to Mangrove LuxCo III S.à r.l.: (EUR thousand) **2023** **2022 Audit 1.322 1,663 Tax Consulting Services 1.633 1,503 Audit-related services  - 349 Other services 47.5 87

On October 9, 2019, Mangrove LuxCo III raised the SSN in the amount of EUR 356,294 thousand on the capital market, considering a premium of EUR 46,372 thousand. The premium was passed to Mangrove LuxCo IV via an Intercompany loan, and respected expenses were fully deducted in tax returns. Deferred taxes on premium were not recognized in the IFRS consolidated financial statements either on the temporary difference from the SSNs or on the tax loss carryforward. This error has been corrected by restating each of the affected financial statement line items for prior period:

Segment reporting ##### 10.1 Disclosures by segment The Segment Reporting of the Mangrove Group focuses on the four segments “Kelvion Refrigeration Technologies” (“RT”), “Kelvion Machine Cooling Systems” (“MCS”), “Kelvion Plate Heat Exchangers” (PHE”) and “Kelvion Thermal Solutions” (“KTS”). These “segments” had previously the status of being Kelvion’s “business units”. All segments are responsible for its respective markets and applications and focus on a distinct technology and product portfolio. In the past the business activities of the Mangrove Group were divided into the two segments Kelvion and ENEXIO. In addition, the administrator brought a separate action in Luxembourg challenging the 2021 restructuring of the assets of Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. This action raised similar allegations to those made in the separate claw back action in Germany. The German insolvency administrator of Galapagos S.A. on January 19, 2024 filed withdrawals (Désistement d’action) in respect of all Luxembourg proceedings previously initiated. During Q1 2024, the group extended the Senior Guarantee Facility (SGF) as well as the Revolving Credit Facility (RCF) to 2025, June 9[th]. ----- ### 12.List of companies included in the consolidated financial statements The following list shows all Mangrove Group companies, joint ventures and associated companies. Kennedy L-1855 Luxembourg ###### To the Sole Shareholder of Mangrove LuxCo III S.à r.l. 2, rue Edward Steichen L-2540 Luxembourg Luxembourg Tel.: +352 22 51 51 1 Fax: +352 22 51 71 E-mail: info@kpmg.lu Internet: www.kpmg.lu ###### REPORT OF THE REVISEUR D’ENTREPRISES AGREE Report on the audit of the consolidated financial statements Opinion We have audited the consolidated financial statements of Mangrove LuxCo III S.à r.l. and its subsidiaries (the "Group"), which comprise the consolidated statement of financial position as at 31 December 2023, and the consolidated statement of profit or loss, consolidated statement of comprehensive income, consolidated statement of changes in equity and consolidated statement of cash flows for the year then ended, and notes to the consolidated financial statements, including material accounting policy information and other explanatory information. In our opinion, the accompanying consolidated financial statements give a true and fair view of the consolidated financial position of the Group as at 31 December 2023, and its consolidated financial performance and its consolidated cash flows for the year then ended in accordance with IFRS Accounting Standards as adopted by the European Union. Basis for opinion We conducted our audit in accordance with the Law of 23 July 2016 on the audit profession (the “Law of 23 July 2016”) and with International Standards on Auditing (“ISAs”) as adopted for Luxembourg by the Commission de Surveillance du Secteur Financier (“CSSF”). Our responsibilities under the Law of 23 July 2016 and ISAs as adopted for Luxembourg by the CSSF are further described in the « Responsibilities of “réviseur d'entreprises agréé” for the audit of the consolidated financial statements » section of our report. We are also independent of the Group in accordance with the International Code of Ethics for Professional Accountants, including International Independence Standards, issued by the International Ethics Standards Board for Accountants (“IESBA Code”) as adopted for Luxembourg by the CSSF together with the ethical requirements that are relevant to our audit of the consolidated financial statements, and have fulfilled our other ethical responsibilities under those ethical requirements. We believe that the audit evidence we have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our opinion. Other information The Board of Managers is responsible for the other information. The other information comprises the information stated in the consolidated report including the consolidated management report but does not include the consolidated financial statements and our report of the “réviseur d'entreprises agréé” thereon. ----- ###### Our opinion on the consolidated financial statements does not cover the other information and we do not express any form of assurance conclusion thereon. In connection with our audit of the consolidated financial statements, our responsibility is to read the other information and, in doing so, consider whether the other information is materially inconsistent with the consolidated financial statements or our knowledge obtained in the audit or otherwise appears to be materially misstated. If, based on the work we have performed, we conclude that there is a material misstatement of this other information, we are required to report this fact. We have nothing to report in this regard. Responsibilities of the Board of Managers for the consolidated financial statements The Board of Managers is responsible for the preparation and fair presentation of the consolidated financial statements in accordance with IFRS Accounting Standards as adopted by the European Union, and for such internal control as the Board of Managers determines is necessary to enable the preparation of consolidated financial statements that are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error. In preparing the consolidated financial statements, the Board of Managers is responsible for assessing the Group’s ability to continue as a going concern, disclosing, as applicable, matters related to going concern and using the going concern basis of accounting unless the Board of Managers either intends to liquidate the Group or to cease operations, or has no realistic alternative but to do so. Responsibilities of the réviseur d’entreprises agréé for the audit of the consolidated financial statements The objectives of our audit are to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the consolidated financial statements as a whole are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error, and to issue a report of the “réviseur d’entreprises agréé” that includes our opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance, but is not a guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with the Law of 23 July 2016 and with ISAs as adopted for Luxembourg by the CSSF will always detect a material misstatement when it exists. Misstatements can arise from fraud or error and are considered material if, individually or in the aggregate, they could reasonably be expected to influence the economic decisions of users taken on the basis of these consolidated financial statements. As part of an audit in accordance with the Law of 23 July 2016 and with ISAs as adopted for Luxembourg by the CSSF, we exercise professional judgment and maintain professional skepticism throughout the audit. We also: — Identify and assess the risks of material misstatement of the consolidated financial statements, whether due to fraud or error, design and perform audit procedures responsive to those risks, and obtain audit evidence that is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our opinion. The risk of not detecting a material misstatement resulting from fraud is higher than for one resulting from error, as fraud may involve collusion, forgery, intentional omissions, misrepresentations, or the override of internal control. — Obtain an understanding of internal control relevant to the audit in order to design audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the Group’s internal control. — Evaluate the appropriateness of accounting policies used and the reasonableness of accounting estimates and related disclosures made by the Board of Managers. ----- ###### — Conclude on the appropriateness of the Board of Managers' use of the going concern basis of accounting and, based on the audit evidence obtained, whether a material uncertainty exists related to events or conditions that may cast significant doubt on the Group’s ability to continue as a going concern. If we conclude that a material uncertainty exists, we are required to draw attention in our report of the “réviseur d’entreprises agréé” to the related disclosures in the consolidated financial statements or, if such disclosures are inadequate, to modify our opinion. Our conclusions are based on the audit evidence obtained up to the date of our report of the “réviseur d’entreprises agréé”. However, future events or conditions may cause the Group to cease to continue as a going concern. — Evaluate the overall presentation, structure and content of the consolidated financial statements, including the disclosures, and whether the consolidated financial statements represent the underlying transactions and events in a manner that achieves fair presentation. — Obtain sufficient appropriate audit evidence regarding the financial information of the entities and business activities within the Group to express an opinion on the consolidated financial statements. We are responsible for the direction, supervision and performance of the Group audit. We remain solely responsible for our audit opinion. We communicate with those charged with governance regarding, among other matters, the planned scope and timing of the audit and significant audit findings, including any significant deficiencies in internal control that we identify during our audit. We also provide those charged with governance with a statement that we have complied with relevant ethical requirements regarding independence, and to communicate with them all relationships and other matters that may reasonably be thought to bear on our independence, and where applicable, actions taken to eliminate threats or safeguards applied. Report on other legal and regulatory requirements The consolidated management report is consistent with the consolidated financial statements and has been prepared in accordance with applicable legal requirements.
