General information #### 1.1 Company information Mangrove LuxCo III S.à r.l., Luxembourg, hereinafter also referred to as " Mangrove LuxCo III " or the "company" is a public limited liability company (Société à responsabilité limitée) incorporated under the laws of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg, having its registered office at 2, rue Edward Steichen, L-2540 Luxembourg, and registered with the Luxembourg Trade and Companies Register (Registre de Commerce et des Sociétés Luxembourg) with registration number B236258. Sole shareholder of the company is Mangrove LuxCo II S.à r.l., Luxembourg, which itself is a direct subsidiary of Galapagos LuxCo I S.à r.l., Luxembourg. The Company was incorporated on July 11, 2019. The purpose of the Company is the acquisition, holding and disposal of interests in Luxembourg and/or foreign companies and undertakings as well as the administration, development and management of such interests. #### 1.2 Acquisition of Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. and its subsidiaries and successful Refinancing on October 9, 2019 With an effective date October 9, 2019, Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l., Luxembourg, a 100 percent subsidiary of Mangrove LuxCo III, bought 100 percent of the shares in Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l., Luxembourg and all its subsidiaries (together “Galapagos BidCo Group”). Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l., Luxembourg, was 100 percent shareholder of the shares in Kelvion Finance GmbH, Germany including all of its subsidiaries (together “Kelvion Group”) and in ENEXIO Management GmbH, Germany including all of its subsidiaries (together “ENEXIO Group”) at the acquisition date. Before the acquisition of Galapagos BidCo Group, the Company did not have any operational activities. The Acquisition was consummated in connection with the balance sheet restructuring transaction of the Galapagos Group, the former shareholder of Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l., which has resulted in a major recapitalization of the operating business of the Mangrove LuxCo III, Mangrove LuxCo IV and the newly acquired subsidiaries (collectively, the “Mangrove Group”), a deleveraging of the Mangrove Group’s balance sheet and access to new debt facilities and instruments with longer tenors (the “Restructuring”). In connection with the Restructuring, the Company issued EUR 356,233,492 in aggregate principal amount of 7.775 percent senior secured fixed rate notes due 2025 (the “New Notes”). In preparation of the aforesaid acquisition of Galapagos BidCo Group the Company incorporated or acquired the following direct and indirect subsidiaries: Incorporation of Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l., Luxembourg on July 11, 2019 and indirectly via the participation in Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l. the following holding entities in Germany were acquired on October 9, 2019: Mangrove GermanCo I GmbH, Germany and Mangrove GermanCo II GmbH, Germany. In the following, Mangrove LuxCo III and its consolidated direct and indirect subsidiaries is referred to as "Mangrove Group" or “the Group”. ----- #### 1.3 Description of the business The Mangrove Group is a leading global manufacturer of heat exchangers and other cooling & heating products. The Group is active in multiple end markets such as Refrigeration, HVAC (Heating, Ventilation, Air Conditioning), Data Center, Power, Heavy & Light Industry, Chemicals, Oil & Gas, Food & Beverage and Marine. In those markets, the “new Group” services a broad, diversified and long-standing customer base in more than 130 countries. ###### 1.3.1 Segment Reporting Mangrove Group operates through the four Kelvion segments, “Kelvion Refrigeration Technologies” (“RT”), “Kelvion Machine Cooling Systems” (“MCS”), “Kelvion Plate Heat Exchangers” (“PHE”) and “Kelvion Thermal Solutions” (“KTS”). The former segment “ENEXIO” continues to be in the process of being wound down. ENEXIO, manufacturer of power plant and industry cooling systems as well as wastewater treatment solutions, consisted of three business units: Dry Cooling Systems (DCS), Service Solutions and Water Technologies (WT). After the strategic decision was taken to exit the DCS business and to either sell or integrate the Service and Water business into Kelvion Group, one part of the DCS business (DCS Heller) was successfully sold at the end of 2020 and on October 20, 2021 closing in connection with the share purchase and transfer agreement for the shares of ENEXIO companies comprising the Service business took place. Furthermore, on January 3, 2022 the same was executed in connection with the shares of ENEXIO companies comprising the Water business. On March 23, 2022 the Group signed an asset-/share purchase agreement for certain parts of the DCS business (DCS Air Cooled Condenser) comprising the stake in an Indian Joint Venture as well as certain assets (intellectual property in Germany and one production line in China). After these transactions, only parts of the Dry Cooling business remain with the Group, until the continuing wind-down of this activity has been completed. The declining importance of the ENEXIO Business is also reflected in its decreasing volume, which represented in FY 2021 already less than 10 Percent and in FY 2022 less than 1 Percent in terms of Mangrove Group. Overall, the contribution of the segment ENEXIO to revenue and normalized EBITDA of the Group is no longer significant for the Group’s earnings position. ###### 1.3.2 The four segments of Mangrove Group The four segments of Mangrove Group focus on distinct technologies and product portfolios: - **Kelvion Refrigeration Technologies (RT) focuses on component business for refrigeration applications with significant growth potential in the data center industry. RT supplies a wide range of standard and customized heat exchangers for cooling and removing heat from different types of data centers (hyperscale, colocation, modular etc.) using both air and liquid cooling methods. The data center market consists of cooling solutions such as air conditioning, chilling units, economizer systems, liquid cooling systems, control systems and includes services such as consulting, installation & deployment and maintenance and support. The heat exchanger solutions are also used in the refrigeration market in cold chain warehouses, supermarkets, non-residential buildings, and industrial production. Product offering includes air cooled condensers which reject heat from refrigeration systems and are often sold as part of a package of equipment with air coolers. RT’s customized air coolers are design-to-order units for industrial or OEM solutions for food processing and distribution facilities. Product offering includes also customized radiators and dry coolers which are mainly used for power and industrial applications. Improving the energy efficiency of commercial and industrial refrigeration equipment is essential for end users looking to reduce carbon footprint and operating costs. ----- - **Kelvion Machine Cooling Systems (MCS) is a leading player in heat exchangers for power and engine applications with substantial growth opportunities by leveraging its global installed base. MCS supplies heat exchangers for power generation, power transmission, large engine applications (marine and off highway) and green applications like biomass, green hydrogen, or renewable energies. The business is mostly with OEM, e.g., for large engine manufacturers, but MCS also engages in smaller projects, like solar, wind or solar photovoltaic. Product offering includes charge air coolers, which cool down combustion-air coming from the turbocharger before entering the engine. MCS’ shell and tube double safety heat exchangers assure the secure handling of safety-critical media. Product offering also includes box coolers which are fitted in the sea chest of small and medium-sized vessels. - **Kelvion Thermal Solutions (KTS), is Kelvion’s largest segment, focusing on project business for demanding applications in the Oil & Gas, Chemicals Industries and, like RT, with significant growth potential in high tech data center business as well as green tech applications such as hydrogen and Carbon Capture and Storage (CCS). KTS’ engineering expertise plays a key role in differentiation against competitors. High degree of geographical diversification with sites in all key region, including Europe, NAFTA, Latin America, China and MEA. Product offering includes air fin coolers typically used for very large cooling requirements in different industries, e.g., Oil & Gas and Chemicals, as well as air dryers which are used to remove humidity from an air stream in various process industries. KTS’ shell & tube heat exchangers are used to heat, cool, or condense water and other media in different process industries. The focus of the BU has shifted in the recent years from Oil & Gas and Petrochemicals to high and green tech business. KTS represents mainly the former segment “Kelvion Thermal Engineered Solutions” (“TES”). - **Kelvion Plate Heat Exchangers (PHE) provides a broad range of plate heat exchangers for a wide variety of applications in terms of pressure and temperature demands for a wide range of customer industries, ranging from HVAC and Refrigeration to Food & Beverages, Chemicals, Power, and Industrials. Product offering includes fully welded plate heat exchangers which are used to save energy in demanding high pressure and temperature applications, as well as brazed plate heat exchangers, often used for environmentally friendly heat pump applications. PHE’s gasketed heat exchangers have the highest efficiency and flexibility and are used in a variety of industries as well as for heat recovery applications. In contrast to the project driven segment KTS, the three segments RT, MCS and PHE represent the component type business of the Group and form together “Kelvion Products” (“KP”). All four segments hold strong favorable market positions in their respective markets. MCS and PHE are among the TOP 3, RT amongst the Top 5 and KTS is niche-market leader. In addition to the above segments there is the fifth Service segment, which is a virtual segment, i.e., Service is not separated from the four segments but managed globally and centrally across segments. ----- ## 2. Reporting and Accounting principles #### 2.1 Going-concern basis of accounting ###### Preparation of consolidated financial statements With effective date December 21, 2022, the Group agreed with the lenders to reset the financial covenants, to which the budget 2023 offers sufficient headroom. In the first three months of the year 2023 the Group can report an order intake and a financial performance that exceeds previous year and budget 2023. Based on the good start to the year, management of the Group expects the financial performance for the full year to exceed budget. With current market conditions and business performance, the Group does not see any current risk to complying with future covenant requirements and consequently the management does not see any risk to the going concern of the Group. Based on actual planning the Group will be at every time and in the upcoming year in the position to meet all its financial obligations. Therefore, the consolidated financial statements of Mangrove Group have been prepared on a going concern basis. #### 2.2 Basis of presentation The presented consolidated financial statements cover the period from January 1, 2022 to December 31, 2022 with the prior period from January 1, 2021 to December 31, 2021. The consolidated financial statements of Mangrove Group - which comprise the consolidated statement of financial position, consolidated statement of profit or loss, consolidated statement of comprehensive income, consolidated statement of cash flows, consolidated statement of changes in equity and the notes to the consolidated financial statements - include Mangrove LuxCo III and its direct and indirect subsidiaries (hereinafter referred to as “Mangrove Group” or the “Group”). The consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) as adopted by the EU. All IFRS standards and interpretations in effect for fiscal years beginning on or after January 1, 2022, have been applied. The consolidated financial statements are prepared in euro (EUR), the functional currency of the group, and presented in thousand of euros (EUR thousand) or in millions of euros (EUR million). Due to rounding, figures presented may result in differences of EUR 1 thousand in certain cases. To improve the clarity of presentation, various items in the consolidated balance sheet and consolidated income statement have been aggregated and are explained accordingly in the Notes. Assets and liabilities are classified into current and non-current items. Current assets are expected to be realized within 12 months after the reporting period and current liabilities are due to be settled within 12 months after the reporting period. The consolidated income statement is prepared using the cost of sales method. The consolidated statement of cash flows is prepared using the indirect method for cash flows from operating activities and the direct method for cash flows from investing and financing activities. The accounting and measurement principles are presented and explained in detail in Note 2.8. The consolidated financial statements were authorized for issue by the Board of Managers on April 28, 2023. #### 2.3 First-time adoption of new accounting pronouncements The Group applied for the first time all standards and amendments, which are effective for annual periods ----- beginning on January 1, 2022. The impact on the consolidated financial statements of the Group is not significant. The Group has not early adopted any other standard, interpretation or amendments that were issued but are not yet effective. ###### 2.3.1 Accounting regulations applied for the first time in the year 2022 - **Amendments to IFRS 16 (Effective April 1, 2021) IFRS 16 contains regulations regarding the recognition of changes in lease payments (including rental concessions) by the lessee. In general, the lessee must assess for each lease whether the lease concessions granted constitute changes to the lease and must remeasure the lease liability as a result. In response to the ongoing impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, IFRS 16 Leases was amended on March 31, 2021 to provide a one-year extension of the practical expedient to assist lessees in accounting for COVID-19-related lease concessions. The amendments extend the practical expedient to lease concessions that reduce lease payments originally due on or before June 30, 2022. Previously, only lease concessions that reduce lease payments that are or were due on or before June 30, 2021, were within the scope of the relief. - **Amendments to IAS 37 (Effective January 1, 2022) Clarification that the cost of fulfilling a contract includes all directly attributable costs. The cost of fulfilling the contract includes both the incremental costs of fulfilling that contract (such as direct wage and material costs) and an allocation of other costs that relate directly to fulfilling contracts. In addition, it is clarified that before a provision for an onerous contract is established, an entity should recognize any impairment loss that has occurred on assets used in (previously: dedicated to) fulfilling the contract. - **Amendments to IFRS 3 (Effective January 1, 2022) In accordance to the amended framework, references to the framework in various standards, including IFRS 3, have been adjusted. The rules for accounting for business combinations are not changed in substance. The amendments are to be applied to business combinations for which the acquisition date is on or after January 1, 2022. Earlier application is permitted. - **Improvements to IFRS 2018 – 2020 (Effective January 1, 2022) The Annual Improvements to IFRS amended the following standards: `o` In IFRS 1, the option was opened for first-time adopters of IFRS 1.D16 (a) to measure cumulative translation differences at the amounts recognized by the parent. `o` The amendment to IFRS 9 clarifies which fees are to be included in the 10 percent test (IFRS 9.B3.3.6) with regard to the assessment of whether a financial liability is derecognized. Only fees paid or received between the entity as borrower and the lender are included. `o` In IFRS 16, the presentation of the reimbursement of leasehold improvements has been removed in explanatory example 13 to IFRS 16. `o` In IAS 41, the prohibition on including tax payments in the fair value measurement is removed. - **Amendments to IAS 16 (Effective January 1, 2022) The amendment prohibits entities from deducting the cost of an item of property, plant and ----- equipment any proceeds from selling items produced while bringing that asset to the location and condition necessary for it to be capable of operating in the manner intended by management. Clarification of the definition of the costs of testing. Revenue and cost that relate to items produced that are not an output of the entity’s ordinary activities must be presented separately. Disclosure of the line item in the statement of comprehensive item that includes such revenue. ###### 2.3.2 Accounting regulations not applied in advance of their effective date The following standards and amendments to existing standards of possible relevance to the Group, which were adopted into EU law (endorsement mechanism) but are not yet mandatory, have not been applied early: - **IFRS 17 Insurance Contracts (including Amendments) (Effective January 1, 2023) IFRS 17 replaces IFRS 4 and for the first time sets out standard requirements for the recognition, measurement, presentation and disclosure of insurance contracts, reinsurance contracts and investment contracts with discretionary participation features. Under the IFRS 17 measurement model, groups of insurance contracts are measured based on the expected value of discounted cash flows with an explicit risk adjustment for non-financial risks as well as a contractual service margin that results in the recognition of profit in line with the provision of services. The amendments add a transition option aimed to improve the usefulness of comparative information presented on initial application of both IFRS 17 and IFRS 9 and introduce the option of applying a "classification overlay approach". This option can be applied when IFRS 17 and IFRS 9 are applied simultaneously for the first time and no "restatement" of a financial asset with regard to the comparative information of IFRS 9 in 2022 is made. - **Amendments to IAS 1 and IFRS Practice Statement 2 (Effective January 1, 2023) The amendment to IAS 1 requires that only "significant" accounting policies are presented in the notes. To be material, the accounting policy must be related to significant transactions or other events and there must be a reason for its presentation. A reason may be, for example, that the method has been changed, it is an option, the method is complex or highly judgmental, or it has been developed in accordance with IAS 8.10-11. The amendments to Practice Statement 2 accordingly indicate how the concept of materiality is applied to the disclosure of accounting policies. Thus, in the future, company-specific disclosures are to be given priority over standardized disclosures. - **Amendments to IAS 8 (Effective January 1, 2023) The amendment to IAS 8 clarifies how entities can better distinguish changes in accounting policies from changes in estimates. For this purpose, it is defined that an accounting estimate always relates to a measurement uncertainty of a financial figure in the financial statements. In addition to input parameters, an entity also uses valuation techniques to determine an estimate. Valuation techniques can be estimation techniques or valuation techniques. ----- - **Amendments to IAS 12 (Effective January 1, 2023) The amendments address previously existing uncertainties in the accounting for deferred taxes in connection with leases and disposal or restoration obligations. The amendments clarify the application of the already existing “initial recognition exemption” (IAS 12.15) and result in the recognition of deferred taxes, e.g. on leases accounted for by the lessee and on disposal or restoration obligations. This is therefore an exemption to the "initial recognition exemption" for narrowly defined cases. These new standards and amendments to existing standards will be applied by the Group starting in fiscal 2022 or later. No material impacts are expected. #### 2.4 Accounting pronouncements not yet endorsed by the EU In previous years, and in fiscal year 2022, the IASB issued the following standards and amendments to existing standards of relevance to the Group, which still have to be adopted into EU law (endorsement mechanism) before they become applicable: - **Amendments to IAS 1 (Effective January 1, 2023) The amendments to IAS 1 concern a limited adjustment to the assessment criteria for classifying liabilities as current or non-current. It is clarified that the classification of liabilities as current depends on the entity's rights at the reporting date to defer settlement of the liability for at least twelve months after the end of the reporting period: If such rights exist, the liability is classified as non-current. The right to defer settlement of the liability must be substantial. If the entity has to meet certain conditions in order to exercise such a right, these conditions must be met at the reporting date; otherwise, the liability is classified as current. For the classification of a liability, it is irrelevant whether management intends or expects that the liability will actually be settled within twelve months after the balance sheet date. The only decisive factor for classification is the right existing at the balance sheet date to defer settlement of the liability for at least 12 months. This also applies in the event of settlement within the value recovery period. - **Amendments to IFRS 16 (Effective January 1, 2024) The Amendments to IFRS 16 shall clarify how a seller-lessee subsequently measures sale and leaseback transactions that satisfy the requirements in IFRS 15 to be accounted for as a sale. It requires a seller-lessee to subsequently measure lease liabilities arising from a leaseback in a way that it does not recognise any amount of the gain or loss that relates to the right of use it retains. The new requirements do not prevent a seller-lessee from recognising in profit or loss any gain or loss relating to the partial or full termination of a lease. - **Amendments to IFRS 10 and IAS 28 The amendments address a known inconsistency between the requirements of IFRS 10 and IAS 28 (2011) in the case of the disposal of assets to an associate or joint venture or the contribution of assets to an associate or joint venture. ----- IFRS 10 requires a parent to recognize the full amount of the gain or loss on disposal of a subsidiary in profit or loss when control is lost. In contrast, the currently applicable IAS 28.28 requires that the gain or loss on disposal of a disposal transaction between an investor and an investment accounted for using the equity method - whether an associate or a joint venture - be recognized only to the extent of the other's interest in the entity. In the future, the entire gain or loss on a transaction is to be recognized only if the assets sold or contributed constitute a business as defined by IFRS 3. This applies regardless of whether the transaction is structured as a share or asset deal. If, on the other hand, the assets do not constitute a business, only pro rata income recognition is permitted. The IASB has postponed the date of first-time application of the amendments indefinitely. #### 2.5 Impact of the introduction of a global minimum tax rate by the OECD (Pillar Two) To address concerns about the unequal distribution of profits and unequal tax levies of large multinational corporations, various agreements have been reached at the global level, including an agreement by over 135 countries to introduce a global minimum tax rate of 15 percent. In December 2021, the OECD published a draft legal framework, followed by detailed guidance in March 2022, to be used by individual countries that are signatories to the agreement to amend their local tax laws. Once the changes in tax laws are in place or will soon be in place in the countries where the Group operates, the Group may be subject to the minimum tax. At the date of authorization of the consolidated financial statements for issue, the tax legislation related to the minimum tax is not applicable or soon to be applicable in any of the countries in which the Group operates. The Board closely monitors the progress of the legislative process in each country in which the Group operates. As of December 31, 2022, the Group did not have sufficient information to determine the potential quantitative impact. #### 2.6 Basis of consolidation ###### Consolidated entities The consolidated financial statements comprise the financial statements of Mangrove LuxCo III and its direct and indirect subsidiaries as of December 31, 2022. The financial statements of the subsidiaries are generally prepared for the same reporting period as the parent company, except of the Indian subsidiary, consistently applying group IFRS accounting policies. The financial year ends due to local Indian commercial law on March 31, each year. This company was incorporated in the consolidated financial statements of Mangrove Group on the basis of interim financial statements. All intra-group balances and transactions, and any unrealized income and expenses arising from intra-group transactions, are eliminated. The consolidated financial statements of Mangrove Group include Mangrove LuxCo III and all material companies which Mangrove LuxCo III controls directly or indirectly. Companies are consolidated as of the date on which control is obtained by Mangrove LuxCo III. They are deconsolidated as of the date on which control is lost. In addition to the ultimate parent company, 55 companies were consolidated. ----- The scope of consolidation changed as follows:

The consideration paid is measured on the basis of the fair value of the assets received, the liabilities assumed from the seller, and the equity instruments issued at the transaction date. The identifiable assets acquired and liabilities and contingent liabilities assumed in the business combination are recognised at their fair value at the transaction date, irrespective of any non-controlling interests. Any contingent consideration agreed is recognised at fair value at the acquisition date. Subsequent changes in fair value are recognised in profit or loss. The excess of cost over the share of the fair value of the company’s net assets acquired is recognised as goodwill. If, after a further examination, cost is lower than the share of the fair value of the subsidiary’s acquired net assets measured at fair value, the difference is recognised directly in profit or loss. ----- Transaction costs related to business combinations are expensed within the period they occur. Non-controlling interests are measured at their proportionate share of the acquiree’s identifiable net assets at the date of acquisition. Changes in the Group’s interest in a subsidiary that do not result in a loss of control are accounted for as equity transactions. Where a subsidiary is disposed of, such that control is no longer held, the entity is removed from the consolidation as at the date when control ceases. If individual group companies have a different reporting date, they are included on the basis of interim financial statements as of the respective reporting date.

Consolidated statement of financial position disclosures: Assets #### 5.1 Goodwill Goodwill represents the excess of the aggregate purchase price over the fair value of the net assets acquired in business combinations. Goodwill is tested for impairment annually at the end of the fiscal year and whenever there is any indication of a potential impairment. The units to which the goodwill is allocated represent the smallest identifiable groups of assets that generate cash flows that are largely independent of cash flows from other (groups of) assets and the lowest level within the Group at which the goodwill is monitored for internal management purposes. In the Mangrove Group, the 4 CGU-segments are coming from four business units Refrigeration Technologies, Machine Cooling Systems, Kelvion Thermal Solutions and Plate Heat Exchangers. The goodwill arose from the acquisition of the Galapagos BidCo Group on October 9, 2019. Goodwill primarily derives from future growth that is expected with new customers and new technological developments. No goodwill was allocated to the former cash-generating unit ENEXIO, as the economic situation does not justify a goodwill. Subsubsection Text: The recoverable amount of each cash-generating unit of the Group as of December 31, 2022 is determined by calculating an individual value in use by applying the discounted cash flow method taking into account existing business developments as well as long-term expectations. The business plan consists of a detailed planning for the year 2023 as well as a strategic planning for the years 2024 and 2025. This detailed planning has been expanded by two years, of which the year 2026 is a transitional period and the year 2027 is used as terminal value. The business plan for the Mangrove Group is based on CGU-specific assumptions about the trend in key macroeconomic parameters such as gross domestic product, market share, trends in labor costs, as well as trends in the cost of raw materials and regulatory framework conditions. Based on this, plan key figures are developed for each CGU for the three-year planning period, which are used to derive at net cash flows to complete the planning process prepared by segment's key management and discussed in shareholder committees. In the base case scenario of the business plan no impairment incurred as shown in the table below.

Subsubsection Text: ----- Although the estimation of the discounted future cash flows is believed to be appropriate, changes in assumptions or circumstances could require changes in the analysis. The goodwill impairment test as of December 31, 2022 leads to no impairment, as the recoverable amounts of the segments are higher than the carrying amount of the respective segment assets. The net cash inflows are discounted at a rate equivalent to the weighted average cost of equity and debt capital. To account for the different risk and return profiles of the Mangrove Group’s principal businesses, the after-tax cost of capital is calculated separately for each unit and a specific capital structure is defined by benchmarking against comparable companies in the same industry sector. The cost of equity corresponds to the return expected by stockholders, while the cost of debt is based on the conditions on which comparable companies can obtain long-term financing. Both components are derived from capital market information. The value in use is based on the following key assumptions: For the period beyond the detailed planning horizon, cash flows are based on an extrapolation using a growth rate of 1.50 percent (FY 2021: 1.00 percent). The increase of 0.5 percent is mainly due to the fact that the assumption on the growth rate is inflation driven growth. This underlying growth rate does not exceed the average long-term growth for the markets in which the segments operate. The CGU-specific total cost of capital assumed for discounting is based on a risk-free long-term interest rate of 2 percent and a market risk premium of 7.5 percent. Additionally, beta factors, a borrowing risk premium as well as capital structures were derived from a peer group for each cash-generating unit. Also, unit-specific tax rates were applied. Subsection Title: Current employee benefit obligations** **30,785** **26,794 Total employee benefit obligations** **59,243** **66,425
Subsubsection Text: ###### 6.4.1 Defined benefit pension plans Mangrove Group employees are offered various benefit options mainly in the form of defined benefit and defined contribution pension plans. The defined benefit pension plan obligations mainly exist in Germany. Mangrove Group grants old-age, disability, and survivors’ benefits to many of its employees. New employees are generally only granted benefits that are partly funded by employee contributions. As part of the general benefits provided all employees have the opportunity to voluntarily defer part of their compensation. Under this arrangement an agreed amount of their salary plus an employer contribution of up to 100 percent of the deferred amount is converted into a pension benefit. A corresponding collective bargaining agreement was entered by the predecessors of the Group in 2002 and revised in 2008. The new pension plan beginning in January 2019 does not only provide for pension payments, but also capital payments and installment payments. The post-retirement benefits are adjusted by minimum of 1 percent each year, according to the occupational retirement act (§ 16 Betriebsrentengesetz). In 2022 post-retirement benefits are adjusted by 2.2 percent. In addition to the currently open benefit schemes, there are a number of historical pension schemes in the company. These schemes are generally closed to new employees but are maintained unchanged for ----- employees who were members at the time the scheme was closed. The pension liabilities are partly covered by reinsurance policies. All liabilities were actuarially valued as of December 31, 2022. Mangrove Group views granting pension benefits as an opportunity to foster employee loyalty and engagement. It is therefore an integral part of the remuneration concept and has an appropriate employee contribution component. In connection with this, Mangrove Group observes developments on the human resources market and regularly checks that the benefits it grants are appropriate and in line with the market. Mangrove Group does not believe that the pension liabilities pose any risks over and above the customary extent and the general risks described above.

Subsection Title: Interest on the notes and right to defer interest payments in cash in 2021 and 2022
Subsubsection Text: The Notes bear interest at a rate of 7.775% per annum and will be payable in cash, semi-annually in arrears on June 15 and December 15 of each year; provided that with respect to the interest periods ending June 15, 2021, December 15, 2021, June 15, 2022 and/or December 15, 2022, the Company may, in its sole discretion, elect (if such election is necessary to ensure compliance with the minimum liquidity covenant and clean-down provision as per the terms of the New RCF on the relevant interest payment date and the twelve months following thereafter) to capitalize part of its interest payments for those periods, with the remainder payable in cash (an “Interest Election”). Following an Interest Election, interest due for the relevant interest period will be equal to an aggregate amount of 9.00% and shall comprise the following elements: (i) 0.25% per annum cash-pay interest; and (ii) 8.75% per annum payment-in-kind interest (increasing the principal amount of the outstanding Notes or by issuing additional New Notes, in each case, in a principal amount equal to an amount corresponding to an interest rate of 8.75% per annum on 100% of the then outstanding principal amount of the Notes).

Pursuant to the security agreements under the Mangrove Finance Agreements, securities will be enforced by the lenders upon occurrence of a so-called acceleration event. An acceleration event requires the existence of a material event of default, which cannot be remedied. Material events of default are for example non-payment of interest or principal, financial covenant is not satisfied or insolvency of Mangrove LuxCo III S.à r.l. As of the reporting date and until the release of this report, no material event of default has been occurred.

Categorization within the levels of the fair value hierarchy is based on the measurement of the underlying inputs: Level 1 inputs: quoted prices (unadjusted) in active markets for identical financial assets and liabilities. Level 2 inputs: quoted market prices that are observable as direct (prices) or indirect (derived from prices) inputs used to measure fair value and that are not quoted prices as defined by Level 1. Level 3 inputs: inputs that are not based on observable market data. As a result, their fair values correspond to the carrying amounts. Regarding Tracking preferred equity certificates / shareholder loan we refer to Note 6.2. The carrying amount of the trade payables and other current liabilities that are subject to the measurement rules of IFRS 9 corresponds to their fair value. The fair value of fixed-interest liabilities is the present value of their expected future cash flows. They are discounted at the rates prevailing at the reporting date. The carrying amount of variable-rate liabilities corresponds to their fair value. The fair value of derivatives and embedded derivatives are calculated using quoted exchange rates and yield curves observable in the market. Accordingly, they are categorized within Level 2 of the fair value hierarchy. The fair value of senior secured notes is categorized within Level 1. Fair Value is calculated according to its quoted (unadjusted) price in active market. The fair value of other financial assets of shares in non-consolidated subsidiaries and other equity investments is measured on the basis of available financial information, such as transaction prices for financing rounds or business plans to the extent that this information is reliable, or, as an approximation, as cost, which is considered an appropriate estimate of fair value as no more suitable information is available. A review is carried out on a quarterly basis using all information available on the equity investments to establish whether cost is still representative of fair value. This would not be the case, for example, in the event of a significant change in the market in which the equity investments are active. As cost is the sole input factor for fair value, a percentage change in cost results in an equal change in fair value. The estimated fair value would increase (decrease) with any increase (decrease) in cost. A 1% increase (decrease) would not materially affect fair value. Accordingly, they are categorized within Level 3 of the fair value hierarchy.

Contingent liabilities, other financial obligations, and litigation #### 9.1 Contingent liabilities A Contingent liability is according to IAS 37.10 a “possible obligation that arises from past events and whose existence will be confirmed only by the occurrence or non-occurrence of one or more uncertain future events not wholly within the control of the entity; or a present obligation that arises from past events but is not recognized because: ###### (i) it is not probable that an outflow of resources embodying economic benefits will be required to settle the obligation; or ###### (ii) the amount of the obligation cannot be measured with sufficient reliability.”, i.e. uncertainties for which the outcome has not been determined. If the occurrence is probable and the outcome can be estimated reliable, a liability is recorded in the balance sheet. As of December 31, 2022, Mangrove Group has a recognized contingent liability relating to the SSNs which amounts to EUR 26,412 thousand (2021: EUR 34,165 thousand) as of December 31, 2022. This contingent liability was recognized via purchase price allocation.. Several companies of Mangrove Group have issued or instructed the issuance of bank guarantees in favor of customers or lenders. These bank guarantees are not considered to be contingent liabilities because these guarantees are linked to a performance obligation to be rendered by Mangrove Group. #### 9.2 Other financial obligations Other financial obligations as of December 31, 2022 related to purchase commitments and bank guarantees.

Mangrove Holding Group companies utilized bank guarantees in the amount of EUR 157.7 million (as of December 31, 2021: EUR 137.6 million). The major part of the lines is granted by a bank consortium (total line EUR 190 million, thereof EUR 134.2 million utilized). #### 9.3 Litigation A number of claims have been brought arising out of the financial restructuring as described below (the “Restructuring”). However, as with any dispute, the outcome of these proceedings cannot be guaranteed. In the opinion of Management, the ultimate liabilities resulting from such claims will not materially affect the consolidated financial position of the Group, but it might be possible that the conclusion of such proceedings may result in future income or expenses if the amounts that have been accrued for them are higher or lower than required. On October 9, 2019, Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l. acquired the shares in Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. as described elsewhere in these notes (e.g. chapter “1.2 Acquisition of Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. and its subsidiaries and successful Refinancing on October 9, 2019”), associated preferred equity certificates and any intercompany payables owed by Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. to its former parent company Galapagos S.A. The acquisition was made in connection with the Restructuring, which was completed on October 9, 2019. A number of sets of internationally recognized advisors were involved in the Restructuring and management believes that the Restructuring was fully legally effective and complied with all obligations, including under the applicable finance documents. The following claims have been brought which arise out of the Restructuring: - Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. has commenced proceedings in England against inter alios the Security Trustee under the Intercreditor Agreement which effected the Restructuring, the trustee which held rights on behalf of the Galapagos Senior Notes and each of the plaintiffs in the New York, German and Luxembourg proceedings described below, requesting that the English Court makes a series of declarations inter alia that the Restructuring complied with the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement. The English proceedings do not contain any claim for damages. A challenge to the jurisdiction of the English Court to hear this claim was lodged by two of the defendants in these proceedings and was heard in December 2020. This challenge was dismissed by the English Court on 19 January 2021. The trial commenced on 9 March and concluded on 23 March. A judgment is expected before summer 2023. - A claim in the Supreme Court of the State of New York by a beneficial holder of the Galapagos Senior Notes (“NY Claimant”) against inter alios Galapagos Holding (former indirect parent of Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l.) and certain of its subsidiaries (now being subsidiaries of Mangrove Group) relating to the Restructuring. The plaintiff alleges that the Restructuring wrongly deprived it of value by diverting assets away from the Group and releasing certain guarantees. The plaintiff seeks: (i) damages; and (ii) a reversal of the steps taken to affect the Restructuring. In addition, the plaintiff seeks a declaration that the release of liabilities under the Galapagos Senior Notes Indenture pursuant to the provisions of the former Intercreditor Agreement applying to certain liabilities of the Group was invalid (in other words, that this part of the Restructuring also be reversed). The Supreme Court of the State of New York decided on 22 July 2020 to stay this action pending a decision from the English Court as to its jurisdiction in these matters (as referred to ----- above). The plaintiff indicated that it intended to appeal this decision, but no substantive appeal was actually served. Following the decision by the English Court on 19 January 2021, the proceedings in New York are still stayed. - On October 31, 2019 main insolvency proceedings were opened over the assets of Galapagos S.A. in Düsseldorf, Germany. Two appeals were lodged at the German Federal Supreme Court on the jurisdiction of the Düsseldorf insolvency court. Following such appeals, on December 17, 2020, the German Federal Court of Justice referred certain legal questions concerning matters of European insolvency law (and, consequently, the jurisdiction of the Düsseldorf court in such insolvency proceedings) to the Court of Justice of the European Union for determination. The Court of Justice of the European Union rendered its decision on 24 March 2022, which confirmed that the German courts did not have authority to appoint the administrator on 23 August 2019, given that the European regime applied to the UK at this time. Following this decision, on 30 June 2022 the English insolvency court made a winding-up order with regard to Galapagos S.A., and has therefore asserted its jurisdiction over the insolvency proceedings (after it had stayed the insolvency proceedings in England in August 2019 due to the court in Düsseldorf, Germany, claiming its jurisdiction). The German Federal Court of Justice rendered its decision (based on the Court of Justice of the European Union decision) on 8 December 2022, declaring that since the English courts did not make their winding-up order prior to the Brexit transition period, i.e. 31 December 2020 such that the German courts are no longer bound by the EU Insolvency regulation when considering proceedings opened in England, the German courts had retrospective authority to appoint the administrator on 23 August 2019,. Thus, the German insolvency proceedings remain in place, alongside the competing equivalent English proceedings. - The purported administrator of Galapagos S.A., Luxembourg (former 100 percent shareholder of Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l.) has brought a claim against Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l. and Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. in Luxembourg detailing his allegations that the Restructuring (i.e. the refinancing of Galapagos Group and the sale of Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. to Mangrove Group) involved a fraudulent exercise of a Luxembourg share pledge and that it should, therefore, be unwound. However, no steps have been taken by the administrator to progress this claw back action. In addition to the main claim, following the administrator’s application the Luxembourg Court granted an ex parte “preservation order” whereby a trustee was appointed to prevent an actual or de facto liquidation of Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. This escrow order has been successfully appealed and set aside by the Luxembourg Court. This decision was then appealed by the administrator, but this appeal was rejected by the Court. A further appeal was then made by the administrator to the Luxembourg Cour de cassation which overturned the Court of Appeal’s decision to set aside the escrow order on the basis that share pledge enforcements cannot be challenged under Luxembourg law. The matter was referred back to the Luxembourg Court to consider the position on the merits. The Luxembourg Court of Appeal decided that the administrator had not demonstrated that any fraudulent action took place and it therefore dismissed the appeal. The consequence of these various actions is that there is no escrow order in place. Finally, the administrator has brought a separate action challenging the 2021 restructuring of the assets of Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. This action raises similar allegations to those made in the claw back action. The Luxembourg Court has yet to order a timetable for Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l. and Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l’ to file their defence. - Following an application of the purported administrator of Galapagos S.A., the District Court of Düsseldorf, Germany, had issued an injunction (einstweilige Verfügung) against Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l., ordering an escrow agent to hold the shares in Galapagos BidCo S.à r.l. This order was successfully appealed and, consequently, the injunction was lifted in June 2021. Further, by the same plaintiff, a main proceeding (Hauptsacheverfahren) has been initiated against inter alios Mangrove LuxCo IV S.à r.l. A first hearing took place in February 2023 with a decision announced for May 2023. Based on legal advice of leading international law firms based in the UK, Luxembourg, Germany and the US ----- (privilege in respect of which is not waived) Management assesses the risk from the above-mentioned ongoing litigation as well as future litigation as follows: 1) The risk that the Restructuring would be unwound is considered remote; and 2) The risk of having to pay damages to former holders of the Galapagos Senior Notes or any other third party is considered unlikely. In the unlikely event of successful damage claims against the Company or any of its subsidiaries, the RCF Facility Agreement, the SGF Facility Agreement, the Cash Cover Loan Facility Agreement and the Mangrove Notes Indenture will permit the Group to incur up to EUR 100 million of new indebtedness only for these purposes which will rank senior to the Mangrove Senior Notes. Therefore, Management is confident to be able to fund such claims from new indebtedness and/or cash available. ## 10.Other disclosures #### 10.1 Consolidated cash flow statement disclosures from continuing operations

Pursuant to IAS 24 persons or entities that (jointly) control or are (jointly) controlled by Mangrove Group shall be disclosed, unless they are included in the consolidated financial statements. The disclosure obligation under IAS 24 furthermore extends to transactions with persons who exercise a significant influence on the financial and business policies of the Mangrove Group. A significant influence on the financial and business policies of the Mangrove Group can hereby be based on a shareholding of 20 percent or more of Mangrove, a seat in the management board of Mangrove Group or another key management position on board either of the parent of Mangrove Group or on lower level holding company. Related parties of the Mangrove Group in accordance with IAS 24 primarily comprise the shareholders of the Mangrove and the subsidiaries of Mangrove Group, which are not consolidated due to materiality reasons. ###### 10.3.2 Transactions with key management personnel In 2022 the members of the Board of Managers of the parent company earned EUR 9 thousand (2021: EUR 9 thousand) of salaries and attendance fees. For more details regarding the share-based payments we refer to Note 10.5 #### 10.5 Share based payments In 2020 certain management personnel (“co-investors”) were invited to participate in the Mangrove Group’s Management Incentive Plan (“Mangrove MIP”). This investment takes the form of part-ownership of Mangrove Management Invest S.C.A; an entity which has a part-ownership of Mangrove LuxCo II S.à r.l., the parent company of Mangrove LuxCo III S.à r.l.. In order to participate in the MIP, an initial cash investment was required from the co-investors, which was at not less than the fair value of the investments. During the year 2022 an additional Management Incentive Plan was launched. Again, certain management personnel were invited to participate in the new Kelvion Thermal Solutions Group’s Management Incentive Plan (“KTS MIP”). This investment takes the form of part-ownership of TESCO Management S.C.A; an entity which has a minority of TES LuxCo S.à r.l.. TES LuxCo S.à r.l. is the parent company of the Mangrove´s business unit Kelvion Thermal Solutions Group. Similar to the first MIP (“Mangrove MIP”) launched in 2020, the investment is structured in a way that the co-investors are taking a part ownership of a holding company via an investment vehicle. In order to participate in the KTS MIP, in a first step the co-investors sold their contribution in the Mangrove MIP at fair value to Mangrove LuxCo I S.à r.l.. In the amount of this receivable from Mangrove LuxCo I S.à r.l., the co-investors received an investment in the new KTS MIP. The initial cash related investment of the co-investors (receivable from Mangrove LuxCo I S.à r.l.) in KTS MIP was not less than to the fair value of the investment in any case. The nature of both schemes is such that co-investors’ investments will only be realised upon “exit” of the Group’s current shareholders, with exception of specific events (for example co-investors leaving the employment of the Group). It is anticipated that co-investors will participate in the MIPs until such exit is achieved. The lead investor is permitted to issue further equity, and each co-investor has the explicit right to participate further in the MIPs, such that their investment is not diluted. In the context of IFRS 2, both MIPs are considered to be equity-settled share-based payment arrangements. #### 10.6 Company bodies The board members of Mangrove LuxCo III S.à r.l. are: Matthew Crill Joakim Lindström-Formicola ----- #### 10.7 Shareholder committees The members of Kelvion's shareholder committee are: - Hubertus Mühlhäuser - Michael Gahleitner - Claus von Hermann In total, the Group incurred shareholder committee costs amounting to EUR 182 thousand. #### 10.8 Disclosure of Audit Fees KPMG Audit, S.à r.l., Luxembourg, and other member firms of the KPMG network, provided the following services during the past two financial years to Mangrove LuxCo III S.à r.l.: (EUR thousand) **2022** **2021 Audit 1,663 2,135 Tax Consulting Services 1,503 1,809 Audit-related services 349 Other services 87 93

#### 10.9 Companies exempt under § 264 (3) HGB The following domestic Group companies in the legal form of a corporation have fulfilled the conditions required under § 264 (3) HGB to make use of the exemption provision and therefore waive the preparation of a management report and notes, the audit of the annual financial statements by an auditor and the disclosure of their annual financial statements for the 2022 financial year: - Kelvion PHE GmbH - Kelvion Machine Cooling Systems GmbH - Kelvion Brazed PHE GmbH - Kelvion Holding GmbH - Kelvion Industriebeteiligungen GmbH - Kelvion Insurance Broker and Services GmbH - Kelvion Germany GmbH - Kelvion Thermal Solutions Germany GmbH - Kelvion Thermal Solutions Holding GmbH - ENEXIO Management GmbH - ENEXIO Germany GmbH - Mangrove GermanCo I GmbH - Mangrove GermanCo II GmbH ----- ## 11.Segment reporting #### 11.1 Disclosures by segment The Segment Reporting of the Mangrove Group focuses on the four segments “Kelvion Refrigeration Technologies” (“RT”), “Kelvion Machine Cooling Systems” (“MCS”), “Kelvion Plate Heat Exchangers” (PHE”) and “Kelvion Thermal Solutions” (“KTS”). These “segments” had previously the status of being Kelvion’s “business units”. All segments are responsible for its respective markets and applications and focus on a distinct technology and product portfolio. In the past the business activities of the Mangrove Group were divided into the two segments Kelvion and ENEXIO. For more details regarding the Segment reporting we refer to Note 1.3.
